questions.question_text: Patient with HIV presenting with bouts of cough and fever. Which medium is appropriate for diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A patient with HIV presenting with cough and fever raises suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), which is common in immunocompromised individuals. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is a specialized culture medium used to isolate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Lab Investigations for TB: 2 Investigatio ns Purpose Advantages Limitations Sputum smear • Initial screening for pulmonary TB. • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid- fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope. • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours. • Low sensitivit y, especiall y in cases of extrapul monary TB or in patients with HIV. • Cannot differenti ate between Mycobac terium tubercul osis and non- tubercul ous mycobac teria (NTM). Culture Methods • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility. • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensenor Middlebrook agar. • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster. • The gold standard for TB diagnosis. • Allows for drug susceptibility testing. • Time- consumi ng; results can take weeks. • Requires specializ ed laborator y facilities. 3 Xpert MTB/RIF • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance. • Method: • A cartridge- based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT). • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge. • Rapid results (within 2 hours). • High sensitivity and specificity. • Simultaneousl y detects rifampicin resistance. • More expensiv e than smear microsco py. • Does not provide full drug susceptib ility testing. LAMP (Loop- Mediated Isothermal Amplificati on) • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. • Method: • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling. • Sputum or other specimens are used. • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours). • High specificity and sensitivity. • Can be performed at the point of care. • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB. • Less widely available than PCR- based tests. • Cannot detect drug resistanc e directly. 4 TrueNat • Point-of-care test for TB detection. • Method: • Uses a micro- PCR technology to amplify DNA. • Results are available within 60 minutes. • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities. • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions. Line Probe Assay (LPA) • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid). • Method: • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted. • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip. • Rapid results (within 1-2 days). • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance. • Requires a laborator y setup and trained personne l. • Not suitable for all strains of TB. RFLP • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis. • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent). Tinsdale medium(Option A) is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria. MacConkey agar (Option C) is used for gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella. Loeffler serum slope (LSS)(Option D) enhances the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 5

questions.question_text: A 45-year-old woman presented with tingling sensation of lateral 3 digits with loss of sensation of base of thumb on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Which is the nerve involved?
questions.explanation: • The patient presents with: • Tingling of lateral 3 digits 8 • Loss of sensation at the base (root) of the thumb on the dorsal aspect • These findings are best explained by involvement of the superficial branch of the radial nerve, which provides: • Cutaneous sensation to the dorsum of the hand, especially the base of the thumb and proximal parts of the lateral 3½ fingers, excluding the fingertips. • The tingling in the dorsal aspect of the lateral 3 digits may also be due to involvement of the proximal dorsal hand region, which is supplied by the radial nerve, not the median nerve. • The median nerve supplies the palmar aspect and the distal dorsal phalanges (fingertips) of the lateral 3½ digits, not the base of the thumb dorsally. Sensory Supply of the Dorsal and Ventral Aspects of the Palm and Fingers: Region Nerve Area Supplied Ventral (Palmar) Aspect Lateral 3½ fingers + lateral palm Median nerve Palmar surface of thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of ring finger + palm Medial 1½ fingers + medial palm Ulnar nerve Palmar surface of little finger and medial half of ring finger + palm Thenar eminence (skin) Median nerve Over the base of thumb (root of thumb, palmar side) Hypothenar eminence Ulnar nerve Over the base of little finger Dorsal Aspect Lateral 3½ fingertips (nail beds) Median nerve Dorsal distal phalanges of thumb, index, middle, and lateral ring finger Medial 2½ fingers + hand dorsum Ulnar nerve Dorsal aspect of little finger, medial half of ring finger, and medial hand Lateral 1½ dorsum + web space Radial nerve Dorsum of hand near base of thumb, lateral hand, and 1st web space 9 Root (base) of thumb Radial nerve Dorsal aspect of thumb base and adjacent dorsum of hand Ulnar nerve (Option B):

questions.question_text: Which segment of the nephron has the lowest osmolality under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?
questions.option_b: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
questions.explanation: The early distal tubule has the lowest osmolality under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). • Mechanism: 11 • ADH increases water reabsorption in the collecting duct and late distal tubule, concentrating the urine. • The descending limb of the loop of Henle is highly permeable to water but not solutes, leading to an increase in osmolality. • In contrast, the early distal tubule is impermeable to water, but actively reabsorbs NaCl, making the tubular fluid hypotonic. • As a result, the lowest osmolality is found in the early distal tubule (~100mOsm/kg), even in the presence of ADH. Descending limb of the loop of Henle (Option B) is
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the afferent limb of the corneal reflex? 12?
questions.explanation: The corneal reflex (blink reflex) involves two components: 1. Afferent limb (sensory input): • The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) detects touch or irritation on the cornea and sends sensory signals to the brainstem. 2. Efferent limb (motor response): • The facial nerve (CN VII) activates the orbicularis oculi muscle, causing eyelid closure. Reflex Afferent Nerve Efferent Nerve Accommodation II (Optic nerve) III (Oculomotor nerve) Corneal V₁ (Ophthalmic, nasociliary branch) Bilateral VII (Facial nerve, temporal branch - orbicularis oculi) 13 Cough X (Vagus nerve) X (Vagus nerve, also phrenic and spinal nerves) Gag IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve) X (Vagus nerve) Jaw Jerk V₃ (Mandibular branch, sensory from masseter) V₃ (Mandibular branch, motor to masseter) Lacrimation V₁ (Ophthalmic branch) (loss of reflex does not preclude emotional tears) VII (Facial nerve) Pupillary II (Optic nerve) III (Oculomotor nerve) Optic nerve (Option A): Involved in the pupillary light reflex, not the corneal reflex. Facial nerve (Option B): Acts as the efferent limb, responsible for blinking, not the afferent limb. Trochlear nerve (Option D): Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which controls eye movement but has no role in the corneal reflex.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A firefighter was admitted with fever, cough, culture shown in the image reveals gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent. 14?
questions.explanation: The firefighter with fever and cough has a culture showing gram-negative, oxidase- positive bacilli with fluorescent colonies under UV light, which is characteristic ofPseudomonas aeruginosa. Diagnostic Tests for Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Diagnostic Method Description Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa Sample Collection Collect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Specimens vary based on the site of infection. Microscopy Gram stain Gram-negative rods; motile with flagella. Culture Growth on common laboratory media: Blood agar Produces beta-hemolytic gray, moist colonies. MacConkey agar Produces pale, non-lactose fermenting colonies, Fluorescence under UV light. Nutrient agar Produces large, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen. Peptone water Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle. 16 Cetrimide Agar Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin). King’s medium used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas Biochemical Tests Various biochemical tests to identify specific metabolic properties: Oxidase test Positive Catalase test Positive ICUT Test: Indole test Negative Citrate test Positive Urease test Negative Triple sugar test Shows alkaline slant with no gas and hydrogen sulfide. Molecular Methods PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencing Provides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA. Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing Disk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testing Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics. Klebsiella (Option A): Although Gram-negative, it is oxidase-negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and typically forms mucoid colonies due to its capsule. Staphylococcus aureus (Option B) is Gram-positive, whereas the given organism is Gram- negative. It does not produce fluorescent pigments under UV light and forms golden-yellow colonies, not greenish ones. Serratia (Option D)is Gram-negative and oxidase-negative. Some Serratia species produce red pigment (prodigiosin), but they do not fluoresce under UV light like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 17
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Chronic malnutrition is best measured by?
questions.explanation: Chronic malnutrition is best measured by height for age. WHO Classification of Malnutrition Moderately underweight Weight-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs. Severely underweight Weight-for-age is < -3 SDs. Moderately wasted Weight-for-length/height is between -2 and -3 SDs. Severely wasted Weight-for-length/height is < -3 SDs. Moderate Acute Malnutrition • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs. • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm. Severe Acute Malnutrition: • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDs. • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm. • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema. Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition) Length/height-for-age is between -2 and -3 SDs. Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition) Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDs. Weight for age (Option B)is used to determine whether a child is moderately or severely underweight. Weight for height (Option C)is used to determine the severity of acute malnutrition and wasting. Body mass index (Option D)is used to determine the severity of acute malnutrition.

questions.question_text: Which of the following changes occurs during muscle contraction while exercising?
questions.option_d: M length increase and I decrease
questions.explanation: During muscle contraction, the sarcomere shortens, leading to specific changes in the myofilament structure: • A-band: The length of the A-band remains the same during muscle contraction because it corresponds to the length of the myosin filaments, which do not change. • H-band: The H-band decreases or disappears as the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments during contraction, reducing the region where only myosin is present. • I-band: The length of the I-band decreases as the sarcomere shortens and the actin filaments overlap more with the myosin filaments. • M-line: The M-line becomes more prominent as it marks the central point of the sarcomere where the thick filaments are anchored. M length increase (Option A) is
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Which anti-epileptic drug is commonly associated with gum hypertrophy and dizziness as side effects?
questions.explanation: Phenytoin is a commonly used anti-epileptic drug (AED) that is well known for causing gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and dizziness as side effects. • Mechanism of Action: • Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilising neuronal membranes and preventing seizures. Adverse effects of Phenytoin include: 1. Gum Hypertrophy: Overgrowth of gingival collagen fibres can cause significant dental and oral health issues. 2. Hirsutism and Acne: Excessive hair growth and acne are common dermatological side effects. 3. Coarsening of Facial Features: Long-term use can lead to noticeable changes in facial appearance. 4. Hypersensitivity Reactions: These can manifest as rashes, discoid lupus erythematosus, lymphadenopathy, and neutropenia. 5. Megaloblastic Anemia: Phenytoin can interfere with folate absorption, leading to anaemia. 6. Osteomalacia: Bone softening or weakening can occur due to interference with vitamin D metabolism. 7. Hyperglycemia: Inhibition of insulin release can result in elevated blood sugar levels. 8. Toxicity: Symptoms of toxicity include diplopia, nystagmus, and ataxia. 9. During Pregnancy: Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a risk, characterised by hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, harelip, and microcephaly. Carbamazepine (Option A) is
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: The toughness of bacterial cell walls is due to:
questions.explanation: Toughness of bacterial cell wall is due to Peptidoglycan. Bacterial Cell Wall: • Tough and rigid structure surrounding the bacterium. • 10-25 nm in thickness and constitutes 20-25% of the dry weight of the cell. • Functions of Cell Wall: • Provides protection to the cell against osmotic lysis. • Confers rigidity upon bacteria due to the presence of a peptidoglycan layer in the cell wall. • Protect a cell from toxic substances and is the site of action of several antibiotics. • Contains certain virulence factors (e.g., endotoxin), which contribute to bacterial pathogenicity. • Antibody raised against specific cell wall antigens (e.g., antibody to LPS) may provide immunity against some bacterial infections. Difference between Gram-positive and Gram-negative Bacterial Cell Walls: Gram-positive Features Gram-negative Thick layer Peptidoglycan layer Thin layer 100 layer thick Thickness 1–2-layer thickness 2-5 % Lipid content 15-50% • Peptidoglycans+++ • Lipoproteins • Teichoic acid Composition • Lipopolysaccharide • Lipoproteins • Peptidoglycan+ Absent Outer membrane Present 25 Absent Periplasmic space + Porins Present Present Teichoic acid (used for attachment) Absent Present Pentapeptide cross bridge Absent Present NAM-NAG Present Teichoic acid (Option A) is present in Gram-positive bacteria, but it mainly contributes to cell wall stability and ion transport, not toughness. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) (Option C) are found in Gram-negative bacteria, but they form the outer membrane, playing a role in immune evasion and permeability, not rigidity. The outer membrane (Option D) is present in Gram-negative bacteria, providing selective permeability and protection, but the structural strength comes from peptidoglycan.
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: Which anti-tubercular drug is associated with mutations in the KATG gene?
questions.explanation: Isoniazid (INH) resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis is commonly associated with mutations in the KATG gene, which encodes catalase-peroxidase. • Mechanism of Action: • Isoniazid is a prodrug that requires activation by KatG (catalase-peroxidase enzyme). • Activated INH inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, disrupting the mycobacterial cell wall. • Mechanism of Resistance: • Mutations in KATG (especially Ser315Thr mutation) prevent isoniazid activation, leading to drug resistance. • Other mutations involve inhA gene (affecting the target enzyme enoyl-ACP reductase), leading to low-level resistance. The mechanisms of resistance with Isoniazid are given below. Mechanism of resistance KatG gene mutation INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase- peroxidase produced by the KATg gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug 27 KasA gene mutation Component of cell wall mycolic acid InhA gene overexpression Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug) Rifampicin (Option A) is

questions.question_text: Which of the following is excreted in the urine of patients with pentosuria?
questions.explanation: L-Xylulose is excreted in the urine of patients with essential pentosuria, a rare benign metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of L-xylulose reductase. This leads to the accumulation and urinary excretion of L-xylulose, which can be mistaken for glucose in urine tests, but patients remain asymptomatic with no metabolic consequences. Essential Pentosuria Feature Essential Pentosuria Cause Deficiency of L-xylulose reductase Metabolic Effect Increased excretion of L-xylulose in urine Clinical Symptoms None (asymptomatic) Diagnosis Urine sugar analysis + Chromatography Treatment No treatment needed D-Ribose (Option B) is

questions.question_text: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation: Bacillus cereuscauses rapid-onset vomiting (within 1–6 hours) after consuming contaminated fried rice. Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus: Clinical Features Details Food Poisoning • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic. • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post- ingestion. • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare) • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours. • Some cases may include diarrhoea Other Infections • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus: Diagnostic Method Details 32 Food Poisoning • Culture of implicated food essential. • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis. • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis. Culture Characteristics • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar. • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance. • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin Selective Media • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources Microscopy • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli. • Motile Clostridium botulinum (Option B) causes botulism, presenting with descending paralysis and no vomiting, with symptoms appearing 12–36 hours after ingestion. Escherichia coli (Option C): ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli) causes watery diarrhea, not isolated vomiting, and has a longer incubation period (12–72 hours). Shigella dysenteriae (Option D): Causes bloody diarrhea (dysentery) with fever, not acute vomiting.

questions.question_text: What is the type of cartilage present in the histology section given below?
questions.explanation: • The image shows a glassy, bluish-white matrix with chondrocytes in lacunae • Hyaline cartilage is the most common type. It has a glassy, translucent matrix due to the fine collagen fibrils. Chondrocytes (cartilage cells) are scattered throughout the matrix, often appearing in small groups (isogenous groups) within lacunae (spaces). Types of Cartilage Characteristic Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common) Elastic Cartilage (Yellow cartilage) (Option B) Fibrocartilage (Option D) Matrix appearance Homogeneous, basophilic Contains elastic fiber network Numerous collagen bundles Chondrocyte arrangement Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups) Similar to hyaline Single rows or isogenous groups Perichondrium Present (except in articular cartilage) Present Absent Main fiber type Type II collagen Elastic fibers Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen Main functions Structural support, forms articular surfaces Provides flexibility and resilience Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption Examples Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube Intervertebral discs, menisci 35 36 37 38 39 40 Articular cartilage (Option C): Articular cartilage is a specific type of hyaline cartilage covering the bones' surfaces in synovial joints. While it is a form of hyaline cartilage, the term "articular" refers to its location rather than a different type of cartilage.

questions.question_text: A 3-year-old child presented with multiple burn injuries involving the entire head, neck & upper limb. What is the percentage of burn?
questions.explanation: In children, the total body surface area (TBSA) percentages differ from adults due to the larger head-to-body ratio. According to the Rule of Nines adjusted for children and the Lund and Browder chart: 62 • The entire head and neck account for approximately 18% of the TBSA in a 3-year-old child. • Each upper limb accounts for approximately 9% of the TBSA. Adding these together: 18% (head and neck) + 9% (one upper limb) = 27% According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated: Adults Children Infants Head & neck 9% 18% 20% Front of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Back of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Lower limb 18 x 2 = 36% 13.5 x 2 = 27% 10 x 2 = 20% Upper limb 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Perineum 1% 1% 40-44% (Option B): This value overestimates the burn area. A 40-44% burn would imply involvement of larger or additional body areas beyond the head, neck, and one upper limb, such as parts of the trunk or both upper limbs. 18-20% (Option C): This value roughly corresponds to the head and neck alone, without including the upper limb. Since the upper limb is also involved, the percentage should be higher. 5-10% (Option D): This severely underestimates the burn size. The entire head and neck alone exceed 10%, so including one upper limb must be substantially more.

questions.question_text: When is a blood sample taken to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: The blood sample taken for diagnosing neonatal hypothyroidism is 48-72 hours after delivery. Diagnosis: • Primary hypothyroidism: • T4 level: low • TSH usually>100mIU/L • Central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism: • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis • Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae • X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures Screening: • Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism • At birth, with umbilical cord blood (Option A) Diagnostic: • Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72 hrs • Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge (vs Option B and C) • Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both ASH's first strategy: 74 • Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot • If TSH>20mIU/L, recheck • Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated. Treatment: • Oral levothyroxine ( early morning with empty stomach for older children and for newborns; it is to be given at a fixed time) • The dose is higher in the earlier age group, and as the babies grow, the dose reduces. • Newborn- 10-15mg/kg/day • Children- 2-4mg/kg/day
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 70-year-old man was admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis, a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), is the most common cause of prosthetic valve infective endocarditis. Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis: • It occurs following cardiac valve replacement. • Early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs within 12 months of valve replacement): • Generally nosocomial. • Results from intra-operative contamination of the prosthesis or a bacteremic postoperative complication. • Common agents: CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis) and S. aureus. • Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs after 12 months of valve replacement): • Usually community-acquired. • Common agents: Viridans streptococci. • Overall: • Regardless of the time of onset after surgery, CoNS are the most common agents (at least 68-85%). • Majority are methicillin-resistant CoNS. Streptococcus viridans (Option A)is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, particularly following dental procedures or in patients with pre-existing valvular disease. However, it is not the primary cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), where Staphylococcal species predominate. Staphylococcus aureus (Option C)is a virulent pathogen that causes rapidly progressive (acute) infective endocarditis, affecting both native and prosthetic valves. It is a leading cause of healthcare-associated IE, often seen in intravenous drug users (IVDU) and patients with catheters or implanted devices. While it can cause prosthetic valve IE, it is more common in late-onset cases rather than early PVE. Enterococci (Option D) (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis) are opportunistic pathogens that cause subacute endocarditis, particularly in elderly patients with genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections. Though they can infect prosthetic valves, they are not the primary causative agent. 76

questions.question_text: A baby is born with microcephaly, intracerebral calcification and chorioretinitis. Which teratogenic infections is the mother suffering from?
questions.explanation: The presence of characteristic intracranial calcifications, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis are features of congenital toxoplasmosis. Etiology and Clinical Features of Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Category Details Etiology Primary maternal infection with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy is the primary cause Risk Factors Infection during the first trimester: severe outcomes, lower transmission rate (~17%) Infection during third trimester: milder outcomes, higher transmission rate (~65%) Clinical Features CNS: Hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, seizures, developmental delays, microcephaly in severe brain damage Ocular:Chorioretinitis, vision impairment, strabismus, photophobia, epiphora Systemic: Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, prematurity Other: Jaundice, thrombocytopenia, rash, hearing loss Diagnosis: Diagnosis Method Details Fetal Ultrasound Performed every 2 weeks during gestation after diagnosis of maternal infection. PCR Analysis of Amniotic Fluid Used for prenatal diagnosis of fetal infection. Serologic Tests Persistent or rising titers in dye/IFA tests, positive IgM-ELISA. 80 Newborn Evaluation General, ophthalmologic, and neurologic exams; head CT scan for intracranial calcifications. CSF Analysis Lumbar puncture with analysis for Toxoplasma-specific IgG and IgM, total IgG, cells, glucose, and protein. Toxoplasma Isolation Isolation from placenta, infant’s leukocytes, and CSF using PCR Management: Treatment Details Pyrimethamine and Sulfadiazine, along with Folinic Acid (Calcium Leucovorin) Synergistic action against Toxoplasma gondii. Standard treatment for congenital toxoplasmosis. Folinic Acid is administered to prevent bone marrow suppression caused by pyrimethamine Spiramycin Used in pregnant women during the first trimester to prevent vertical transmission. Monitoring Regular leukocyte counts twice weekly to detect neutropenia and other hematologic effects. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection(Option B) can also cause intracranial calcifications; however, these are more commonly seen in a periventricular pattern.While there is some overlap, the calcifications in congenital toxoplasmosis are often more diffuse. 81 Varicella (Option C)presents with microcephaly and chorioretinitis. But it is associated with microphthalmia, cataracts, cortical atrophy, seizures, mental retardation, etc. as well. Rubella (Option D)presents with patent ductus arteriosus, bilateral cataracts, and salt & pepper retinopathy, which are classical signs of congenital rubella syndrome
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: Identify the defect in the given image:
questions.explanation: The given image depicts a newborn with an open neural tube defect, specifically rachischisis or myeloschisis, which is a severe form of spina bifida where the neural tissue is exposed without skin or meningeal covering. Neural tube defects: Category Details Definition Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly. Inheritance Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance. Maternal risk factors Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency. Types of NTDs Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly. Spina bifida occulta Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence. Craniorachischisis Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus. 84 Meningocele Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering. Myelomeningocele Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation. Anencephaly Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore. Iniencephaly Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect. Prenatal diagnosis Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE). Prevention 0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child). Risk of recurrence 3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children. Treatment Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present. Meningoencephalocele (Option B):
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: During spermatogenesis, which of the following hormones inhibits Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) secretion?
questions.explanation: Inhibin is the primary hormone that inhibits Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) secretion during spermatogenesis. Function of Sertoli cells: 86 • Only Sertoli cells form the blood-testis barrier • Nourishment and protection to developing sperm cells. • Sertoli cells contain receptors for FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and androgens, which indirectly support spermatogenesis. • Sertoli cells produce androgen-binding protein (ABP). • Sertoli cells express the aromatase enzyme, responsible for converting testosterone to estrogen. • They produce extracellular matrix components and anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH/MIS), which induces regression of Müllerian ducts during male fetal development. • Sertoli cells secrete Inhibin B, a crucial factor in the testes that negatively regulates (decreases) FSH secretion through feedback mechanisms. Testosterone (Option A) is
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation? 87?
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A young male presented with weakness in the lower half of the right side of his face, with drooping of the angle of his mouth. He is unable to raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.option_a: Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
questions.option_b: Supranuclear facial palsy on left side
questions.explanation: • Infranuclear facial palsy occurs when there is damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) after it exits the brainstem. 90 • This leads to weakness or paralysis of the muscles of facial expression on the same side (right side in this case) of the face. • The patient will have difficulty raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes, and drooping of the mouth on the affected side. Both the upper and lower facial muscles are affected. Facial nerve palsy: Feature Upper Motor Neuron Lesion (Supranuclear) Lower Motor Neuron Lesion (Infranuclear) Lesion Location Motor cortex, connection from motor cortex to facial nucleus in pons Facial nucleus, anywhere along CN VII Affected Side Contralateral Ipsilateral Muscles Involved Lower muscles of facial expression Upper and lower muscles of facial expression Forehead Involved? Spared, due to bilateral UMN innervation Affected Other Symptoms Variable; depends on size of lesion Incomplete eye closure (dry eyes, corneal ulceration), hyperacusis, loss of taste sensation to anterior tongue
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A patient shows flat affect. What does it indicate?
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions is not reversed with the administration of atropine? 93?
questions.option_b: Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade
questions.explanation: Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade is not reversed by atropine administration. Atropine is an antimuscarinic (anticholinergic) agent that competitively blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It has no effect on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, which are responsible for skeletal muscle contraction. Therefore, atropine cannot reverse muscle weakness caused by neuromuscular blocking agents. Atropine Classification • Anticholinergic drug (Muscarinic receptor antagonist) • Competitive antagonist at muscarinic receptors 94 Mechanism of Action • Competitive inhibition of postganglionic acetylcholine muscarinic receptors • Blocks all subtypes of muscarinic receptors (M₁, M₂, M₃) • Direct vagolytic action leading to parasympathetic inhibition • Allows preexisting sympathetic stimulation to predominate Pharmacological Actions 1. CNS Effects • Overall CNS stimulant action • Stimulates medullary centers (vagal, respiratory, vasomotor) • Depresses vestibular excitation (antimotion sickness property) • Suppresses tremor and rigidity in parkinsonism • High doses: cortical excitation, restlessness, hallucinations, delirium • Very high doses: respiratory depression and coma 2. CVS Heart: • Tachycardia (primary effect) - blocks M₂ receptors on SA node(Option A Ruled Out) • Initial transient bradycardia may occur with IM/SC injection • Abbreviates refractory period of A-V node • Facilitates A-V conduction • Shortens P-R interval Blood Pressure: • No consistent/marked effect on BP • Tachycardia and vasomotor center stimulation tend to raise BP • Histamine release and direct vasodilator action (at high doses) tend to lower BP • Blocks vasodepressor action of cholinergic agonists 95 3. Eye • Mydriasis (pupil dilation) • Cycloplegia (paralysis of accommodation) • Abolition of light reflex • Effects last 7-10 days with topical application • May increase intraocular tension, especially in narrow angle glaucoma • Has mild local anesthetic action on cornea 4. Smooth Muscles • Relaxes all visceral smooth muscles with parasympathetic innervation (M₃ blockade) • Reduces tone and amplitude of GI contractions • Slows passage of chyme; may cause constipation • Causes bronchodilation, reduces airway resistance (Option D Ruled Out) • Relaxes ureter and urinary bladder • Relaxation of biliary tract (less marked) • Minimal effect on uterus 5. Glandular Secretions • Markedly decreases sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lacrimal secretions (M₃ blockade) (Option C Ruled Out) 6. Body Temperature • Higher doses can cause rise in body temperature • Due to inhibition of sweating and stimulation of temperature regulating center • Children are highly susceptible to atropine fever Relative Sensitivity of Organs Decreasing order of sensitivity: Saliva, sweat, bronchial secretion > eye, bronchial muscle, heart > smooth muscle of intestine, bladder > gastric glands and smooth muscle
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A patient presents with the palsy of the face as shown. Which of the following is most likely involved?
questions.explanation: The image presents a clinical case of facial palsy. The child's facial asymmetry, particularly the drooping of one side of the face, suggests a lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, commonly known as Bell’s palsy. Bell’s palsy: Description • Most common cause of facial palsy • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve is involved. • Males and females are equally affected. Aetiology • Idiopathic: Most common cause • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster • Vascular Ischemia • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8% • Autoimmune Risk Factors • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention). Clinical Features • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva. • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement). 98 Diagnosis • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis. Treatment • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir (Adult doses) • Surgical: Nerve decompression Prognosis • 85%-90% of patients fully recover • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases 3rd N. Palsy (Option B): Affects the oculomotor nerve (CN III), causing ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and pupil involvement, not facial asymmetry. Erb’s Palsy (Option C): A brachial plexus injury affecting arm movement, not facial muscles. Orbicularis Oculi Palsy (Option D): Would only affect eyelid closure, not the entire face.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A young man with a psychiatric disorder has become very aggressive. He speaks very rapidly and sleeps very little. He exhibits hyperactive behavior after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis? 99?
questions.subject: Psychiatry

questions.question_text: A patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A history of chronic smoking and decreased FEV₁% (forced expiratory volume in 1 second as a percentage of forced vital capacity) are hallmarks of obstructive lung disease, with COPD being the most probable diagnosis. • Key Features of COPD: • Chronic smoking history is the most significant risk factor. • Obstructive pattern on spirometry: • ↓ FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 sec) • ↓ FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%) → hallmark of airflow obstruction • Progressive dyspnoea, chronic cough, sputum production • Irreversible airflow limitation Features of Obstructive Diseases: 1. Total Lung Capacity is normal or increased 2. Residual Volume is elevated due to trapping of air during expiration 3. The ratio of RV/TLC is increased 4. Vital Capacity frequently decreases (not due to decreased lung volumes but increased RV). 5. FEV is less than 80% of TLC 6. FEV/FVC decreases 7. MMFR (Maximum Mid-Expiratory Flow Rate) decreases Emphysema: Chronic infection ↓ Impaired mucus clearance + Excess mucus secretion + Inflammatory edema 103 ↓ Bronchiolar obstruction ↓ Air trapping and Alveolar damage ↓ Elevated RV and TLC Examples of obstructive lung disease: • Asthma • COPD (Chronic bronchitis and emphysema) • Bronchiectasis • Bronchiolitis • Cystic fibrosis Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option B) is
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic. What is the gene associated with hand-feet syndrome?
questions.explanation: Hand-Foot-Genital Syndrome (HFGS): • Rare, dominantly inherited condition affecting distal limbs and genitourinary tract. • Genetic cause: • Identified mutation in the HOXA13 homeobox gene. • HFGS is the second human syndrome linked to a HOX gene mutation. • Clinical Characteristics: • Limb Malformations: • Bilateral shortening of thumbs and great toes, typically involving distal phalanx or first metacarpal/metatarsal. • Impaired dexterity or thumb apposition due to the malformations. 105 • Urogenital Defects: • In females: Abnormalities in the ureters and urethra, incomplete müllerian fusion. • In males: Hypospadias with or without chordee. • Associated conditions: Vesicoureteral reflux, recurrent urinary tract infections, and chronic pyelonephritis. • Normal fertility. • Diagnosis and Testing: • Clinical Diagnosis: • Physical examination, radiographs of hands/feet, and imaging of kidneys, bladder, and female reproductive tract. • Genetic Diagnosis: • Identification of a heterozygous HOXA13 pathogenic variant confirms diagnosis if clinical/radiographic features are unclear. • Management: • Treatment of Manifestations: • Surgery for hand/foot malformations is usually unnecessary. • Ureteric reimplantation and bladder outlet abnormality correction often needed. • Rare surgical correction for vaginal septum or uterine abnormalities, unless recurrent pregnancy loss occurs. • Prevention of Secondary Complications: • Prophylactic antibiotics or surgery for urinary tract issues. • Gynecological exams before menstruation for hymenal constriction. • Pre-pregnancy evaluation for uterine and vaginal anatomy due to risks in pregnancy. BCL6 gene (Option B)mutations are associated with B cell lymphomas and other cancers. FGFR gene (Option C)mutation causes skeletal disorders, mainly dwarfism and craniofacial malformations. COI 11 (Option D)mutation is associated with hearing loss.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A patient’s laboratory results were positive for malarial antigen, and the Widal test findings were as follows: O ag >1:300, H ag >1:20, A >1:20, B >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A significantly elevated O antigen titer (>1:300) only in the Widal test suggests a recent Salmonella infection. Widal Test: • It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi. • It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi. • The test is based on the agglutination reaction where patient serum is mixed with antigens of Salmonella typhi. 107 • If the antibodies are present, they will cause the antigens to clump together (agglutinate), indicating a positive result. • The test primarily measures: • O-antibodies: These are antibodies against the somatic (O) antigens of Salmonella typhi. • H-antibodies: These are antibodies against the flagellar (H) antigens of Salmonella typhi. • Antigens Used: • O antigen of S. Typhi (TO) • H antigen of S. Typhi (TH) • H antigen of S. Paratyphi A (AH) • H antigen of S. Paratyphi B (BH) • Interpretation: • Cut-off values in most parts of India: • H agglutinin titer >200. • O agglutinin titer >100. • Low titers: Considered baseline in endemic areas and should be ignored. Widal Test Result Suggestive of Rise of TO and TH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Typhi Rise of TO and AH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi A Rise of TO and BH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi B Rise of only TO antibody Recent infection due to S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi A or B Rise of only TH antibody Convalescent stage / Anamnestic response Rise of all TH, AH, BH Post-TAB vaccination antibodies (Option B) Past infection (Option C): A past infection usually results in elevated H antigen titers, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer is significantly high, indicating a recent infection. Reconvalescence (Option D): In the recovery phase, both O and H antigen titers decline, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer remains markedly high, supporting a recent infection instead. 108
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A young female has episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. Which of the following acid- base disturbace is she likely to have?
A 4-year-old child with mid-arm circumference of 105mm, upon providing therapeutic food, eagerly completed all of it. This patient is considered under?
questions.explanation: • In this case, the 4-year-old child has a MUAC of 105 mm (10.5 cm), which falls below the Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) threshold of 115 mm (11.5 cm), indicating severe malnutrition. • The child eagerly consumed the therapeutic food, successfully passing the appetite test. • There is no severe edema or medical complications requiring inpatient care, and no immediate life-threatening conditions. Based on these findings, the child is classified as having Uncomplicated SAM and can be managed with supervised home-based therapeutic feeding. Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in Children (6 to 59 months of age): Criteria Details Diagnostic Criteria for SAM Assessment for Complications Check for the following complications: • Severe edema (+++) • Low appetite (fails appetite test) • Medical complications • Presence of one or more danger signs (as per IMNCI guidelines) Management Approach Based on the presence or absence of complications: • If NO complications → Uncomplicated SAM → Supervised home management • If YES (complications present) → Complicated SAM → Inpatient management in a healthcare facility 112
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient sample positive for Infectious Hepatitis B. Choose the correct marker for thiscondition.
questions.explanation: The correct marker for Infectious Hepatitis B isHBsAg + HBe, as HBsAg indicates active infection, and HBeAg signifies high infectivity. Stages and Associated Markers of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBsAg HBeAg Anti- HBc Anti- HBs Anti- HBe Interpretation + + IgM - - Acute HBV infection Highly infectious + + IgG - - Chronic HBV infection, highly infectious 114 + - IgG - -/+ Chronic HBV infection, low infectivity - - IgG -/+ -/+ Recovery - - IgM - - Window period - - - + - Post-vaccination
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A renal biopsy image is shown. Identify the cells marked in the histological section. 115?
questions.explanation: Lacis cells, also called extraglomerular mesangial cells or Goormaghtigh cells, are found within the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) of the kidney. • These cells are located between the afferent and efferent arterioles and the macula densa. • They play a role in signal transmission between the macula densa and juxtaglomerular cells, influencing renin secretion. • They are part of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and contribute to blood pressure regulation. Juxtaglomerular Apparatus (JGA) and its Components Component Location Function Macula densa Distal tubule near afferent arteriole Senses sodium concentration & regulates renin secretion Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells Afferent arteriole Secrete renin in response to low BP 116 Lacis cells (Extraglomerular mesangial cells) Between the afferent & efferent arterioles Facilitate communication between macula densa and JG cells Podocytes Visceral layer of Bowman's capsule Filtration barrier in glomerulus Macula densa (Option A):
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Identify the lymphatic structure from the histology section given below?
questions.explanation: The image shows a distinct lobulated structure with a darker outer cortex and a lighter inner medulla. This is characteristic of the thymus. 119 Parts of the Thymus: 1. Cortex: • The outer, more densely packed region of the thymus. • Filled with immature T cells (thymocytes), undergoing differentiation and maturation as they move towards the medulla. • The cortex contains thymic nurse cells that support the maturing thymocytes. • T cells express surface markers (like TCR, CD3, CD4, and CD8) during maturation. • Macrophages are present to phagocytose apoptotic T cells, which fail to mature properly. 2. Medulla: • The inner, less densely populated region. • Dominated by epithelial cells with pale-staining nuclei and large cytoplasm. • Contains Hassall's corpuscles, concentric structures made of keratinized epithelial cells, involved in T cell regulation. • Dendritic cells and macrophages in the medulla present self-antigens to maturing T cells, ensuring the elimination of self-reactive cells to prevent autoimmunity. Histology of the Thymus: • Epithelial Framework: Throughout the thymus, epithelial cells provide a structural scaffold for lymphocyte development and produce hormones like thymopoietin, which regulate T cell maturation and proliferation. • It is divided into lobules by connective tissue septa. • A protective blood-thymus barrier prevents antigens from entering, safeguarding T cell maturation. With age, the thymus undergoes involution, where lymphoid tissue is replaced by fat, but it continues to produce mature T cells. 120 Tonsil (Option A): Tonsils contain lymphoid follicles with germinal centers. The histology of tonsils features these follicles, unlike the thymus. Lymph node (Option B): Lymph nodes also have lymphoid follicles but have a more defined capsule, cortex, paracortex, and medulla. 121 Spleen (Option C): The spleen has a characteristic red pulp (containing blood) and white pulp (containing lymphocytes)
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of a person with a history of a long-term sexual relationship presenting with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender lymphadenopathy points towards a diagnosis of Chancroid, typically caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Haemophilus ducreyi: • Gram-negative coccobacillus • Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor • Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains • Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining. 123 • Clinical features of chancroid: • Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base • Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) • Incubation period of 3-10 days • Diagnosis: • Clinical presentation • Gram stain of ulcer exudate • Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity) • PCR (most sensitive method) • Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum • Treatment: • Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR • Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days • Treatment of sexual partners is crucial Gonorrhea (Option A) typically causes urethritis and discharge, not painful ulcers or lymphadenopathy. Chlamydia (Option B) can cause urethritis or cervicitis, but ulcers are rare. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) (Option C) presents with painless ulcers and later, painful lymphadenopathy, unlike the painful ulcers seen in chancroid. 124

questions.question_text: Dehydration is more severe in infants compared to adults. Which of the following is a true statement about infants?
questions.option_a: Extracellular fluid (ECF) is more than intracellular fluid (ICF)
questions.option_b: Intracellular fluid (ICF) is more than extracellular fluid (ECF)
questions.option_c: Total body water in infants is more than in adults
questions.explanation: Infants have a higher total body water (TBW) percentage compared to adults, making them more susceptible to dehydration. 125 • Total body water (TBW) composition: • Infants: ~75-80% of body weight • Adults: ~55-60% of body weight • Higher water turnover: Infants lose water more rapidly due to higher metabolic rates, increased insensible losses, and immature renal function. Total Body Water (TBW) Composition: • 90% of body weight in early fetal life. • 75% of body weight at birth. • 60% of body weight by the end of the first year, remaining consistent until puberty. • After puberty, males have slightly more TBW compared to females. Preterm vs. Term Neonates: • Preterm neonates have a higher TBW compared to term neonates. TBW Distribution: • TBW is divided into: • Extracellular Fluid (ECF) • Intracellular Fluid (ICF) • The equation is: TBW = ECF + ICF • ECF = plasma + interstitial fluid ECF and ICF Changes: • In fetuses and newborns, ECF > ICF volume. • After birth, ECF volume decreases and ICF volume increases. Extracellular fluid (ECF) is more than intracellular fluid (ICF) (Option A) is
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: Which drug is preferred for management of diabetes in a patient with cardiac and renal failure?
questions.explanation: Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors (e.g., empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are preferred for diabetes management in patients with cardiac and renal failure due to their cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits. 127 • Cardiovascular Benefits: • Reduce heart failure hospitalisation (especially in HF with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)). • Lower major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in high-risk patients. • Renal Benefits: • Slow progression of diabetic nephropathy. • Reduce albuminuria and preserve glomerular function. Diabetic patients with heart failure best benefit from adding a group of drugs called SGLT-2 (sodium-glucose cotransporter-2) inhibitors, and empagliflozin falls in this group. By inhibiting the SGLT-2 receptors in the proximal tubule of the kidneys, glucose (and sodium) reabsorption can be prevented. Since both sodium and glucose are osmotic molecules, increasing their excretion draws out more water, making these drugs effective in patients with heart failure. Drugs: • Dapagliflozin. • Empagliflozin. • Canagliflozin. • Ertugliflozin. Side effects: • Infections (vaginal thrush, balanoposthitis, Fournier’s gangrene): Favour the growth of microbes in the lower urinary tract by providing an environment of excessive glucose. • Euglycemic ketoacidosis is due to inhibiting glucose reabsorption and the body’s p
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: Which adverse effect of Bleomycin is exacerbated by radiation exposure?
questions.explanation: 129 Bleomycin-induced pulmonary toxicity is the most significant adverse effect, and it is exacerbated by radiation exposure (a phenomenon known as radiation recall pneumonitis). • Mechanism: • Bleomycin generates free radicals, leading to oxidative damage and fibrosis in the lungs. • The lungs have low bleomycin hydrolase activity, making them more susceptible to damage. • Radiation exposure further increases oxidative stress and inflammatory responses, worsening lung injury. • Risk Factors: • Cumulative bleomycin dose >400 units • Concurrent oxygen therapy (risk of oxygen toxicity) • Prior or concurrent radiation therapy • Older age and renal impairment • Clinical Features: • Progressive dyspnoea, non-productive cough • Interstitial pneumonitis → pulmonary fibrosis • Restrictive lung disease with ↓ DLCO (diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide) Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that is well-known for its association with pulmonary toxicity, including pulmonary fibrosis which occurs as follows: 130 Gastric toxicity (Option B) is
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: • Gum bleeding & petechiae: Classic signs of scurvy, caused by vitamin C deficiency, due to impaired collagen synthesis leading to fragile capillaries. • Poor wound healing: Vitamin C is crucial for collagen formation and connective tissue repair, and its deficiency results in defective wound healing. • Other symptoms of scurvy: Fatigue, corkscrew hairs, anemia, and subperiosteal hemorrhages. Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy) Feature Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy) Cause Poor dietary intake (malnutrition, alcoholism, elderly, infants on cow's milk) Key Symptoms Bleeding gums, petechiae, bruising, corkscrew hairs, poor wound healing Other Signs Subperiosteal hemorrhage, joint pain, anemia, weakness Diagnosis Clinical features, low plasma vitamin C levels Treatment Vitamin C supplementation Vitamin A Deficiency (Option A):
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: A patient presents with arthritis, and arthroscopy reveals blackening of the joints. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: • Arthritis with joint blackening suggests alkaptonuria, a disorder caused by homogentisate oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which deposits in joints and cartilage. • Ochronosis (dark pigmentation): Homogentisic acid polymerizes and stains connective tissues, cartilage, and joints black, seen during arthroscopy. 133 • Other features: Black urine (on standing due to oxidation), ochronotic pigmentation in the sclera and ear cartilage. Alkaptonuria Feature Alkaptonuria (Homogentisate Oxidase Deficiency) Deficient Enzyme Homogentisate oxidase Accumulated Metabolite Homogentisic acid Key Features Black urine (on standing), ochronosis (dark connective tissue pigmentation), early-onset arthritis Affected Areas Joints, cartilage (ear, sclera, intervertebral discs) Diagnosis Urine darkening with alkalization, elevated homogentisic acid in urine Treatment Low-protein diet (restricting phenylalanine & tyrosine), vitamin C, symptomatic management • Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (Option B):
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: What is the key difference between Cisplatin and Carboplatin?
questions.option_a: Cisplatin is less neurotoxic than Carboplatin
questions.option_b: Cisplatin causes fewer gastric issues compared to Carboplatin
questions.option_c: Carboplatin is more neurotoxic than Cisplatin
questions.option_d: Cisplatin has more nephrotoxic side effects compared to Carboplatin
questions.explanation: Cisplatin and Carboplatin are platinum-based chemotherapy agents, but Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic due to its accumulation in renal tubular cells. • Key Differences: • Cisplatin: • More nephrotoxic → Causes acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and requires aggressive hydration with mannitol or amifostine to reduce damage. 135 • More neurotoxic and ototoxic → Causes peripheral neuropathy and sensorineural hearing loss (ototoxicity). • More severe nausea and vomiting. • Carboplatin: • Less nephrotoxic and does not require aggressive hydration. • Less neurotoxic compared to cisplatin. • More myelosuppressive (causes thrombocytopenia). Cisplatin is known for its nephrotoxic effects, which can lead to acute kidney injury. The management of cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity includes • Adequate i.v. fluids - Chloride diuresis (Cl inactivates cisplatin) • Mannitol - diuresis of inactivated cisplatin • Use of nephroprotective agents like amifostine (only i.v.) • Cisplatin is less neurotoxic than Carboplatin (Option A):
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation: • Alcohol metabolism increases NADH/NAD+ ratio: • Ethanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to excessive NADH production. • Inhibition of Gluconeogenesis: • High NADH shifts metabolic balance, preventing conversion of lactate to pyruvate and malate to oxaloacetate, both of which are essential for gluconeogenesis. • Hypoglycemia Risk: • After exercise and fasting, glycogen stores are depleted. • The body relies on gluconeogenesis for glucose, but alcohol blocks this pathway, leading to hypoglycemia after drinking. 137 Alcohol-Induced Hypoglycemia Feature Effect of Alcohol Key Mechanism ↑ NADH inhibits gluconeogenesis Primary Effect ↓ Glucose production → Hypoglycemia Clinical Features Weakness, dizziness, confusion, seizures Risk Factors Fasting, exercise, malnutrition, chronic alcoholism Treatment IV dextrose, thiamine in alcoholics • Glycogenolysis (Option B):

questions.question_text: Scientists administered norepinephrine to guinea pigs, resulting in an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and a decrease in heart rate. What mechanism explains this response? 138?
questions.explanation: The administration of norepinephrine (NE) causes: • ↑ Systolic and diastolic blood pressure (due to α₁-mediated vasoconstriction). • ↓ Heart rate (bradycardia) despite norepinephrine’s β₁-stimulatory effects. This paradoxical bradycardia occurs due to the activation of the baroreceptor reflex in response to increased blood pressure. Baroreceptor Reflex: Aspect Details Mechanism • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center 139 Actions • Vasodilation of blood vessels • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output Importance • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing • Fastest acting • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation • Beta-1 receptor blockade (Option A) is
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting a large quantity of paracetamol tablets. What is the most likely progression of paracetamol poisoning in this case? 140?
questions.option_a: Increase in liver enzymes within 24 hours
questions.option_c: Paracetamol achieves peak concentration within 4 hours
questions.explanation: Paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning follows a predictable progression based on the time since ingestion. The first 24 hours are usually asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms, but a rise in liver enzymes (AST, ALT) occurs as hepatotoxicity begins. Metabolism of Acetaminophen 141 • Acetaminophen is mainly metabolized via phase II reactions into harmless sulfate and glucuronide metabolites. • A small portion undergoes phase I metabolism by CYP2E1, forming the hepatotoxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI). Detoxification of NAPQI • NAPQI is neutralized by binding to glutathione, forming water-soluble mercapturic acid, which is excreted via the kidneys. Glutathione Depletion • When excessive NAPQI is produced, or glutathione is depleted, NAPQI binds to hepatocyte macromolecules, forming acetaminophen-protein adducts, causing hepatocyte necrosis. Risk Factors • Chronic alcohol use (induces CYP2E1, depletes glutathione). • Starvation. • Prior use of mixed-function oxidase-inducing drugs (e.g., phenobarbital, INH). • Hepatitis C infection increases the risk of liver injury in overdose. Clinical features Early Symptoms (4-12 hrs): • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, shock. Delayed Symptoms (24-48 hrs): • Hepatic injury becomes apparent. • Coagulopathy and encephalopathy. • Maximal damage seen 3–5 days post-ingestion with aminotransferase levels >10,000 IU/L. • Renal failure and myocardial injury may occur. Stages of acute acetaminophen poisoning Stage Time Post- Ingestion Description I 0–24 hours Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. 142 II 24–72 hours Right upper quadrant abdominal pain; elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), and sometimes increased bilirubin and INR if poisoning is severe. III 72–96 hours Vomiting, signs of liver failure; peak levels of AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR. Possible renal failure and pancreatitis. IV > 5 days Recovery of liver function or progression to multiple organ failure. • Liver failure within 24 hours (Option B) is

questions.question_text: Which of the following is deficient in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease? 143?
questions.explanation: • Natowicz Disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type IX - MPS IX) • Definition: A rare autosomal recessive mucopolysaccharidosis caused by hyaluronidase deficiency. • Biochemical Defect: • Hyaluronidase is responsible for degrading hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan). • Deficiency leads to accumulation of hyaluronic acid. • Glycosaminoglycan Involved: • Hyaluronic acid (a non-sulfated GAG). • Clinical Features: • Mild phenotype compared to other MPS types. • Soft tissue masses (especially periarticular), joint stiffness. 144 • Normal intelligence and no significant skeletal or neurological abnormalities. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) & Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) Accumulation MPS Type Enzyme Deficiency Accumulated GAG MPS I (Hurler/Scheie) (Option A ruled out) (Option B ruled out) α-L-iduronidase Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate MPS II (Hunter) (Option A ruled out) (Option B ruled out) Iduronate-2- sulfatase Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate MPS III (Sanfilippo) (Option B ruled out) Heparan N- sulfatase, etc. Heparan sulfate MPS IV (Morquio) (Option C ruled out) Galactosamine-6- sulfatase Keratan sulfate MPS VI (Maroteaux-Lamy) (Option A ruled out) Arylsulfatase B Dermatan sulfate MPS VII (Sly) (Option A ruled out) (Option B ruled out) β-Glucuronidase Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate MPS IX (Natowicz) Hyaluronidase Hyaluronan

questions.question_text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is taking indomethacin and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What potential side effect is likely to be seen?
questions.explanation: The combination of indomethacin (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, NSAID) and an ACE inhibitor increases the risk of hyperkalemia due to their combined effects on renal function and potassium homeostasis. • Mechanism: • ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril, lisinopril) block angiotensin-converting enzymes, reducing aldosterone secretion. • Aldosterone promotes potassium excretion, so reduced aldosterone leads to potassium retention. • Indomethacin (NSAID) further reduces renal perfusion by inhibiting prostaglandins, worsening potassium retention. • This can lead to hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), dehydration, or concurrent diuretic use. 146 Drug Interaction Mechanism Clinical Implication ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K- sparing diuretics Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents. Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias. ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs NSAIDs can reduce the anti- hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria. Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high- risk patients. ACE Inhibitors + Lithium ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity. Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed. ACE Inhibitors + Antacids Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids. Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy. ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels. In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially. • Hypercalcemia (Option B) is

questions.question_text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity?
questions.explanation: • Role of Prolyl Hydroxylase and Vitamin C: • Prolyl hydroxylase catalyzes the hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen. 148 • This process is essential for collagen stability via hydrogen bonding. • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, aiding in the regeneration of the enzyme’s Fe²⁺ active site. • Vitamin C Deficiency and Scurvy: • Deficiency leads to impaired collagen synthesis, causing fragile blood vessels, poor wound healing, and gingival bleeding (Scurvy). Vitamin C-Dependent Enzymes in Collagen Synthesis Enzyme Function Vitamin C Dependency Prolyl hydroxylase Hydroxylates proline residues in collagen for stability. Yes Lysyl hydroxylase Hydroxylates lysine residues in collagen for cross-linking. Yes Lysyl oxidase Cross-links collagen via aldehyde formation. No (Requires copper) Hydroxyprolyl kinase Phosphorylates hydroxyproline. No • Lysyl dehydrogenase (Option A):

questions.question_text: A patient with penicillin allergy presents with fever, burning micturition, and hearing problems accompanied by dizziness. Which drug is the most appropriate for the management?
questions.explanation: The patient presents with fever, burning micturition (suggestive of a urinary tract infection, UTI), and hearing problems with dizziness (suggestive of ototoxicity). Given the penicillin allergy, the most appropriate alternative is Ciprofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone), which is: • Effective against common UTI pathogens (E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas). • Safe in penicillin-allergic patients. • Less likely to exacerbate hearing loss compared to aminoglycosides. Ciprofloxacin 150 Pharmacokinetics • Good oral absorption • Bioavailability ~70%,Moderate half-life (~4-5 hours) • Widely distributed in tissues and body fluids • Renal excretion Uses • Urinary tract infections • Prostatitis • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (DOC) • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) (DOC) • Gastrointestinal infections (e.g., traveller's diarrhoea) • Bone and joint infections Side Effects • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea). • CNS effects (headache, dizziness). • Tendonitis and tendon rupture. • Photosensitivity. Contraindications • Pregnancy • Children (due to potential for cartilage damage) • Myasthenia gravis (can exacerbate muscle weakness) • Azithromycin (Option A) is

questions.explanation: Acid phosphatase, specifically prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP), is an enzyme that is elevated in prostate cancer, particularly in advanced or metastatic cases. PAP was historically used as a 152 tumour marker for prostate cancer, though prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is now the preferred marker. • Significance: • Elevated in prostate cancer with bone metastases • Can be used to monitor disease progression • Less commonly used now due to the superior sensitivity of PSA • Alkaline Phosphatase (Option B) is

questions.question_text: A TB patient with HIV begins ART and experiences deterioration in health after 2 months. What is the likely cause?
questions.option_a: Development of drug resistance to TB drugs
questions.option_b: Drug-drug interactions between TB and ART medications 153
questions.option_d: Development of drug resistance to ART
questions.explanation: The deterioration of health after starting ART in an HIV-TB co-infected patient is most likely due to Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), which is caused by immunological changes in response to ART. • Mechanism: • ART restores CD4+ T-cell function and improves the immune response. • This leads to a stronger inflammatory response against pre-existing TB infection, worsening symptoms. • IRIS typically occurs 2–12 weeks after ART initiation. • Clinical Presentation: • Worsening TB symptoms (fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms). • New inflammatory lesions (e.g., enlarging TB lymph nodes, worsening pleural effusions). • No evidence of drug resistance. • Management: • Continue both TB treatment and ART. • NSAIDs or corticosteroids may be used for severe cases. • HIV-positive individuals face an 8-fold increased risk of developing TB and are prone to more severe and potentially fatal extrapulmonary TB. • To manage co-infection, ATT is initiated first, followed by ART after 2 weeks to mitigate the risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), an exaggerated inflammatory response. 154 • Rifampin, a potent CYP inducer in ATT, accelerates the metabolism of certain ART drugs like nevirapine (NNRTI), dolutegravir (integrase inhibitor), and protease inhibitors (e.g., Ritonavir, Indinavir, lopinavir), reducing their effectiveness. However, nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and efavirenz can be safely combined with Rifampin. • Rifabutin, a weaker enzyme inducer, is often used as an alternative to mitigate drug interactions in ART. • All HIV-positive TB patients should also receive cotrimoxazole preventive therapy to guard against Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. • Development of drug resistance to TB drugs (Option A) is
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old male experiences headache, nausea, and shortness of breath while trekking. The physician prescribes a drug to alleviate his symptoms. The drug administered primarily acts on which part of the nephron? 155?
questions.explanation: The patient is experiencing symptoms of acute mountain sickness (AMS) due to hypoxia at high altitude. The drug commonly prescribed for AMS is acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, which primarily acts on the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron. • Mechanism of Acetazolamide in AMS: • Inhibits carbonic anhydrase in the PCT, leading to: • Decreased bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) reabsorption → metabolic acidosis • Increased renal excretion of bicarbonate → compensatory hyperventilation • This enhances ventilation and improves oxygenation, helping alleviate AMS symptoms. 156 Acetazolamide in AMS Symptom Alleviation • Inhibits kidney carbonic anhydrase. • Increases urine bicarbonate ions excretion → Metabolic acidosis. • Counteracts respiratory alkalosis from high altitude hyperventilation. • Improves oxygenation and alleviates AMS symptoms. • Loop of Henle (Option B) is

Which findings are suggestive of tubal pregnancy?
questions.option_a: Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium
questions.option_d: Adnexal mass with empty uterus and fluid in pelvis
questions.explanation: Tubal (ectopic) pregnancy occurs when a fertilized ovum implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. The characteristic ultrasound findings suggestive of a tubal pregnancy include: 1. Adnexal mass – Represents the ectopic pregnancy, often seen as a tubal ring or a gestational sac outside the uterus. 2. Empty uterus – Absence of an intrauterine gestational sac despite a positive pregnancy test. 3. Fluid in the pelvis – Suggests hemoperitoneum due to rupture or bleeding from the ectopic site. Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium (Option A) suggests an ovarian pathology (e.g., corpus luteum cyst), not tubal pregnancy. Adnexal mass with empty uterus (Option B): While this is suggestive, the presence of fluid in the pelvis increases suspicion of rupture. Trilayer endometrium without adnexal mass (Option C): A trilaminar endometrium is seen in normal early pregnancy or luteal phase and does not indicate an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.explanation: • Von Willebrand factor (vWF) primarily binds to Glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) on platelets, facilitating platelet adhesion to damaged endothelium via exposed subendothelial collagen. • vWF also carries and stabilizes Factor VIII, preventing its degradation. • Von Willebrand disease (vWD) results in defective platelet adhesion and prolonged bleeding time. gp1b-IX is a membrane complex in platelets that facilitates binding to the von Willebrand Factor which is defective/deficient in von Willebrand disease. Platelet factor 3 (Option B): PF3 is a phospholipid aiding coagulation but does not directly bind vWF. 208 ADP (Option C): ADP is involved in platelet aggregation, not adhesion. Prothrombin (Option D): Prothrombin (Factor II) converts to thrombin but does not interact with vWF.

questions.question_text: A child presents with telecanthus, hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, and cardiac defects. What is the most likely chromosomal abnormality?
questions.explanation: • The clinical presentation of telecanthus, hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, and cardiac defects is most consistent with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge syndrome or velocardiofacial syndrome). • This condition is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 22, specifically at the 22q11.2 region. DiGeorge Syndrome: Aspect Details Cause Microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. Developmental Defect Abnormal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches during embryogenesis. Clinical Features: Feature Type Details 226 Facial Features • Hypertelorism (widely spaced eyes). • Antimongoloid slant of eyes. • Low-set ears. • Micrognathia (small jaw). • Short philtrum. • Bifid uvula. Other Features • Hypocalcaemic tetany (due to hypoparathyroidism). • Aortic arch anomalies. • Thymic hypoplasia or aplasia. 227 Immunodeficiency: T Cell Defect Details Prevalence Present in 20–30% of patients. Severity Ranges from mild susceptibility to severe immunodeficiency requiring thymus or HSCT. Diagnosis: 228 • Molecular Genetic Testing: Detects the 22q11.2 microdeletion.
