questions.question_text: Identify the treatment option with the image given below: 244?
questions.explanation: Type 3 Tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus and incus are absent, but the stapes footplate is intact and mobile. The tympanic membrane or graft is placed directly over the stapes head to allow sound conduction. This technique helps improve hearing in cases of ossicular erosion due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), cholesteatoma, or trauma. Types of Tympanoplasty (Wullstein's Classification): Type Description Type I Defect: perforated tympanic membrane. Repaired using a graft. (myringoplasty) (Option A ruled out) Type II Defect: Eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane. Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus. (Option B ruled out) Type III Defect: Absence of malleus and incus. Graft placed directly on stapes head (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty). Type IV Defect: Only the footplate of the stapes is present. It is exposed to the external ear. A graft is placed between oval and round windows, allowing sound to act directly on the footplate and the round window is shielded. (Option D ruled out) Type V Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional. 246

A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of melena that contains gastric mucosa and acute intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following structure was found, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of melena (dark tarry stools) suggests gastrointestinal bleeding. The gastric mucosa in the ectopic location is a hallmark of Meckel's diverticulum. Intermittent pain in the right iliac region can occur due to inflammation or obstruction. Surgical exploration revealing a diverticular structure is characteristic of Meckel’s diverticulum. Meckel's Diverticulum Feature Details Definition Congenital true diverticulum of the small intestine, resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. Rule of 2’s 2% population, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2 inches in length, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric, pancreatic), 2 years most common presentation, 2:1 male predominance. Clinical Features Painless bleeding (melena), intestinal obstruction, diverticulitis, volvulus, intussusception. Diagnosis Meckel’s scan (Tc-99m pertechnetate scan for ectopic gastric mucosa). Treatment Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic. 275 Appendicular lump (Option B):

questions.question_text: A 26 year old female was brought to ER post fire incidence. Her face and lower limbs were spared. Calculate the area of burn. 276?
questions.explanation: 277 Face & Lower Limbs are Spared → These are NOT included in the burn calculation. Burned Areas: • Anterior Torso: 18% • Posterior Torso: 18% • Both Arms: 9% (each arm is 9%, but if only the front or back is affected, it would be 4.5% per arm) • Perineum: 1% Total Burn Area Calculation: • Anterior Torso (18%) + Posterior Torso (18%) + Both Arms (9%) + Perineum (1%) = 46% TBSA According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated: Adults Children Infants Head & neck 9% 18% 20% Front of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Back of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Lower limb 18 x 2 = 36% 13.5 x 2 = 27% 10 x 2 = 20% Upper limb 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Perineum 1% 1% 278

questions.question_text: A patient with grade 4 hemorrhoids underwent surgery, identify the instrument.
questions.explanation: • Grade 4 hemorrhoids are permanently prolapsed and require surgical intervention. • Rubber band ligation (RBL) is commonly used for hemorrhoid treatment, especially for grade 2 and 3 hemorrhoids, but may be attempted for early grade 4 cases before surgery. • If the patient underwent surgery, the most likely instrument used would be a hemorrhoidectomy (stapler or excision-based) rather than a band kit. However, if ligation was performed prior to surgery, a haemorrhoid band kit could have been used. Hemorrhoid Treatment Options Grade of Hemorrhoids Treatment Options Grade 1 (No prolapse) Lifestyle modification, fiber, sitz bath, topical agents Grade 2 (Prolapse, spontaneous reduction) Rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared coagulation Grade 3 (Prolapse, manual reduction needed) Rubber band ligation, surgical excision if persistent symptoms Grade 4 (Irreducible prolapse) Surgical options: Hemorrhoidectomy (excision or stapler), laser hemorrhoidoplasty 281 Haemorrhoid resection kit (Option A):
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: Following a fight between 2 groups, a boy was brought with severe pain in the chest, distended neck veins, dyspnea, and a BP of 80/50 mmHg. X-ray shows the following findings: What is the diagnosis? 282?
questions.explanation: 1. Clinical Presentation: • Severe chest pain, dyspnea, distended neck veins (JVD), and hypotension (80/50 mmHg) suggest a life-threatening tension pneumothorax. • Trauma history (fight) further supports the diagnosis. 2. Increased Intrathoracic Pressure → Impaired Venous Return → Distended Neck Veins (JVD) • As intrathoracic pressure rises, it compresses the superior vena cava (SVC) and right atrium, obstructing venous return to the heart. • This results in jugular venous distension (JVD) due to backed-up blood in the venous system. 3. Decreased Preload & Cardiac Output → Hypotension (Low BP) • The compression of the right atrium and ventricle reduces blood filling (preload), decreasing stroke volume and cardiac output. • This leads to severe hypotension and, if untreated, cardiac arrest due to obstructive shock. 283 4. X-ray Findings: • Hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) on the right side due to air accumulation. • Mediastinal shift to the left due to increased intrathoracic pressure. • Depressed diaphragm on the affected side. • Absence of lung markings on the affected side. 5. Management: • Immediate needle decompression at the 2nd intercostal space (midclavicular line) followed by chest tube placement. Pneumothorax Types and Features Type Cause Clinical Features X-ray Findings Tension Pneumothorax Trauma, mechanical ventilation Severe dyspnea, hypotension, JVD, tracheal deviation Mediastinal shift away from affected side, hyperlucency Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax Ruptured subpleural blebs (tall, thin males) Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain Hyperlucency without mediastinal shift Traumatic Pneumothorax Blunt/penetrating trauma, rib fractures Dyspnea, pain, absent breath sounds Hyperlucency, no mediastinal shift unless tension develops Bilateral Pneumothorax Rare, seen in severe trauma, barotrauma Respiratory distress, hypoxia Bilateral hyperlucency Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (Option B):
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Identify the procedure?
questions.explanation: • VP is a radiographic study of the urinary tract using intravenous contrast. • The contrast is injected intravenously, filtered by the kidneys, and visualizes the renal calyces, pelvis, ureters, and bladder in sequential X-ray images. • The characteristic findings in IVP include contrast-filled renal collecting systems, ureters, and bladder, differentiating it from other contrast-based urinary tract studies. Urinary Tract Imaging Techniques Procedure Method Indications Key Features Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) IV contrast injection Suspected urinary obstruction, nephrolithiasis, tumors Contrast seen in kidneys, ureters, and bladder on sequential films Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP) (Option A ruled out) Contrast injected via cystoscopy into ureters Suspected ureteral obstruction, non- visualization on IVP Contrast opacifies the ureter and renal pelvis without nephrogram Antegrade Pyelography (Option D ruled out) Contrast injected percutaneously into the renal pelvis Upper urinary tract obstruction, post- surgical assessment Contrast fills renal pelvis and ureters from above 286 Combined RGP & Ureteroscopy (Option B ruled out) Ureteroscope inserted via cystoscopy + contrast study Ureteric stones, strictures, or tumors Direct visualization of ureter along with contrast study

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not related to disease progression? 287?
questions.explanation: • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing skin cancer that rarely metastasizes. • Disease progression in BCC depends on: • Depth of invasion (deeper tumors are more aggressive). • Site (high-risk areas like the nose, periorbital region, and ears have a higher recurrence risk). • Stage of cancer (advanced stages indicate deeper tissue involvement). • Duration alone does not determine progression, as BCC can remain localized for years without significant spread. Factors Affecting BCC Progression Factor Effect on Progression Explanation Depth Yes Deeper invasion into muscle, cartilage, or bone increases severity Site Yes High-risk sites (face, scalp, ears) have more aggressive behavior 288 Stage of Cancer Yes Later stages indicate increased tumor burden and invasion Duration No Slow growth means duration does not directly impact aggressiveness Depth (Option B):

questions.question_text: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with a punctured wound. Choose the correctmanagement:
questions.explanation: For a PLHIV withcategory III dog bites (multiple deep wounds), the correct management islocal treatment, Rabies Immune Globulin (RIG), and the rabies vaccine. Management of Dog Bite: Category Exposure Type Management Category I • Touching or feeding animals • Licking of intact skin • Ensure proper hygiene • No treatment required Category II • Nibbling on uncovered skin • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding • Immediate wound washing with soap and water Rabies vaccination: • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14 • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3 • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required 290 Category III • Bites or scratches with bleeding • Licks on broken skin • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose) • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes. • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours. • Rabies vaccination: • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14 • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3 • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG): • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses) • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days). • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound. Required for unvaccinated individuals Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.question_text: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of decreased glucose, increased protein, and neutrophilic pleocytosis points towards a diagnosis ofbacterial meningitis. Ceftriaxoneis the first-line antibiotic for treatment of bacterial meningitis. Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention 292 Causes Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems. Pathophysiological Process Classic Triad of Symptoms • Fever • Headache • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck) CSF Findings • Opening pressure: Elevated • Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs) • Protein: Elevated • Glucose: Decreased • Gross appearance: Turbid 293 Treatment • Immediate Management: • Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens. • First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone • Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility • Adjunctive Therapy:Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early. • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures. Prevention • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections. • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections. • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose Ampicillin (Option A)is primarily used in Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, which is more common in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised patients. It is not first-line for typical bacterial meningitis in healthy adults. Penicillin (Option C)was historically used for Neisseria meningitidis but is not sufficient as monotherapy due to increasing resistance. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage. Vancomycin (Option D)is used in combination with Ceftriaxone when penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae is suspected, but it is not sufficient alone.
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: A 2-week-old neonate was brought to the hospital with a complaint of non-bilious vomiting. While examining the baby, the physician noted a lump in the left epigastric region, which showed movement while feeding. What is the likely diagnosis of this child?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is most likely congenital/ idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 to 6 weeks of age. Risk Factors of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis 295 Genetic Factors • White race of northern European descent • Male sex • Familial History: Higher risk in offspring of mothers with CHPS (20% for sons, 10% for daughters) • Twin Studies: Higher concordance in monozygotic twins suggests a genetic component • Blood Groups: Infants with B and O blood groups. Environmental Factors • Erythromycin Use: Especially if administered within the first two weeks of life • Higher incidence in infants whose mothers used macrolides during pregnancy or breastfeeding, particularly in females. Other Associated Factors • Other Congenital Defects Syndromes: Occasionally associated with tracheoesophageal fistula and hypoplasia or agenesis of the inferior labial frenulum. • Associated with eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Apert syndrome, Zellweger syndrome, trisomy 18, Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome, and Cornelia de Lange syndrome. • Clinical Presentation: • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age. • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis and a palpable “olive- shaped” mass in the epigastric region. • Diagnosis: • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm • Pyloric length > 14 mm • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm) 296 • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation. Characteristic findings of Contrast studies in CHPS Findings Description String Sign A thin line of contrast material passes through the narrowed pyloric channel, indicating severe narrowing due to hypertrophied muscle. 297 Shoulder Sign A bulge of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle into the gastric antrum gives the appearance of a “shoulder.” Double Tract Sign Parallel streaks of contrast material within the narrowed pyloric channel suggest the presence of a narrow passage for contrast flow. 298 Mushroom sign Bulging of the hypertrophic muscle into the 1st part of the duodenum. Esophageal atresia (Option A) will have bilious vomiting and does not present with any mass in the epigastrium. Duodenal atresia (Option B)presents with bilious vomiting immediately after birth. This is not the given scenario. Intussusception (Option D)presents with a sausage-shaped abdominal mass but is not associated with vomiting. It is more characteristically associated with red currant jelly stools.
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy? 299?
questions.explanation: Treatment of DVT: Anticoagulation:For initial management of acute DVT without contraindications to anticoagulation, the current recommended approach is to start with LMWH and transition to an oral anticoagulant. This approach has several advantages: • LMWH provides rapid anticoagulation without the need for monitoring. • Oral anticoagulants have shown non-inferiority or superiority to warfarin in large clinical trials. They have a better safety profile and do not require regular INR monitoring. • This regimen allows for outpatient management in many cases, reducing hospitalization rates. Investigation of DVT: 300 Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins. • Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein • Absence of compressibility • Absence of blood flow Venogram Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness. Impedance Plethysmography Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis. Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer. D-dimer has a high negative predictive value. Radioactive Fibrinogen Study Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used. Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI) Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC. Management of DVT: Initial Anticoagulation • Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases. • Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment. • Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Transition to Oral Anticoagulation • Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence. • Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor). • Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs). 301 Monitoring Anticoagulation • Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT). • Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0. For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D) Endovascular Surgery • Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting. • Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post- thrombotic syndrome. Unfractionated heparin followed by warfarin (Option A) was the traditional approach. • But it has largely been superseded by LMWH and DOACs due to the need for hospitalization, frequent aPTT monitoring for unfractionated heparin, and long-term INR monitoring for warfarin. Catheter-directed thrombolysis(Option C) is generally reserved for massive iliofemoral DVT with severe symptoms or limb-threatening situations. • It carries a higher risk of bleeding and is not first-line therapy for most DVT cases.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 45-year-old man is found unconscious after a fall from a ladder. In the emergency department, his eyes do not open even in response to pain; he is making incomprehensible sounds, and he exhibits abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.explanation: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a tool used to assess a patient’s level of consciousness based on three parameters: eye-opening, verbal response, and motor response. • Each parameter is scored, and the total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake). • Eye response: The patient's eyes do not open, even in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 1. • Verbal response: The patient makes incomprehensible sounds, corresponding to a score of 2. • Motor response: The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing) in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 3. • Thus, the GCS score for this patient is: 1 (Eye) + 2 (Verbal) + 3 (Motor) = 6 Simplified Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) Table 303 Category Response Score Eye Opening (E) Spontaneous 4 To speech 3 To pain 2 None 1 Verbal Response (V) Oriented 5 Confused conversation 4 Inappropriate words 3 Incomprehensible sounds 2 None 1 Motor Response (M) Obeys commands 6 Localizes to pain 5 Withdraws from pain 4 Abnormal flexion (decorticate) 3 Abnormal extension (decerebrate) 2 No response 1 Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification Minor head injury GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness) Mild head injury GCS 14 or 15 with LOC Moderate head injury GCS 9 - 13 304 Severe head injury GCS 3 - 8 The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS. Pupils Unreactive to Light Pupil Reactivity Score Both Pupils 2 One Pupil 1 Neither Pupil 0 • GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15 • GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the classical triad of acute cholangitis? 305?
questions.explanation: Pain, jaundice, fever - this triad, known as Charcot's triad- indicates cholangitis. Cholangitis Aetiology Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species. Symptoms • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common. • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis. 306 Lab Findings • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels. • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy. Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides. Pain, jaundice, shock (Option B): This option is
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with fever, rash, and Bitot spots. What is the appropriate line of management? 307?
questions.explanation: • The child already has measles, so the priority is to address the vitamin A deficiency (as evidenced by Bitot spots) to reduce the risk of complications and support recovery. • The measles vaccine is not required at this stage because the child has already been infected and will develop lifelong immunity. Measles Causative agent • ssRNA paramyxovirus Incubation period • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash Source of infection • Person with measles • Infective material Period of communicability • 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash 308 Clinical features Prodromal stage: • Fever • Cough • Coryza with sneezing • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation • Koplik’s spots-grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) Eruptive stage: • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs. • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days. Post measles stage: • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea. Isolation period • 7 days from the onset of rash Difference between measles and rubella rash • Both rashes are maculopapular • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non- confluent. Diagnosis • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots • Gold standard: PCR Treatment • No specific treatment • Symptomatic management only 309 Measles Rash Measles Vaccine + Vitamin A Supplementation (Option A): The measles vaccine is not needed after measles infection, as the child will have lifelong immunity. The vaccine is for prevention, not for post-infection management. Only Measles Vaccine (Option B): The vaccine is unnecessary post-infection, and vitamin A supplementation is critical in this case. Supportive Care (Option D): While supportive care is part of the management, it does not address the important need for vitamin A supplementation in a measles case.
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: For the diagnosis of typhus, an antigen of Proteus is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.explanation: Proteus antigens are classified asheterophile antigens because they cross-react with antibodies produced against Rickettsia in the diagnosis of typhus. Weil-Felix Test: • Weil-Felix Test is a heterophile agglutination test that works on the principle of rickettsial antibodies showing antigenic cross-reactivity with Proteus antigens (OX 19, OX 2 and OX K strains). • It is a tube agglutination test where serial dilutions of a patient's serum are treated with non-motile strains of P. vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and P. mirabilis OX K. Disease Agglutination Test Result Epidemic and endemic typhus Mainly agglutinates with OX19; sometimes with OX2 Tick-borne Spotted Fever Antibodies to both OX19 and OX2 elevated. Scrub Typhus Raised antibodies to OXK 311 Rickettsial Pox, Q Fever, Ehrlichiosis, Bartonellosis Negative test • False-positive titer - Due to underlying Proteus infection. Hence, fourfold rise of antibody titer in paired sera is better than a single high titer. • False-negative titer - Due to excess antibodies in the patient's sera (prozone phenomenon). This can be obviated by testing with serial dilutions of the patient's serum. Sequestered antigens (Option A)are normally hidden from the immune system due to anatomical barriers (e.g., myelin basic protein, lens proteins of the eye, sperm-associated antigens). When exposed after trauma, infection, or inflammation, they may trigger autoimmune reactions (e.g., sympathetic ophthalmia, multiple sclerosis). Superantigens (Option B) are highly potent immune activators that bypass normal antigen presentation by directly binding to MHC class II molecules and T-cell receptors, leading to massive cytokine release and systemic immune activation. Examples include: • Staphylococcal enterotoxins (food poisoning) • Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1) • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (scarlet fever, toxic shock syndrome) Isoantigens (or alloantigens) (Option C) are antigens that vary among individuals of the same species, such as blood group antigens (ABO, Rh) and HLA antigens. These play a role in blood transfusion compatibility and organ transplantation but are not relevant in the diagnosis of typhus.

questions.question_text: Identify the level of lymph nodes indicated in the marked region of the neck in the given anatomical image.
questions.explanation: • The marked lymph nodes are located along the upper part of the internal jugular vein, extending from the skull base to the hyoid bone. • Level II lymph nodes include the jugulodigastric nodes, commonly involved in head and neck malignancies. • They are subdivided into: • Level IIa: Medial to the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. • Level IIb: Posterior to the SCM muscle. Cervical Lymph Node Levels Level Anatomical Location Key Features Level I Submental & submandibular Divided into Ia (midline) & Ib (lateral) Level II Upper internal jugular nodes Jugulodigastric region (common in nasopharyngeal CA) Level III Mid-jugular region Between the hyoid & cricoid Level IV Lower jugular nodes Between the cricoid & clavicle Level V Posterior triangle Spinal accessory nodes 317 Level Ia (Option B):

questions.question_text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. He has a history of perineal trauma. On examination, blood is noted at the external urethral meatus. Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: • Patient presentation: • Severe urinary urgency but inability to void → Suggests urethral obstruction. • History of perineal injury → Strongly suggests trauma to the anterior urethra. • Blood at the meatus → A classic sign of urethral injury. • Bulbar urethral injury is common in perineal trauma: • Common mechanism: Straddle injuries (e.g., fall on a hard surface). 319 • Bulbar urethra is vulnerable due to its location in the anterior urethra. • Extravasation of urine may be seen if severe. Urethral Injuries Urethral Segment Common Causes of Injury Clinical Features Bulbar urethra (Anterior) Straddle injuries, blunt perineal trauma Blood at meatus, urinary retention, perineal hematoma Membranous urethra (Posterior) Pelvic fractures High-riding prostate, inability to pass urine Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture Blunt abdominal trauma Peritonitis, urinary ascites Posterior Urethral Valve Congenital anomaly Recurrent UTIs, voiding difficulty Posterior urethral valve (Option B):
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A woman, a few weeks after delivery, complains of bloody discharge from nipple and fever. On examination, diffuse lump under areola. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Recent postpartum status → Lactating women are at high risk of mastitis due to milk stasis and bacterial infection. • Bloody nipple discharge and fever → Suggests infection and inflammation, which are characteristic of lactational mastitis. • Diffuse lump under the areola → Likely represents engorgement or inflammatory induration due to stasis or bacterial invasion (commonly Staphylococcus aureus). Lactational Mastitis Feature Lactational Mastitis Etiology Bacterial infection due to milk stasis (commonly Staphylococcus aureus) 321 Risk Factors Breastfeeding, nipple trauma (cracks), poor latch, prolonged engorgement Symptoms Fever, malaise, painful swollen breast, erythema, bloody or purulent discharge Examination Tender indurated mass, warmth, erythema over the affected breast Complications Breast abscess (if untreated) Management Frequent breastfeeding, warm compress, analgesics, antibiotics (dicloxacillin, cephalexin) Galactocele (Option A):
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra is via?
questions.explanation: • Prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to bones, especially the lumbar vertebrae. • Batson’s venous plexus (valveless vertebral venous system) connects the prostatic venous plexus to the vertebral column, providing a direct route for metastasis. • This system allows retrograde venous flow, especially in conditions of increased intra- abdominal pressure, facilitating spread to the lumbar spine. Spread of Prostate Cancer Route Mechanism & Common Sites Local spread Direct extension into the seminal vesicles, bladder, or rectum Lymphatic spread Obturator, internal & external iliac nodes are commonly involved Hematogenous spread Via Batson’s venous plexus → lumbar vertebrae, pelvis, femur, ribs Arterial spread Rare, usually occurs late in disease progression Arterial spread (Option A):

questions.question_text: The ureter is safe in which type of hysterectomy?
questions.explanation: • In vaginal hysterectomy, the ureter is least at risk of injury because: • The procedure is performed entirely through the vaginal route without significant dissection near the ureter. 324 • There is less manipulation of pelvic structures compared to other approaches. • Other methods like open, laparoscopic, and robotic hysterectomy involve greater ureteric handling, increasing the risk of thermal injury, ligation, or transection. Ureteric Safety in Hysterectomy Types Hysterectomy Type Ureteric Injury Risk Reasons Open laparotomy Moderate Direct ureteric handling, risk during ligation Laparoscopic High Increased risk due to thermal and traction injuries Robotic Moderate to high Similar to laparoscopic but better visualization Vaginal Lowest Minimal ureteric dissection, lower risk of injury Open laparotomy (Option A):
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.explanation: • Course and Branching: • The Right Hepatic Artery (RHA) originates from the Proper Hepatic Artery and courses toward the right lobe of the liver. • It runs behind the common hepatic duct and gives rise to the Cystic Artery, which supplies the gallbladder. • Image-Based Identification: • The marked structure is seen branching toward the right lobe of the liver, which aligns with the usual anatomical location of the Right Hepatic Artery. • Its size and direction distinguish it from smaller branches such as the Cystic Artery. 327 Right Hepatic Artery Feature Description Origin Proper Hepatic Artery (branch of Common Hepatic Artery) Course Runs behind the common hepatic duct and ascends toward the right lobe of the liver Branches Cystic artery (to gallbladder), Segmental branches to liver Function Supplies the right lobe of the liver and gallbladder Clinical Importance Injury during cholecystectomy can lead to hemorrhage or hepatic ischemia 328 Cystic Artery (Option A):
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: What is the most likely cause of lower right abdominal pain and rebound tenderness in a patient with Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate acute appendicitis, despite the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Lower right abdominal pain with rebound tenderness is a classic sign of acute appendicitis, and the presence of a Meckel's diverticulum does not change this presentation. While Meckel's diverticulum can cause abdominal pain, the specific location and presence of rebound tenderness strongly suggest appendicitis as the primary pathology. Perforation (Option A): While perforation of Meckel's diverticulum can occur, it typically presents with more diffuse abdominal pain and peritonitis rather than localized right lower quadrant pain. The presentation described is more consistent with appendicitis (Option A ruled out). Perforation would likely cause more widespread symptoms and signs of peritoneal irritation. 330 Intestinal obstruction(Option B): Meckel's diverticulum can cause intestinal obstruction, but this typically presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention rather than localized rebound tenderness (Option B ruled out). The absence of these obstruction symptoms makes this diagnosis less likely. Cholecystitis(Option D): Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, not lower right abdominal pain. The location of pain and the presence of rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant is inconsistent with cholecystitis (Option D ruled out). Murphy's sign would be expected in cholecystitis, which is elicited in the right upper quadrant.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old female presents with a painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A painful red granular lesion on the vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy in a sexually active adult is highly suggestive of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Feature Chancroid Causative organism Haemophilus ducreyi Incubation period 3–10 days Ulcer Painful, non-indurated, soft ulcer with irregular borders and granular base Number of ulcers Often multiple Lymphadenopathy Painful, unilateral or bilateral, may form buboes (fluctuant lymph nodes) Base of ulcer Necrotic, purulent, bleeds on contact Tenderness Marked Neisseria Gonorrhoeae Infection (Option B): Causes urethritis, cervicitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), but not painful genital ulcers. 332 Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis) (Option C): Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that slowly enlarge and lack lymphadenopathy. Donovan bodies seen on microscopy. Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV) (Option D): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serotypes). Typically presents with small, painless ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), which can lead to groove sign (inguinal ligament indentation).
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A 29-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine gestational sac or features suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Her serum β-hCG is 1,200 IU/L, which is below the discriminatory zone. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: In a hemodynamically stable patient, when β-hCG levels are below the discriminatory zone (<1,500–2,000 IU/L) and ultrasound findings are inconclusive, the next step is to repeat β-hCG testing after 48 hours to assess the trend. • A doubling β-hCG level suggests a normal intrauterine pregnancy. • A plateauing or declining β-hCG raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy or early pregnancy loss. Investigations for ectopic pregnancy: • Blood examination should be done as a routine for: • Haemoglobin • ABO and Rh grouping • Total white cell count and differential count • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) • Estimation of β-hCG: The suspicious find-ings are: • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy • Sonography (TVS): The diagnostic features are: • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test. • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas. • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign). • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. • Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog-raphy: TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period. • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L. • So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected. • Laparoscopy offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions. • Dilatation and curettage: Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive. 334 • Serum progesterone: A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy. • Laparotomy offers benefits when in doubt. Laparoscopy (Option A) is reserved for cases with significant clinical suspicion of ectopic pregnancy or instability. Methotrexate therapy (Option B) is initiated only after a confirmed diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy. Dilatation and curettage (Option D) is used when miscarriage is suspected and histological confirmation is needed.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step? 335?
questions.option_a: Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation.
questions.option_b: Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.
questions.option_c: Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
questions.option_d: Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.
questions.explanation: Diagnosis Gestational Diabetes Pre-existing Diabetes Timing During pregnancy Present before conception Criteria Fasting Plasma glucose 92 mg/dL 126 mg/dL (on two occasions) 1-hour plasma glucose 180 mg/dL ≥200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms) 336 2-hour plasma glucose 153 mg/dL ≥200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals) HbA1c ≥5.7-6.4% ≥6.5% Management Resolves after delivery. Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy. • After experiencing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) during pregnancy, a mother may have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes in later life. • Lifestyle modifications are appropriate, but immediate diagnosis and management of GDM are necessary. • Monitoring without intervention is inappropriate because the patient meets the criteria for GDM diagnosis and requires management to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.question_text: During a routine pediatric check-up, a mother brings her 5 month old baby to the clinic. The pediatrician observes that the baby actively looks at his mother’s face and seems to respond with interest as she talks to him, showing recognition and engagement. When is this milestone normally achieved?
questions.explanation: Key Developmental Milestones 343 Age Gross Motor Milestones Fine Motor Milestones Social Milestones Language Milestones 1 month Alerts to sounds 2 months Social smile 3 months Neck holding Recognises mother, anticipates feed (Option B) Cooing 4 months Laugh Loud 5 months Rolls over Bidextrous reach 6 months Sits in tripod position Unidextrous reach Recognize strangers, stranger anxiety Monosyllables 8 months Sits without support 9 months Stands with support Immature pincer grasp Waves bye bye Bisyllables 12 months Creeps well, stands without support Mature pincer grasp Comes when called, plays simple ball game 1 to 2 words with meaning 15 months Walks alone, creeps upstairs Imitates scribbling, tower of 2 blocks Jargon speech 18 months Runs, explores drawers Scribbles, tower of 3 blocks Copies parents in task 8 to 10 words vocabulary 2 years Walks up and downstairs (2 feet per step), jumps Tower of 6 blocks, vertical and circular stroke Asks for food, drink, toilet, pulls people to show toys 2 to 3 word sentences 344 3 years Rides tricycle, alternate feet going upstairs Tower of 9 blocks, copies circle Shares toys, knows full name and gender Asks questions, tells name and gender 4 years Hops on one foot, alternate feet going downstairs Copies cross, bridge with blocks Plays cooperatively in a group, goes to toilet alone Says song or poem, tells stories 5 years Copies triangle, gate with blocks Helps in household tasks, dresses and undresses Asks meaning of words
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A 35 y/o asthmatic patient is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure. Which induction agent and muscle relaxant combination is safest for this patient?
questions.explanation: • Ketamine is beneficial in asthmatics as it provides analgesia and induces bronchodilation without significant hemodynamic instability. • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that does not release histamine, making it safe for use in asthmatic patients. Anaesthesia in Asthmatics • IV Induction Agent: • Propofol: Preferred for stable patients, promotes bronchodilation. • Ketamine: Ideal for hemodynamically unstable asthmatics, promotes bronchodilation. • Muscle Relaxant: • Vecuronium, Rocuronium, Cis-atracurium: Safe for use in asthmatics, no significant histamine release. • Pancuronium: Releases low levels of histamine. • Inhalational Agent: • Sevoflurane, Isoflurane, Halothane: Ideal choices as they depress airway reflexes and relax bronchial smooth muscle. • Desflurane: This should be avoided due to airway irritation and increased airway resistance. Propofol and Succinylcholine (Option A): Succinylcholine may provoke bronchospasm. Ketamine and d-tubocurarine (Option B): d-tubocurarine releases histamine, which can trigger bronchospasm. Thiopental and Rocuronium (Option D): Thiopental has slower recovery times and can cause respiratory depression. 346

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not caused by food adulteration?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings? 350?
questions.explanation: • The ECG shows a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) but consistently conducts P waves to QRS complexes, indicating first-degree AV block. 351 • There are no dropped beats, ruling out higher-degree blocks. First Degree AV Block Pathology • First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles. • The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers. Etiology • Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients. • In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system. • Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases. • Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma. Clinical Features • Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG. • In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain. ECG Features • Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG. • PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves. Treatment • Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient. • Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease. • No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening. Second-Degree AV Block (Option A): 352 • This block features progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex, which is absent in this ECG as there are no dropped beats. Third-Degree AV Block (Option C): • Here, there is complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. • This is absent in the ECG since P waves are consistently followed by QRS complexes. 353 Bundle Branch Block (Option D): • This condition shows a wide QRS complex with characteristic morphology. 354 • This feature is absent in the ECG, where the QRS complexes are normal in width and shape

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation: • MuSK is essential for clustering AChRs at the neuromuscular junction. • Anti-MuSK antibodies are found in AChR-negative patients, often presenting with bulbar muscle weakness (affecting speech and swallowing). Autoantibodies in Myasthenia Gravis • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness due to disrupted neuromuscular transmission. Types of Autoantibodies Autoantibody Target Effects Associated Features AChR antibodies Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness Most common MuSK antibodies Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues) • Diagnostic Tests • Repetitive Nerve Stimulation: Shows a decremental response (decline in muscle activity with repeated stimulation), indicating faulty neuromuscular transmission. • Blood Tests: Detect the presence of AChR and MuSK antibodies. Anti-dsDNA antibodies (Option A): Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not associated with neuromuscular transmission issues. Anti-TPO antibodies (Option C): Linked with autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto’s thyroiditis). 356 Anti-Ro antibodies (Option D): Found in Sjogren’s syndrome and neonatal lupus, not relevant to myasthenia gravis.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old female who delivered a healthy term baby one week ago is now presenting to the OBG clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling pale brownish vaginal discharge. What is the nature of this discharge?
questions.explanation: Lochia Serosa is usually seen from the 5th to the 9th day of puerperium, the color of discharge is yellowish, pink, or pale brownish (Option B) Lochia is the vaginal discharge seen in early puerperium due to the sloughing of decidual tissue. It has an offensive fishy smell and may last up to 35 days. Depending upon the variation of the colour, the types of Lochia are: Type of Lochia Timing Composition Lochia Rubra -red (Option A) Seen in 1-4 days • Blood • Shreds of fetal membranes and decidua • Vernix caseosa • Lanugo and meconium. Lochia Serosa- yellowish or pink or pale brownish (Option B) 5-9 days • Less RBC but more leukocytes • Wound exudate • Mucus from the cervix • Microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci) Lochia Alba-pale white (Option C) 10-15 days • Decidual cells • Leukocytes • Mucus • Cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells • Microorganisms. Leukorrhea: Profuse white discharge might be seen in vaginitis, cervicitis, or subinvolution (Option D)
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient undergoing surgery is administered succinylcholine for muscle relaxation. Shortly after administration, he develops hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, tremors, and tachycardia. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening genetic disorder triggered by certain anesthetic agents, particularly succinylcholine. It is characterized by the rapid onset of hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and metabolic acidosis following exposure to these triggering agents. The first-line treatment and specific antidote for malignant hyperthermia is Dantrolene sodium. It works by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, effectively reducing the hypermetabolic state and preventing further temperature elevation. Immediate administration of Dantrolene is crucial to prevent severe complications and mortality. Diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia • Best screening test: Creatine kinase test • Gold Standard Diagnostic test: Halothane-Caffeine Test Treatment for malignant hyperthermia 2 1. Discontinue volatile anaesthetics and succinylcholine immediately. Notify the surgeon and call for assistance. 2. Hyperventilate the patient with 100% oxygen at a fresh flow rate of at least 10 L/min. 3. Mix dantrolene sodium with sterile distilled water and administer 2.5 mg/kg intravenously as soon as possible. Repeat every 5 to 10 minutes until symptoms improve, with a maximum total dose of 10 mg/kg. 4. Administer bicarbonate to address metabolic acidosis. 5. Implement cooling measures, such as lavage, cooling blankets, and cold intravenous fluids. 6. For severe hyperkalemia, administer dextrose (25–50 g IV) along with regular insulin (10–20 units IV for adults). 7. Provide antiarrhythmic medications as necessary. 8. Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels, electrolytes, blood gases, creatine kinase, serum myoglobin, core temperature, urinary output and colour, and coagulation status. Neostigmine(Option A) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used primarily to reverse non- depolarizing neuromuscular blockade at the end of surgery. It would treat the underlying pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia and could potentially worsen symptoms by increasing acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions. Neostigmine is contraindicated in this scenario as it may exacerbate the hypermetabolic crisis. Atropine(Option C) is an anticholinergic medication that blocks muscarinic receptors. It would not treat malignant hyperthermia and might actually worsen the condition by inhibiting sweating and further elevating body temperature. Additionally, it could exacerbate the tachycardia already present in this patient. Midazolam (Option D) is a benzodiazepine with sedative, anxiolytic, and amnestic properties. While it might provide some symptomatic relief through sedation, it does not address the underlying pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A patient scheduled for elective hip surgery is currently taking aspirin, enalapril, a multivitamin, and metoprolol. The surgery is planned in 5 days. What is the appropriate perioperative management for this patient?
questions.option_b: Stop aspirin to minimize perioperative bleeding risk
questions.option_c: Stop metoprolol to increase cardiac output
questions.option_d: Increase aspirin dosage for additional analgesic benefit
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors such as enalapril should typically be stopped 24 hours before elective surgery. This recommendation is based on evidence that continuing ACE inhibitors perioperatively can lead to clinically significant hypotension during Anaesthesia, particularly when combined with the vasodilatory effects of anesthetic agents. Medication discontinuation before surgery Drug Continued or stopped preoperatively Antithyroid Continued Antiepileptic Continued Antidepressants Continued Aspirin Continued Beta Blockers Continued 4 Smoking Stop at least 6-8 weeks prior Steroid Continued Anticonvulsants Continued Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs) Discontinue 2-3 weeks before surgery Oral Contraceptive Pill Discontinue at least 6 weeks before Herbal Supplements Discontinue at least 2 weeks before surgery ACE Inhibitors (Enalapril) Stop 24 hours before surgery Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers (ARBs) (Telmisartan) Stop 24 hours before surgery Calcium Channel Blockers (Amlodipine) Continue Stop aspirin to minimize perioperative bleeding risk (Option B) may be considered for neurosurgery or ocular procedures, but current guidelines generally recommend continuing aspirin for most orthopedic procedures including hip surgery. The modest increase in surgical bleeding with aspirin continuation is typically manageable and outweighed by the potential cardiovascular risks of discontinuation. Stop metoprolol to increase cardiac output(Option C) would be inappropriate and potentially dangerous. Abrupt beta-blocker discontinuation perioperatively significantly increases the risk of sympathetic hyperactivity, tachycardia, hypertension, myocardial ischemia, and mortality. Increasing aspirin dosage for additional analgesic benefit (Option D) has no supporting evidence of additional benefit and would unnecessarily increase bleeding risk.

questions.option_c: Non-development of the perimembranous part of the septum

questions.question_text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? 7?
questions.explanation: • Characteristic rash: The image likely shows acrodermatitis enteropathica, which presents with perioral, perianal, and acral dermatitis—a hallmark of zinc deficiency. • History of diarrhea: Zinc plays a crucial role in intestinal function and immunity; its deficiency leads to chronic diarrhea. • Other symptoms of zinc deficiency: Growth retardation, poor wound healing, alopecia, and immune dysfunction. Zinc Deficiency & Acrodermatitis Enteropathica Feature Zinc Deficiency Cause Congenital (SLC39A4 mutation) or acquired (malnutrition, chronic diarrhea) 8 Key Skin Features Perioral, perianal, and acral dermatitis with erythematous, scaly plaques Other Symptoms Growth retardation, diarrhea, alopecia, immune dysfunction Diagnosis Low serum zinc levels Treatment Zinc supplementation Niacin Deficiency (Option B) is
questions.subject: Dermatology

questions.question_text: A newborn child is brought to the emergency department with respiratory difficulty. The doctor evaluated, and the child was found to have a posterolateral defect, as shown in the x-ray given. What is the diagnosis? 9?
questions.explanation: The clinical features and X-ray show a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and the most common type that appears in the posterolateral part on the left side is the Bochdalek hernia. Diaphragmatic Hernia: • It is a communication between the abdominal and thoracic cavities, which may or may not involve abdominal contents in the thorax. • Aetiology: Rarely traumatic, usually congenital. • Symptoms and Prognosis: Dependent on the location of the defect and associated anomalies. 10 Types of diaphragmatic hernia: • Hiatal hernia (Option C): Occurs at the esophageal hiatus. • Paraesophageal Hernia: Near the esophageal hiatus. • Morgagni Hernia (Option B): Retro-sternal, occurring in the foramen of Morgagni (2– 6% of CDH cases). • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs in the posterolateral portion of the diaphragm; most common, accounting for 90% of congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH). It occurs predominantly on the left side (80-90%). Pathology and etiology: • CDH involves a diaphragmatic defect and often leads to pulmonary hypoplasia. • Pulmonary hypoplasia is due to both compression of the lungs and, in some cases, may precede the diaphragmatic defect. • Pathological features include reduced pulmonary mass, abnormal alveolar septa, thickened alveoli, and biochemical imbalances such as surfactant deficiency. Clinical Features: • Symptoms include respiratory distress, tachypnea, cyanosis, and scaphoid abdomen. • Infants may show delayed symptoms and present with vomiting or mild respiratory distress. Diagnosis: • CDH is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound (16-24 weeks) and fetal MRI. • Key findings: polyhydramnios, chest mass, mediastinal shift, abdominal organs in the chest, and fetal hydrops. • After birth, a chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis. Treatment: • Initial Management: o Birth in a tertiary care centre with expertise in CDH management is essential. o Immediate stabilization includes intubation, gastric decompression, and central venous and arterial access. o Goal oxygenation: preductal SpO2 ≥85%. o Gentle ventilation and permissive hypercapnia are recommended. • Ventilation Strategies: o Conventional mechanical ventilation, HFOV, and ECMO are primary methods. 11 o Permissive hypercapnia and low-pressure ventilation reduce lung injury. o Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) may be used to manage pulmonary hypertension. • Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO): o ECMO is used when conventional ventilation fails. o The duration of ECMO may be longer in CDH infants than in other conditions. • Surgical Repair: o Repair is typically done after stabilization (48 hours post-birth). o A subcostal approach is preferred, with a focus on primary repair if possible. o If primary repair is not feasible, synthetic patches (e.g., Gore-Tex) may be used. o Postoperative monitoring for complications like pulmonary hypertension, bleeding, and bowel obstruction is crucial. Novel Strategies: • Fetal lung-to-head ratio (LHR) on ultrasound is a reliable predictor of outcomes. • Fetoscopic tracheal occlusion shows promise for severe cases, but more research is needed. Traumatic diaphragmatic hernia (Option D)is not the likely diagnosis in the given scenario since there is no significant history of trauma that may indicate this diagnosis.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which electrolyte abnormality will lead to cardiac arrhythmia in patients with severe vomiting?
questions.explanation: Severe vomiting leads to hypokalaemia, which is a major risk factor for cardiac arrhythmias due to its effect on cardiac membrane potential and conduction. • Mechanism: o Vomiting causes loss of gastric acid (HCl) → metabolic alkalosis o Alkalosis shifts potassium into cells → worsens hypokalaemia o Renal compensation increases potassium excretion (due to increased bicarbonate delivery to the distal tubule) o Low serum potassium disrupts cardiac repolarisation, leading to arrhythmias • ECG changes in hypokalaemia: o Flattened T waves o U waves o Prolonged QT interval → risk of ventricular arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes, ventricular tachycardia) Hyponatraemia (Option B) is
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A body brought for autopsy is cold and has developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at the back/fixed, but no signs of putrefaction. What will be the estimated time since death? 13?
questions.explanation: The postmortem interval (PMI) estimation is based on a combination of algor mortis, rigor mortis, livor mortis, and putrefaction findings: Findings in This Case: Observation Interpretation Body cold to touch Suggests death occurred more than 8–12 hours ago (body cools gradually) Rigor mortis in all four limbs Fully established rigor occurs around 12 hours post-death and lasts up to 24 hrs Livor mortis fixed at the back Lividity becomes fixed after 6–12 hours No signs of putrefaction Putrefaction usually begins after 24–36 hours, depending on environment 14 Given that: • Rigor mortis is fully developed (12 hours), • Livor mortis is fixed (~8–12 hours), • No putrefaction is seen (<24–36 hours), The most accurate estimate for time since death is 12–24 hours. Livor Mortis Feature Details Other names Cadaveric lividity, postmortem staining, suggillations, vibices, "darkening of death" Site Superficial dermis (capillaries and venules) Mechanism Gravitational settling of deoxygenated blood → purple-blue skin discolouration in dependent areas Onset Begins in 30 minutes – 1 hour after death Fully developed by ~ 4 hours Fixation time Becomes fixed in 6–12 hours Confirmation of fixation Apply pressure → if colour does not blanch, it is fixed Primary lividity Max intensity seen by 6–12 hours Secondary lividity Lividity may shift if the body is moved within a few hours of death Duration Persists until putrefaction begins 15 Image The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases. Phase Description Timeframe Primary Relaxation Muscles are flaccid; ATP levels are 100%. Sphincters relax, leading to the release of urine/feces. 0–1 hour after death Rigor Mortis Onset Begins as ATP falls to 85%; actin-myosin cross-linking causes stiffening. Appears in smaller muscles first (eyelids, jaw), progresses to limbs. Begins 1–2 hrs; full by 12 hrs Rigor Resolution Due to proteolysis, rigidity dissipates. Rigor fades by 24–36 hours depending on conditions. 12–36 hours after death Position Lividity Location Supine Back of head, neck, trunk, and limbs (excluding pressure areas) Prone Chest, face, front of limbs Side Dependent side Head-down Face and neck blackened Vertical suspension Legs, hands, external genitalia (glove and stocking pattern) Drowning Face, chest, hands, feet, calves Conditions Where Livor Mortis May Be Absent: • Severe anaemia 16 • Massive blood loss • Cachexia (wasting diseases) • Some infections like lobar pneumonia Medicolegal Significance of Livor Mortis: • Helps estimate time since death • Indicates body position at death • Suggests if the body was moved postmortem • May hint at cause of death (e.g., cherry-red lividity in CO poisoning)
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: A 39-year-old patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 139 cells/μL presents with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. CSF examination using an India ink preparation reveals a positive result. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation: A patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 139 cells/μL, altered sensorium, and a positive India ink preparation of CSF points towardCryptococcus neoformans, a common cause of opportunistic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals. Clinical Features of Cryptococcosis Respiratory System • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress. • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to the involvement of other organs Central Nervous System Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection Skin Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D) Other Organs Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis Microscopy • India ink:Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans 18 Culture • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream- coloured colonies. • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme. • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci. Antigen detection tests Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutinationtest Treatment • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine • Maintenance Therapywith Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status. • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes. • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient came to the hospital with muscle weakness, diarrhea, and bradycardia. He was diagnosed with organophosphate poisoning for which atropine was administered. After atropine administration, which of the following changes are not seen? 19?
questions.explanation: Organophosphate (OP) poisoning causes cholinergic overstimulation by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist, used to treat the muscarinic symptoms of OP poisoning. OPC poisoning: Symptoms Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS) Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion 20 Laboratory Diagnosis • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific) • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common) • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning • Inexpensive, sensitive) • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation. Management • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing- Circulation) • Decontamination • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4 • Activated charcoal • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization) • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms • removes phosphate group • reduces atropine requirement Cause of Death Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP) 21 Option Explanation Seen after atropine? Bradycardia Reversed by atropine (muscarinic blockade) Not seen Muscle weakness Nicotinic effect; not reversed by atropine Seen Diaphoresis Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves Nasal discharge Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves 22 Muscle weakness (option B): Remains because atropine does not affect nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Diaphoresis (option C): Caused by muscarinic stimulation → improves with atropine. Nasal discharge (option D): Muscarinic effect → improves with atropine.

questions.question_text: A patient is positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A patient positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM points toward Acute hepatitis B. Stages and Associated Markers of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBsAg HBeAg Anti- HBc Anti- HBs Anti- HBe Interpretation + + IgM - - Acute HBV infection Highly infectious + + IgG - - Chronic HBV infection, highly infectious (Option B) + - IgG - -/+ Chronic HBV infection, low infectivity - - IgG -/+ -/+ Recovery (Option C) - - IgM - - Window period - - - + - Post-vaccination (Option D)
