Supporting features: • Location: Commonly over the dorsal aspect of the wrist (as seen in image) • Fluctuation in size: Classic feature due to cyst fluid dynamics • Mild numbness: Can occur if the cyst compresses nearby nerves • Occasional pain: Especially with wrist movement or pressure Differentiating Wrist Masses: Condition Characteristics Pain Fluctuation in Size Numbness Lipoma Soft, mobile, subcutaneous fat mass No No No Ganglion cyst Fluid-filled, over joint or tendon sheath, translucent Occasional Yes Rare Dermoid cyst Congenital, contains ectodermal elements (hair/sebum) Rare Rare Yes Hematoma Post-trauma, discoloured, self-resolving Yes (initially) No No Lipoma (Option A): Typically soft, non-fluctuant, and slow-growing; not commonly associated with wrist joints or changes in size with activity. Dermoid cyst (Option C): Usually congenital, midline, and more common in children; contains ectodermal elements, and rarely found over the wrist joint. Hematoma (Option D): Usually follows trauma, appears bruised or discoloured, and resolves over time; not fluctuant or recurrent like this. 254
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 1.5-month-old male infant presents to the outpatient department with vomiting after feeding and failure to thrive. On examination, a firm, olive-shaped mass is palpated in the upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A newborn male presents with urinary retention, lethargy and a distended bladder. Antenatal ultrasound showed a "keyhole sign" with a thickened bladder wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with a 3 cm breast lump in the upper medial quadrant. The lump has an uneven, bosselated surface, and the overlying skin is mildly ulcerated. Microscopic examination reveals the given findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? 257?
questions.explanation: • Phyllodes tumors are fibroepithelial breast tumors that exhibit stromal overgrowth and a leaf-like architecture on histology. • They often present as large, bosselated (lobulated) masses with rapid growth. • Ulceration of overlying skin suggests an aggressive nature, which is common in borderline or malignant phyllodes tumors. • Histopathology confirms the diagnosis by showing stromal hypercellularity and cleft-like spaces resembling leaf-like structures. Phyllodes Tumor Feature Description Age Group 30-50 years Growth Rapid, large lobulated mass Surface Uneven, bosselated Histology Stromal overgrowth, leaf-like pattern Treatment Wide local excision / mastectomy Galactocele (Option B):
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: A patient with dilated tortuous veins of the leg presented to the OPD and is diagnosed with varicose vein of grade C4a. What is the best preferred treatment?
questions.explanation: • Grade C4a varicose veins (as per CEAP classification) indicate skin changes such as pigmentation or eczema due to chronic venous insufficiency. • Endothermal ablation (radiofrequency or laser) is the first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. • It is minimally invasive, effective, and has faster recovery compared to open surgery. CEAP Classification & Treatment of Varicose Veins CEAP Class Clinical Features Preferred Treatment 259 C0 No visible/palpable signs No treatment needed C1 Telangiectasias or reticular veins Conservative (compression) C2 Varicose veins Compression, ablation, or surgery C3 Edema Endothermal ablation C4a Pigmentation/eczema Endothermal ablation C4b Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche Endothermal or open surgery C5 Healed venous ulcer Endothermal ablation + ulcer care C6 Active venous ulcer Multimodal therapy Compression (Option A):
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: In a follow-up case of prostate cancer, what do we need to check?
questions.explanation: • Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA): • PSA is the most sensitive marker for monitoring prostate cancer progression and recurrence. • Serial PSA measurements help assess treatment response and early detection of relapse. • Role in Follow-Up: • After radical prostatectomy: A rising PSA suggests biochemical recurrence. • During androgen deprivation therapy (ADT): Persistent or rising PSA indicates treatment resistance. • Post-radiotherapy: A gradual PSA rise may suggest local or metastatic progression. Follow-Up in Prostate Cancer Parameter Significance in Prostate Cancer Follow-Up PSA (Prostate-Specific Antigen) Most important marker; rising levels indicate recurrence or metastasis Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) Marker for bone metastases, but not routinely used for follow-up Acid Phosphatase (PAP) Older marker, now largely replaced by PSA Testosterone Checked in hormone-sensitive cases on ADT to confirm castrate levels Alkaline Phosphatase (Option A):

questions.question_text: A 38 Y/o woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and frequent urination. On physical examination, her uterus is found to be irregularly enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This patient's symptoms of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, frequent urination, and an irregularly enlarged uterus are most consistent with a diagnosis of leiomyoma, also known as fibroids. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle neoplasms that originate in myometrium. Clinical features: • Asymptomatic (75%) - mostly an incidental finding • Abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB)(30%): Menorrhagia,metrorrhagia • Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia • Subfertility • Pressure symptoms 262 • Bladder symptoms: increased frequency or retention of urine • Rectal symptoms: constipation • Lower abdominal or pelvic pain or heaviness • Irregularly enlarged lower abdomen. Endometriosis (Option A) also presents with pelvic pain and abnormal menstrual bleeding but an irregularly enlarged uterus is not seen. An ovarian cyst (Option B) most commonly, is asymptomatic but increases the risk of ovarian torsion and presents with an adnexal mass but not an enlarged uterus. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option D) is usually seen in obese women and presents with irregular menstrual bleeding along with hormonal symptoms such as hirsutism and acne.
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and excessive hair growth. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: 263 Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances. Components of PCOS: • Increased androgens • Ovulatory dysfunction • Polycystic ovaries Clinical features: • Usually present in young women • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm. • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea • Infertility • Hirsutism • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance Endometriosis (Option B) involves the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus and presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea and infertility. • While it can cause irregular menstrual cycles, it does not typically cause acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts. Hypothyroidism (Option C) can cause menstrual irregularities, weight gain, and fatigue. • However, it does not commonly present with acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) (Option D): • This condition can occur as a complication of Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART), particularly in individuals who have undergone ovulation induction with medication. • The ultrasound may reveal multiple ovarian cysts, but the clinical presentation is typically characterized by acute abdominal pain rather than irregular menstrual cycles, acne, or hirsutism.
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a yellowish-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She reports painful urination and pain during intercourse & no itching. On speculum examination, her vulva and vaginal walls appear inflamed. What is the causative agent? 264?
questions.explanation: Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age. Symptoms include: • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening • Painful urination • Pain during intercourse • Recurrent infections • Inflamed vulva • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix") Candida albicans (Option B): • Characterized by a scanty, white, curdy vaginal discharge • Intense vulvovaginal itching present leading to erosions causing splash dysuria and dyspareunia Gardnerella vaginalis (Option C): • Characterized by a foul-smelling, thin, gray-white, or green-yellow vaginal discharge • Absence of itching, dysuria, or dyspareunia Neisseria gonorhhea (Option D): • It does not typically cause vaginitis alone. • It can cause cervicitis, whose symptoms can overlap with that of vaginitis.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation: • Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels correlate with the number of antral follicles in the ovaries and provide a direct measure of ovarian reserve. • AMH is less variable throughout the menstrual cycle and is considered the most reliable single test for assessing ovarian reserve. Tests for Ovarian Reserve: Test Name Description Key Points 266 Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles. • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs. • Not affected by the menstrual cycle. • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve Antral Follicle Count (AFC) Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries. • Direct visual assessment. • Can vary with the cycle. • Baseline assessment and monitoring. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles. • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle. • Initial screening of ovarian function. Estradiol (E2) Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles. • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle. • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH. Inhibin B Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles. • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT) Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate. • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10. • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve. • Used for detailed functional assessment. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) on day 3 (Option A): • Elevated levels of FSH on the third day of the menstrual cycle can indicate diminished ovarian reserve. • However, FSH levels can fluctuate and be influenced by various factors, making it a less reliable single test. 267 Estradiol on day 3 (Option B): • Elevated estradiol levels on the third day of the menstrual cycle can suggest a diminished ovarian reserve. • However, like FSH, estradiol levels can be variable and influenced by other factors. Serum inhibin levels on day 5 (Option D): • Inhibin B levels can reflect the size and function of the ovarian follicle pool, but they can be more variable and less consistent than AMH.
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. She has a history of gestational diabetes, and her pregnancy has been otherwise uneventful. The doctor decides to perform antepartum fetal surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess the fetal well-being in this scenario?
questions.option_b: Biophysical profile Contraction Stress test Non Stress test
questions.explanation: 268 • The NST is a non-invasive, quick, and reliable method to assess fetal heart rate response to fetal movements, which is crucial given the reported decrease in fetal movements. • During an NST, the mother is placed in a comfortable position, and external monitors are attached to her abdomen to record the fetal heart rate and any fetal movements for 20 minutes. • A reactive NST (presence of accelerations in fetal heart rate with movements) indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive NST (lack of sufficient accelerations) may necessitate further testing or intervention. Antepartum fetal surveillance: Fetal movement Maternal observation and recording of fetal movements to assess fetal well-being and activity levels. Non-stress test (NST) Monitors fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements to assess fetal well-being. Biophysical profile (BPP) (Option B ruled out) Assesses fetal well-being based on fetal heart rate accelerations, fetal movements, muscle tone, breathing movements, and amniotic fluid volume Doppler velocimetry Uses ultrasound to assess blood flow in fetal vessels like umbilical artery,middle cerebral artery (MCA), and ductus venosus aiding in the evaluation of fetal well-being and placental function Amniotic fluid index (AFI) (Option A ruled out) Measures the depth of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being and detect potential complications like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios Contraction stress test (CST) (Option C ruled out) Evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions to assess fetal well-being and uteroplacental function under controlled stress conditions. BPP, CST, AFI are not the initial tests that are performed as they are either invasive (CST) or time consuming (BPP) or do not properly tell us about fetal movements (AFI).
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: During the active management of the third stage of labor, which intervention is recommended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage primarily due to uterine atony?
questions.option_a: Immediate administration of 20 units of undiluted oxytocin intravenously
questions.option_c: Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent
questions.option_d: Controlled cord traction with immediate removal of the placenta
questions.explanation: • Vigorous fundal massage helps to maintain uterine tone and prevent uterine atony, a common cause of postpartum hemorrhage. • Combining it with a uterotonic agent like oxytocin further enhances uterine contraction, reducing the risk of excessive bleeding. Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) for PPH Uterine Massage • Always palpate the uterine fundus after placental delivery. • Vigorous fundal massage, combined with a uterotonic agent, is recommended to prevent PPH due to uterine atony. • During immediate PPH, perform uterine massage while evaluating for other bleeding sources and administering uterotonic agents. 270 Oxytocin • Recommended by WHO as a first-line prophylactic treatment for postpartum hemorrhage. • Administer 20 units of oxytocin in 1,000 mL of crystalloid solution intravenously at 10 mL/min for a dose of 200 mU/min. • Never administer oxytocin as an undiluted bolus due to risks of severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias.(Option A) • Intravenous oxytocin is also a first-line treatment for uterine atony. • Oxytocin 10 units can be given IM with the delivery of the anterior shoulder (Option B) Delayed Cord Clamping/Controlled Cord Traction (CCT) • If placental separation is evident, perform expression via fundal pressure or controlled cord traction. • If the placenta is not separated, perform manual removal under general anaesthesia. • Delivery of the placenta by cord traction before placental separation especially in an atonic uterus may cause uterine inversion. (Option D)
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most likely abnormality in a patient of recurrent vomiting with pH 7.5, pCO2 48mm Hg, and HCO3- 33?
A patient presents with unilateral throbbing pain, photophobia, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms improve after taking sumatriptan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a food adulteration disease?
A patient with a history of pneumonia develops pleural effusion. What is the expected finding in the pleural analysis for parapneumonic effusion?
questions.option_a: Pleural protein/plasma protein ratio less than 0.5
questions.option_b: Pleural LDH less than 2/3rd of plasma LDH
questions.option_d: Pleural LDH less than 0.6 of plasma LDH
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is often characterized by an expansile, lytic lesion, and its FNA typically yields a bloody aspirate due to the cystic, vascular nature of the lesion. • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages are commonly seen due to prior hemorrhage within the cyst. 281 Giant cell tumor (GCT) (Option A) can also present as an expansile lytic lesion, but it usually involves the epiphysis without such a significant cystic, vascular component or bloody aspirate on FNA. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) Age Primarily affects children and teenagers Most common in young adults (15-35 years) Gender Equal distribution between males and females More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1) Location Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia) Symptoms Pain and swelling; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues Swelling without pain; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture Histology • FNAC: Hemosiderin + • Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae • FNAC: No hemosiderin • Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy Radiology Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction Treatment Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously) Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy Osteosarcoma (Option C): Itis a malignant tumor that presents with mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions rather than a purely lytic, expansile lesion with a bloody aspirate. Chondroblastoma (Option D): Itis a rare benign tumor that affects the epiphysis, usually seen in younger patients, but it does not typically show a bloody aspirate or hemosiderin deposits on FNA. 282
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 65-year-old male with chronic stable angina presents with worsening chest pain during routine activities. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, and atorvastatin, but his symptoms persist. ECG shows ST-segment depression in V5-V6, and coronary angiography reveals 80% stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. What is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.option_c: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)
questions.option_d: Refer for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)
questions.explanation: • The patient has significant stenosis (80% in the LAD) and persistent anginal symptoms despite optimal medical therapy. • PCI with a drug-eluting stent (DES) is the most appropriate intervention in this scenario, as it restores blood flow and relieves symptoms. • DES is preferred due to its lower risk of restenosis compared to bare-metal stents. Medical management Medicatio n Class Function/Mechanism Indications Side Effects/ Contraindication 283 Nitrates Sublingual nitroglycer in (0.4 or 0.6 mg) Long- acting forms (oral, transderma l) • Systemic venodilation • Reduces LV end- diastolic volume and pressure • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle • Angina relief • Preemptive use before activities • Improves exercise tolerance • Tolerance development • Headaches, dizziness Beta- Blocker (Option A) • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility • Improves survival post-MI • Angina relief • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates • Asthma • AV conduction disturbances • Severe bradycardia Calcium Channel Blockers • Coronary vasodilators • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non- dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil) • Angina treatment when beta blockers are ineffective • Variant angina • Bradyarrhythmias • May aggravate LV failure Antiplatel et Drugs • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations • Stent placement • Risk of bleeding • Gastrointestinal issues, allergies Other Therapies: • Ranolazine: Inhibits late sodium current, minimizing Na and Ca overload in ischemic myocytes. (Option B) 284 • SGLT2 Inhibitors: Provide cardiovascular and renal protection, promoting weight loss and reducing plasma volume; beneficial in IHD patients. • Nicorandil: Opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels. • Ivabradine: Reduces heart rate in patients with IHD and LV dysfunction. Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) (Option C) PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries. • Indications: • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy. • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests. • Post-PCI Management: • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months. • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT). Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) (Option D) Involves bypassing obstructive lesions using internal mammary arteries, radial arteries, or saphenous veins. • Indications: • Safe with low mortality in patients without serious comorbidities and normal LV function. • Effective for patients with left main coronary artery stenosis, multivessel disease, or impaired LV function. • Outcomes: • Angina relief in ~90% of patients after complete revascularization. • Long-term survival benefits in specific populations, particularly those with diabetes or impaired LV function.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A 72 y/o woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath after a stressful argument. She is post-menopausal with no history of heart disease. O/E, she is slightly tachycardic with normal blood pressure. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular ballooning during systole, and cardiac enzymes are minimally elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken heart syndrome, is characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction often triggered by emotional or physical stress. • The patient’s recent stressful event, post-menopausal status, ballooning of the left ventricle, and minimal elevation of cardiac enzymes align perfectly with this diagnosis. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Gebrochenes-Herz syndrome) About • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken-heart syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a non-ischemic condition primarily affecting post-menopausal women. • It features temporary left ventricular dysfunction that resembles a heart attack but with minimal cardiac enzyme release and no significant obstructive coronary artery disease. • The name "Takotsubo" is derived from Japanese, meaning octopus trap, reflecting the ballooning shape of the left ventricle during contraction. 286 Pathophysiology • Catecholamine Hypothesis: Elevated catecholamines (norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) indicate stress- induced sympathetic overdrive, leading to microvascular spasms and myocardial injury. • Microvascular Dysfunction: Impaired function is suggested by abnormalities in coronary flow reserve and microvascular resistance. • Inflammation: Imaging may show myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis, with conditions like myocarditis and autoimmune diseases potentially triggering TC. • Estrogen Deficiency: Exaggerated vasoconstriction and increased sympathetic activity in post-menopausal women contribute to TC. Clinical features • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy often mimics acute coronary syndrome.(MI) • Common Triggers: • Emotional Stress: Events like the unexpected death of a loved one, domestic abuse, or financial loss. • Physical Stress: Serious medical diagnoses or natural disasters. • Symptoms: Chest pain, dyspnea, and syncope. Some patients may have signs of heart failure, such as tachyarrhythmias or bradyarrhythmias. • A late-peaking systolic murmur may be present due to LVOTO. • About 10% of patients may develop cardiogenic shock. Hypertensive Heart Disease (Option A): • Caused by chronic high blood pressure, leading to left ventricular hypertrophy. • This patient's history does not indicate long-standing hypertension. Coronary Artery Disease (Option C): • Involves plaque buildup in coronary arteries, causing reduced blood flow. • The absence of obstructive disease on angiography and minimal enzyme release suggests this is unlikely. Pulmonary Embolism (Option D): • Occurs when a blood clot blocks a pulmonary artery, leading to sudden shortness of breath and chest pain. History of long term immobilization/ DVT is present. • The patient's findings indicate a cardiac issue, not a pulmonary one. 287
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department in acute distress. He is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and complains of severe chest pain. His ECG is given below. Given the patient's condition, what is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: The patient's clinical presentation of acute distress, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and severe chest pain, along with the ECG showing saw-tooth flutter waves indicative of atrial flutter, suggests he is hemodynamically unstable. • This necessitates immediate synchronized cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize his condition. Atrial Flutter Features • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus. • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute. • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute. ECG Features • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F- waves." • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify. Diagnosis • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute. • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block. 289 Manageme nt 1. Rhythm Control: • Acute Management: • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion. • Stable Patients: • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus). • Pharmacological cardioversion: • Antiarrhythmic drugs: • Amiodarone • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol • Long-Term Management: • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus. 2. Rate Control: • First-Line Agents: • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem) • Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol) • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity). • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute. 3. Anticoagulation: • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score: • Anticoagulation Recommendations: • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation. • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with increased breathlessness, cough, and sputum production over the last two days. She appears distressed and has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for her immediate treatment?
questions.option_a: Initiate high-flow oxygen therapy to maintain oxygen saturation above 95%
questions.option_b: Start nebulised bronchodilator therapy with salbutamol and ipratropium
questions.option_d: Order a chest X-ray before any treatment is provided
questions.explanation: • Nebulised bronchodilator therapy with salbutamol and ipratropium is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this patient experiencing an acute exacerbation of COPD. • This therapy helps relieve bronchospasm and improve airflow, which is critical given her increased breathlessness and distress. Treatment of Acute Exacerbation of COPD: Initial Management and Assessment: • Symptoms: Increased breathlessness, cough, sputum production; deterioration in lung function and health status. • Triggers: Usually bacterial or viral infections, or changes in air quality. • Home management: Increased bronchodilator therapy, short course of oral glucocorticoids, and possibly antibiotics. • Hospital referral indicators: • Cyanosis 291 • Peripheral oedema • Altered consciousness • Comprehensive assessment upon admission: • Level of consciousness (response to commands, ability to cough) • Signs of CO2 retention (warm peripheries, bounding pulse, flapping tremor) • Airway obstruction assessment (wheeze, prolonged expiration) • Signs of cor pulmonale (peripheral oedema, raised JVP) • Background functional status and quality of life • Precipitating causes (e.g., infection, environmental factors) Investigations: Investigation Purpose/Findings Arterial blood gases Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation. Chest X-ray Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion. (Option D ruled out) Management Strategies: Management Details Oxygen Therapy • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%. (Option A ruled out) • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy. Bronchodilators • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium). • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation. Glucocorticoids • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations. • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses. 292 Antibiotic Therapy • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness. • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms. Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV) • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality. • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway. Mechanical Ventilation • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated. • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP. Additional Therapy • Diuretics for peripheral oedema. • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk. • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates. Discharge and Follow-Up: • Discharge criteria: • Clinically stable on maintenance medication. • Off nebulised therapy for at least 24 hours. • PEF reaches 75% of predicted or personal best. • Post-exacerbation follow-up: • Identify and avoid trigger factors. • Provide asthma education and a written self-management plan. Begin intravenous glucocorticoids immediately (Option C) is not the first-line treatment in the acute setting; while glucocorticoids are important in managing exacerbations, nebulised bronchodilators are prioritised for immediate relief of symptoms.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine follow-up. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are normal, but she has microalbuminuria and an HbA1c of 8%. Her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits, and she is currently on metformin for diabetes management. What should be the next step in her management?
questions.option_c: Stop Metformin and start a different OHA
questions.explanation: Starting ACE inhibitors early in the progression of diabetic nephropathy, particularly with the presence of microalbuminuria, has demonstrated significant benefits in reducing the risk of kidney failure and cardiovascular events. 294 Management of Diabetic nephropathy Oral Hypoglycemic agents (OHAs) • SGLT2 inhibitors lower the risk of cardiovascular events and renal failure; they are also recently approved for HFpEF. • For HbA1C < 9.5%, OHAs can be used • Metformin is withheld if eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (Option C), and drugs safe in renal failure can be used like • Glipizide • Linagliptin • Repaglinide Insulin 80% of the calculated dose is started if HbA1C > 9.5% (Option B) Antihypertensives • In the presence of microalbuminuria, ACEi and ARBs have shown evidence to slow the progression of nephropathy if started in early stages. • In hypertension, for BP > 130/90, ACEi or ARBs are preferred • If BP is still not under control, Calcium channel blocker (CCB) can be added • Thiazide diuretic - in the presence of oedema (Option A) • If eGFR <30 ml/min, then the diuretic used - Metolazone. • ACEi/ARB comes with a side effect of hyperkalemia; hence, regular monitoring of potassium is necessary. • In the presence of hyperkalemia, ACEi/ARB is replaced by CCB • Alpha blocker (Prazosin) - hyperkalemia in ESRD. 295 For Hyperkalemia K Binding resins (Bind to potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promote its excretion) • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate • Patiromer • Sodium zirconate Renal Transplant If eGFR is < 20 mL/min/1.73m2.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 38-year-old male presents with a one-week history of fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, and myalgia. Skin examination reveals multiple purpura and petechiae on the left shoulder, trunk, and legs. Similar cases have been reported linked to increased incidence of mosquito breeding. What is the most common neurological complication associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: 296 • The clinical presentation including fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and the presence of purpura and petechiae, suggests a viral infection consistent with dengue fever. • The association with increased mosquito breeding further supports this diagnosis. • Encephalopathy is the most common neurological complication associated with this condition. Dengue complications Neurological • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures • CSF profiles typically remain normal. • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema. • Encephalitis • GBS • Stroke Cardiomyopathy • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure. Hepatic injury • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis Pneumonia • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia Orchitis • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age. 297 Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever All of the following: • Acute onset of fever • 2-7 days duration • Hemorrhagic manifestations • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae • Ecchymosis • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm. • Plasma leakage • Rising hematocrit • Hemoconcentration >20% • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia) Dengue Shock Syndrome • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80) • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older child and adults)
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: An alcoholic patient presents with palpitations, dizziness, and syncopal attacks. On examination, irregularly irregular pulse is seen. What will be seen on JVP?
questions.explanation: The patient’s irregularly irregular pulse suggests atrial fibrillation (AF), which is common in chronic alcoholics (so-called holiday heart syndrome). In AF, the atria do not contract effectively → no coordinated atrial systole → no a wave is produced in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). Therefore, the finding will be absent a wave. Jugular Venous Pulse (JVP) reflects right atrial pressure changes during the cardiac cycle. • The a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (just before S1). • In AF, there is complete loss of organized atrial contraction → a wave disappears. • Chronic alcoholics are prone to AF due to atrial dilation, electrolyte imbalance, and direct myocardial effects. Atrial fibrillation: Feature Details 2 ECG Irregularly irregular RR intervals, absent P waves, fibrillatory baseline Causes Hypertension, valvular heart disease (esp. mitral), alcohol (holiday heart), thyrotoxicosis Complications Stroke, heart failure, tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy Management Rate control (β-blockers, CCBs), rhythm control (amiodarone, cardioversion), anticoagulation (CHA₂DS₂-VASc score) JVP Waveform: • Positive waves in JVP: • a, c and v • a wave - Atrium Contraction (Lat Rapid Filling Phase) • c wave - Cusp bulging (tricuspid valve cusp bulging towards the atrium) v wave - Venous return • Negative waves in JVP: • x wave - Atrium relaxation • x' wave - Tricuspid valve pulling towards the ventricle • y descend - Opening of tricuspid valve JVP finding Cause Absent a wave Atrial fibrillation Large a wave Tricuspid stenosis, pulmonary hypertension 3 Cannon a wave Complete heart block, VT (atria contracting against closed tricuspid valve) Steep y descent Constrictive pericarditis

questions.question_text: During the assessment of drinking water from a village tank, which of the following parameters is not within the acceptable limits for safe drinking water?
questions.explanation: • The correct answer is Cadmium - 0.03 mg/L because the BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) acceptable limit for cadmium in drinking water is 0.003 mg/L. A value of 0.03 mg/L is ten times higher and is therefore unsafe. 4 Parameter Acceptable Limit (mg/L) Cadmium 0.003 Fluoride 1.0 Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) 500 Nitrate 45 • Cadmium – Toxic heavy metal, harmful to kidneys and bones. • Fluoride – 0.8 mg/L is safe and below the limit of 1.0 mg/L. • TDS – 300 mg/L is within safe range (limit 500 mg/L). • Nitrate – 20 mg/L is below limit of 45 mg/L. Fluoride – 0.8 mg/L (Option B): Safe; below permissible limit of 1.0 mg/L. TDS – 300 mg/L (Option C): Safe; below permissible limit of 500 mg/L. Nitrate – 20 mg/L (Option D): Safe; below permissible limit of 45 mg/L.

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old female with a previous history of rheumatic fever. Examination shows a loud S1 and mid-diastolic murmur is having which of the following valvular heart disease?
questions.explanation: • The patient has a history of rheumatic fever and presents with a loud S1 and mid- diastolic murmur, which are classic findings of mitral stenosis. Rheumatic fever is the most common cause of MS worldwide. • Mitral stenosis results from thickening and fusion of the mitral valve leaflets, most often due to rheumatic heart disease. The loud S1 occurs because the stiff valve closes forcefully, and the mid-diastolic murmur is due to turbulent flow across the narrowed mitral orifice during diastole. Other features may include an opening snap and signs of pulmonary congestion. Mitral stenosis: • Cause: Rheumatic fever (most common), congenital, calcific degeneration (elderly). • Pathophysiology: Narrowed mitral orifice → ↑ left atrial pressure → pulmonary venous hypertension → right heart strain. • Clinical features: Dyspnea, orthopnea, hemoptysis, atrial fibrillation. • Auscultation: Loud S1, opening snap after S2, low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur at the apex (best heard with the patient in the left lateral position). • Complications: Pulmonary hypertension, right heart failure, thromboembolism. • Treatment: Medical (diuretics, rate control for AF) or surgical (percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy, valve replacement). 6
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient presents to the ER with central chest pain. He has a past medical history of heart disease. ECG is shown below. What is the diagnosis? 8?
questions.explanation: ECG Findings: • ST-segment elevation: • Anterior leads: V2–V4 • Lateral leads: I, aVL, V5, V6 • Reciprocal ST-segment depression: leads III and aVF (inferior leads) Interpretation: 9 • This combination indicates acute injury involving both the anterior wall (supplied by the LAD) and the lateral wall (supplied by the LCX or diagonal branches of LAD) — hence, anterolateral MI. • Reciprocal changes (ST depression in inferior leads) strengthen the diagnosis of acute MI and help differentiate from pericarditis. MI location vs. ECG leads MI Location Leads with ST Elevation Likely Artery Anterior V1–V4 LAD Lateral I, aVL, V5, V6 LCX or diagonal branch Anterolateral V2–V6, I, aVL LAD + LCX/diagonal branch Inferior II, III, aVF RCA or LCX Inferolateral II, III, aVF, I, aVL, V5, V6 RCA + LCX Posterior V7–V9 (or tall R in V1–V2) RCA or LCX
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A study was conducted among nursing staff to analyze the time spent on different aspects of patient care, such as bed preparation, monitoring vital signs, attending the doctor’s rounds, blood sampling, and drug administration. Which of the following management techniques is most appropriate for this type of analysis?
questions.explanation: • The study in the question focuses on estimating how much time nursing staff spend on various activities across the day, but not by continuously timing each task from start to finish. Work Sampling is the appropriate method here because it involves taking observations at random intervals to determine the proportion of time spent on different activities. Work Sampling: • Definition: A statistical technique for determining the proportion of time spent on various activities by making observations at random intervals. • Purpose: • Assess workload distribution. • Identify major time-consuming activities. • Provide data for staffing and scheduling decisions. • Applications in Healthcare: 11 • Studying nurse-patient interaction time. • Determining how much time doctors spend in direct patient care vs. paperwork. • Evaluating efficiency in diagnostic labs. Critical Path Method (Option A): Project management technique for scheduling dependent tasks; not for estimating activity time proportions. System Analysis (Option B): Studies entire systems and processes; too broad for specific activity-time proportion studies. Time and Motion Study (Option D): Continuous observation of each step of a task; gives detailed task timings but is more intrusive and detailed than required for this study.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A patient after MI develops a broad QRS complex tachycardia. His BP is 120/85 mm Hg. ECG is given below. Best management?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Recognising the rhythm • Broad QRS (>120 ms) • Regular tachycardia • Monomorphic appearance • Post-MI patient → high risk of ventricular tachycardia (VT) • Diagnosis: Sustained monomorphic VT Step 2: Assessing stability • BP = 120/85 mm Hg → patient is hemodynamically stable (no shock, syncope, severe hypotension, or heart failure). • In stable VT, first-line pharmacologic management = IV amiodarone (or procainamide in some guidelines). Class III antiarrhythmic that prolongs repolarisation and suppresses ventricular ectopy. Preferred in structural heart disease post-MI because other agents (like some beta-blockers) may worsen VT in the acute setting. Stable vs. unstable broad complex tachycardia (VT) Status First-line management Stable VT IV amiodarone (or procainamide) Unstable VT Immediate synchronized DC cardioversion Pulseless VT / VF Immediate defibrillation + CPR

questions.question_text: A patient presents with weight gain, thinning of hair, and dry skin. Diagnosis is Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Which antibody is seen in this case?
questions.explanation: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas, and it is strongly associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies. These antibodies cause autoimmune destruction of the thyroid gland. Anti-TPO antibodies target the enzyme thyroid peroxidase, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis (oxidation and iodination of iodine, coupling of iodotyrosines). Their presence confirms autoimmune thyroid disease, especially Hashimoto’s. Other antibodies, like anti- thyroglobulin, may also be present but anti-TPO has the highest diagnostic relevance. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis: • AKA Chronic autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis. • Epidemiology: More common in women, especially middle-aged. • Pathogenesis: Autoantibodies (anti-TPO, anti-thyroglobulin) → chronic inflammation → fibrosis → hypothyroidism. 14 • Clinical features: Weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair thinning, constipation, menstrual irregularities. • Lab findings: High TSH, low free T4, positive anti-TPO antibodies. • Histopathology: • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration • Formation of germinal centers • Hurthle cells (large oxyphilic epithelial cells with granular cytoplasm) replacing follicular epithelium • Atrophic thyroid follicles with dense fibrosis in late stages • Treatment: Lifelong levothyroxine replacement. • Complications: Increased risk of thyroid lymphoma.
questions.subject: Dermatology

questions.question_text: An RTA patient has received 4 packed RBC within a few hours. Which of the following will be seen?
questions.explanation: • Stored packed RBCs contain citrate as an anticoagulant. Rapid transfusion leads to citrate binding ionized calcium in the recipient’s blood, causing acute hypocalcemia. • Citrate toxicity is more likely when large volumes of blood are transfused rapidly, as in massive transfusion protocols. The liver normally metabolizes citrate, but in shock or hypothermia this clearance is impaired. • Clinical signs: Perioral numbness, paresthesia, muscle cramps, tetany, hypotension, and prolonged QT interval on ECG. Massive Blood Transfusion: • Definition: Replacement of blood volume exceeding patient’s total blood volume within 24 hrs (or >10 units of PRBC). • Acute complications: • Metabolic: Hypocalcemia (citrate toxicity), hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia (from hemolysis), hypothermia, metabolic alkalosis. • Coagulopathy: Due to dilution of platelets and clotting factors. • Volume overload & ARDS. 16 • Prevention: Warm blood before transfusion, monitor electrolytes, give calcium gluconate if needed, replace platelets & FFP in balanced ratios. Key electrolyte changes in massive transfusion: Electrolyte Cause Change Calcium Citrate binding ↓ (Hypocalcemia) Potassium Leakage from stored RBCs ↑ (Hyperkalemia) Magnesium Citrate binding ↓ (Hypomagnesemia) Sodium Usually normal; slight ↑ if using older preservatives —

questions.question_text: A young female presents with ptosis showing diurnal variation. CT chest shows an anterior mediastinal mass identified as thymus gland cancer. Which receptor is affected in this patient?
questions.option_c: Voltage-gated calcium channels at the NMJ 17
questions.explanation: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies target post-synaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. Thymic abnormalities (hyperplasia or thymoma) are common in MG. In MG, antibody-mediated blockade and destruction of post-synaptic ACh receptors reduce the number of available receptors, leading to muscle weakness. Weakness worsens with activity and improves with rest (diurnal variation). The association with thymoma is due to aberrant immune activation in the thymus. Key features: Ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, proximal muscle weakness, preserved reflexes, and response to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Myasthenia Gravis: • Epidemiology: More common in young women and older men. 18 • Pathophysiology: Autoantibodies against post-synaptic nicotinic ACh receptors at NMJ → impaired depolarization of muscle fibers. • Association: Thymic hyperplasia (65%) and thymoma (15%). • Diagnosis: Edrophonium (Tensilon) test, anti-AChR antibody assay, repetitive nerve stimulation showing decremental response. • Treatment: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (pyridostigmine), immunosuppressants, thymectomy (if thymoma present), plasmapheresis/IVIG for crisis. NMJ disorders: Disorder Site of defect Antibody target / mechanism Myasthenia gravis Post-synaptic membrane Nicotinic ACh receptor Lambert–Eaton syndrome Presynaptic terminal Voltage-gated calcium channels Botulism Presynaptic terminal Inhibits ACh release (toxin action)
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old female with progressive limb weakness for the past 1 year. On examination, muscle fasciculations and hypertonia are noted, and the sensory system is intact. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder involving both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN), leading to weakness, hypertonia, and fasciculations, while sparing the sensory system. The presence of UMN signs (hypertonia) and LMN signs (fasciculations) together is characteristic. ALS affects motor neurons in the motor cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord. • UMN involvement → spasticity, hyperreflexia • LMN involvement → muscle atrophy, fasciculations, weakness. • Sensory pathways are usually preserved, helping differentiate from other neuropathies. • Onset is insidious and relentlessly progressive, leading to respiratory failure. ALS: • Epidemiology: Usually presents in middle age; more common in men. • Pathophysiology: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts (UMN) and anterior horn cells (LMN). • Clinical features: Combination of UMN + LMN signs in multiple regions, no sensory loss. • Diagnosis: Clinical (exclusion of mimics), EMG shows denervation and reinnervation. • Prognosis: Progressive; most patients die within 3–5 years from respiratory failure. • Treatment: Riluzole (glutamate inhibitor) modestly prolongs survival; supportive care is key. LMN and UMN signs in ALS: Feature UMN signs LMN signs Tone Spasticity Hypotonia Reflexes Hyperreflexia, Babinski+ Hyporeflexia Muscle bulk Normal initially Atrophy 20 Fasciculations Rare Common
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A patient presents with symmetrical leg weakness and areflexia. He had developed diarrhoea 2 weeks ago. He was diagnosed as having GBS. What is the cause?
questions.explanation: Guillain–Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy, most often triggered by infections like Campylobacter jejuni. It primarily affects myelinated large- diameter motor and sensory fibers (A and B fibers), leading to weakness and areflexia. A- and B-fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for motor function and some sensory modalities. In GBS, autoantibodies and immune cells attack the myelin sheath, impairing conduction. This demyelination disrupts both motor signals (causing weakness) and reflex arcs (causing areflexia). 21 Guillain–Barré Syndrome: • Trigger: Often post-infectious (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, Mycoplasma). • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune-mediated demyelination of peripheral nerves and nerve roots. • Clinical features: Symmetrical ascending weakness, areflexia, minimal sensory loss; may involve cranial nerves (bilateral facial palsy). • Complications: Respiratory muscle involvement → respiratory failure; autonomic instability. • Diagnosis: CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein, normal cell count); NCS shows slowed conduction velocity. • Treatment: IVIG or plasmapheresis; avoid steroids. • Prognosis: Most recover fully, but some have residual deficits. Fiber types affected in GBS: Fiber Type Myelination Function A fibers Myelinated Motor + sensory B fibers Myelinated Preganglionic autonomic C fibers Unmyelinated Pain + temperature
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A patient has developed a cough and weight loss for the last 3 months. Biopsy of lung mass shows expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which paraneoplastic syndrome will most likely occur in this patient?
questions.explanation: Chromogranin and synaptophysin positivity suggests a neuroendocrine tumor, such as small cell carcinoma of the lung. These tumors often produce ectopic ADH, leading to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). In SIADH, excessive ADH secretion causes water retention without corresponding sodium retention, resulting in dilutional hyponatremia and low plasma osmolality. Small cell lung carcinoma is notorious for secreting ectopic hormones, particularly ADH and ACTH. The presence of neuroendocrine markers confirms the tumor’s secretory nature. Small Cell Carcinoma: • Origin: Neuroendocrine Kulchitsky cells in the lung. • Markers: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase (NSE). • Paraneoplastic syndromes: SIADH (ADH), Cushing syndrome (ACTH), Lambert– Eaton myasthenic syndrome (autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels). • Histology: Small cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear molding, high mitotic count. • Prognosis: Aggressive, early metastasis; often unresectable at diagnosis. • Treatment: Combination chemotherapy ± radiotherapy; surgery rarely indicated. 23 Salt and pepper chromatin (black arrows) Paraneoplastic Syndromes in Lung Cancers: Lung Cancer Type Paraneoplastic Syndromes Small cell carcinoma SIADH, Cushing syndrome, Lambert–Eaton Squamous cell carcinoma Hypercalcemia (PTHrP) Adenocarcinoma Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy Carcinoid tumor Carcinoid syndrome Paraneoplastic syndromes seen in other cancers: Cancer Type Paraneoplastic Syndrome Mechanism / Mediator Renal cell carcinoma Polycythemia Erythropoietin production 24 Hepatocellular carcinoma Polycythemia Erythropoietin production Ovarian teratoma Anti–NMDA receptor encephalitis Autoantibodies to NMDA receptors Thymoma Myasthenia gravis Autoantibodies to postsynaptic AChRs Breast cancer Dermatomyositis / Polymyositis Immune-mediated Gastric carcinoma Acanthosis nigricans Growth factors stimulating melanocytes Pancreatic carcinoma Trousseau syndrome (migratory thrombophlebitis) Hypercoagulability (mucin) Lymphomas Hypercalcemia 1,25-(OH)₂ vitamin D production Medullary thyroid carcinoma Diarrhea, flushing Calcitonin, VIP

questions.question_text: A patient presents with palpitations, headache, and sweating. His BP is 180/100 mmHg. 24-hour urinary metanephrine values are elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. Classic symptoms are episodic headache, sweating, and palpitations with hypertension. Elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines confirm catecholamine excess. • Pheochromocytomas arise from chromaffin cells derived from neural crest tissue. Excess secretion of epinephrine and norepinephrine causes paroxysmal hypertension and sympathetic overactivity. Metanephrines are catecholamine metabolites, and their measurement in a 24-hour urine sample or plasma is the most sensitive test for diagnosis. Pheochromocytoma: • Origin: Chromaffin cells (adrenal medulla). • Rule of 10s: ~10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% extra-adrenal (paraganglioma), 10% in children. • Associations: MEN 2A, MEN 2B, von Hippel–Lindau disease, NF1. • Treatment: α-blockade (phenoxybenzamine) before β-blockade, then surgical resection. • Histology: Zellballen pattern (nests of cells with rich vascular stroma). 26
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: A patient with osteoarthritis, for the last 3 months, has been taking ibuprofen and has developed occult GI bleeding. Which is correct about the cause?
questions.option_a: PGE-2 and prostacyclin production were reduced
questions.option_c: PGE-1 and prostacyclin production were reduced
questions.option_d: Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2
questions.explanation: • NSAIDs like ibuprofen inhibit COX enzymes, reducing prostaglandin (PGE₂) and prostacyclin synthesis. These mediators normally maintain gastric mucosal protection by increasing mucus and bicarbonate secretion and promoting mucosal blood flow. • Loss of PGE₂ and prostacyclin leads to impaired gastric mucosal defense, making the mucosa susceptible to acid-induced injury and bleeding. This is the primary mechanism for NSAID-induced gastritis and peptic ulcers. COX-1 inhibition is particularly responsible for GI side effects, as it is involved in constitutive prostaglandin synthesis for mucosal protection. NSAID-induced GI injury: • Mechanism: COX-1 inhibition → ↓ PGE₂, ↓ prostacyclin → ↓ mucus, ↓ bicarbonate, ↓ blood flow. 28 • Risk factors: High-dose/long-term NSAID use, elderly, alcohol, corticosteroids, H. pylori infection. • Prevention: Co-prescription of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or misoprostol (PGE₁ analog). • Histology: Superficial mucosal erosions with inflammatory infiltrates. • Complications: Peptic ulcers, GI bleeding, perforation.
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: What is the name of the technical platform developed under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) to deliver mental healthcare services through a multi-tiered system via telephone, digital platforms, and online portals?
questions.explanation: 29 • The technical platform under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) designed specifically for delivering mental healthcare services through telephone, digital platforms, and online portals in a multi-tiered system is Tele-MANAS (Mental Health Assistance and Networking Across States). Tele-MANAS: • Launched by: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India. • Objective: • Provide accessible, affordable, and quality mental health services across India. • Reduce stigma and bridge the treatment gap for mental illnesses. • Structure: • Tier 1: State Tele-MANAS cells with trained counsellors and mental health professionals answering calls via a toll-free helpline. • Tier 2: District-level mental health facilities for in-person follow-up and advanced care. • Key Features: • Toll-free 24×7 helpline. • Multi-language support. • Integration with digital platforms and online portals for follow-up care. NIKSHAY (Option A): Web-enabled application for TB surveillance, monitoring, and patient management under the National TB Elimination Programme. Quinidine (Option C): An antiarrhythmic and antimalarial drug; unrelated to healthcare IT platforms. e-Sanjeevani (Option D): National telemedicine service providing online OPD and doctor consultations; not specific to mental health.

questions.question_text: During a field visit to monitor training given to an ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) on safe immunization practices, you observe that she has used a syringe with a needle, a vaccine vial, and a cotton swab. After completing the immunization, which of the following statements about biomedical waste disposal is correct?
questions.option_a: The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container
questions.option_b: The used vaccine vial should be discarded in a blue bag 30
questions.option_c: A used cotton swab should be discarded in a red bag
questions.option_d: The needle should be bent and thrown in a red bag
questions.explanation: • Used or expired vaccine vials are considered glass waste and are disposed of in puncture- proof blue containers or blue bags for recycling or proper treatment. • Syringes with needles go into white translucent puncture-proof containers without removing the needle, cotton swabs with blood/body fluids go in yellow bags, and needles should never be bent or broken before disposal, as it increases the risk of needle-stick injury. Item Waste Category Disposal Container/Bag Notes Syringe with needle Sharps White translucent container (puncture- proof) Needle not removed, container disinfected before disposal Used vaccine vial (glass) Glass waste Blue puncture-proof box/bag After ensuring vial is empty/expired Cotton swab (contaminated) Infectious waste Yellow bag If with blood/body fluids Plastic syringe without needle Contaminated recyclable Red bag For autoclaving/microwaving before recycling 31 Biomedical Waste Management Summary • Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressings, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicines, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X- ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial. • Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag. • Sharps and other metals: White bag. • Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag. The syringe with the needle should be disposed of in a black translucent container (Option A):
questions.subject: Community Medicine

questions.question_text: Who is primarily responsible for registering eligible couples for family planning and maintaining their records under the national health system?
questions.explanation: • Under India’s national health system, the Multipurpose Worker (Female), often synonymous with the Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM), is responsible for registering eligible couples for family planning and maintaining their records. • This includes updating the Eligible Couple Register, tracking contraceptive use, and ensuring follow-up services. ASHAs and Anganwadi Workers assist in community mobilization and education but do not maintain the official eligible couple records. Multipurpose Worker (Female) / ANM in Family Planning: • Role in Family Planning: • Maintain Eligible Couple Register (ECR) at the sub-centre level. • Identify eligible couples (married women aged 15–49 years). • Record contraceptive choices and follow-up dates. • Distribute contraceptives (condoms, OCPs) and counsel couples. • Refer for IUCD, sterilization, or other services as required. • Coordination: Works with ASHAs, Anganwadi Workers, and Medical Officers for outreach. ASHA (Option A): Assists in identifying eligible couples, motivating them for family planning, and distributing contraceptives, but does not maintain the official ECR. Village Health Guide (Option C): Works in basic health education and minor treatment at the village level; not involved in formal family planning registration. Anganwadi Worker (Option D): Focuses on nutrition, child care, and preschool education under ICDS; not responsible for maintaining eligible couple records. 33

questions.question_text: A HIV-positive patient presents with chronic diarrhoea for 4 weeks. Stool microscopy shows oval/ elliptical cysts measuring 16 X 20 µm. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation: • Cystoisospora (formerly Isospora belli) causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV. Its oocysts are oval/elliptical, acid- fast, and measure around 20–30 µm (commonly ~16 × 20 µm). • Cystoisospora belli infection leads to malabsorptive diarrhea, often chronic in HIV patients. Diagnosis is made via stool microscopy or modified acid-fast staining, showing large oval oocysts. The organism is transmitted via ingestion of sporulated oocysts in contaminated food or water. Treatment typically involves trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). Opportunistic Protozoal GI infections in HIV: 34 Feature Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora Size 4-6 μ 8-12 μ 24-36 μ Shape Round Round Oval Acid fast (Coccidian cold ZN stain/Kinyoung) + Variable +/- + Autofluorescenc e - + + Treatment Nitazoxanide Cotrimoxazole Cotrimoxazole

questions.question_text: A known case of hyperthyroidism, who is not on medication, is scheduled for total thyroidectomy. The PAC check was not done properly. What is the leading complication that can occur during surgery?
questions.explanation: • In uncontrolled hyperthyroidism, catecholamine sensitivity is increased, predisposing the patient to severe intraoperative arrhythmias, especially during surgical manipulation of the thyroid gland. • A patient with untreated hyperthyroidism undergoing thyroidectomy is at high risk of thyroid storm, precipitated by surgical stress. This can manifest with tachyarrhythmias, hyperthermia, and hypertension. Arrhythmia (especially atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia) is the most immediate and dangerous intraoperative complication. • Proper preoperative control with antithyroid drugs, β-blockers, and adequate preparation is essential.
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old male presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain of cluster headache. What is the best management?
questions.explanation: • High-flow 100% oxygen is the most effective acute abortive therapy for cluster headaches, rapidly relieving pain within 15–20 minutes in most cases. It is safe, well- tolerated, and works faster than most medications. • Cluster headaches are severe unilateral headaches with autonomic features. Acute attacks require rapid-acting treatment — high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask or subcutaneous sumatriptan are first-line. • Oxygen relieves pain by causing vasoconstriction and possibly modulating trigeminal- autonomic reflexes. Prophylaxis (e.g., verapamil, lithium) is started later to prevent recurrences, but during an acute attack, oxygen is the gold standard. Cluster Headache: Feature Cluster Headache 37 Pain Severe, unilateral, retro-orbital/temporal Duration 15–180 minutes per attack Frequency Up to 8/day during cluster periods Autonomic signs Lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, ptosis, miosis Triggers Alcohol, histamine, nitroglycerin during cluster period Acute treatment 100% O₂ (12–15 L/min), subcutaneous sumatriptan Prophylaxis Verapamil (drug of choice), lithium, topiramate
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: Patient presents with hypertension and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. CT scan shows a mass over the kidney with elevated ARR. What is the next best step for the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: • This patient likely has primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome) due to an adrenal adenoma. In unilateral disease confirmed by imaging and biochemistry (elevated Aldosterone–Renin Ratio), surgical adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice. • Hypertension + hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis + high ARR + adrenal mass suggests unilateral aldosterone-producing adenoma. After confirming lateralization (often with adrenal venous sampling in some protocols), the definitive treatment is laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Medical management with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (spironolactone/eplerenone) is reserved for bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or non-surgical candidates. Primary Hyperaldosteronism: Feature Primary Hyperaldosteronism Common causes Adrenal adenoma (Conn’s), bilateral adrenal hyperplasia Key features Hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis Screening Elevated ARR (Aldosterone–Renin Ratio) Confirmatory tests Saline suppression test, fludrocortisone suppression test Treatment – unilateral Surgical adrenalectomy Treatment – bilateral Spironolactone/eplerenone
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old male has had chronic hypercalcemia for the last 1.5 years, but PTH levels are normal. Which of the following is most likely the cause?
questions.explanation: • From the given history, the patient has chronic hypercalcemia but PTH is normal. This means the hypercalcemia is PTH-independent. Sarcoidosis, due to extra-renal production of calcitriol by activated macrophages, presents with hypercalcemia. Sarcoidosis: • Multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, characterized by non-caseating granulomas. In sarcoidosis, activated macrophages inside the granulomas express 1-α- hydroxylase, converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D into 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This leads to increased intestinal calcium absorption and persistent hypercalcemia. • Because the calcium level is high, the parathyroid gland decreases PTH secretion, explaining the normal or low PTH levels in such cases. Feature Details Pathology Non-caseating granulomas in multiple organs Common Sites Lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes 40 Lab Findings ↑ Serum ACE, ↑ calcium, normal/low PTH CXR Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy Diagnosis Clinical + radiological + biopsy confirmation Treatment Glucocorticoids for symptomatic disease 41 42
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: On examination, a person has distended neck veins, absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, and a shift of the trachea. What is the management? 43?
questions.option_a: Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion
questions.explanation: • This is tension pneumothorax – caused by air trapping in the pleural space under pressure. • Key signs: • Respiratory distress • Hyperresonance (air in pleural space) • Absent breath sounds (no lung expansion) • Distended neck veins (↑ intrathoracic pressure → ↓ venous return) • Tracheal shift away from the affected side (mass effect) • In tension pneumothorax, waiting for imaging can be fatal. • Immediate needle decompression is done in the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line using a wide-bore cannula, followed by chest tube insertion. Tension Pneumothorax: • Pathophysiology: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot exit (one- way valve mechanism). This increases intrapleural pressure → lung collapse → mediastinal shift → compression of heart and opposite lung → obstructive shock. • Causes: trauma, mechanical ventilation, rib fractures, ruptured bleb. • Emergency Management: • Needle decompression (life-saving) – 2nd ICS MCL or 4th/5th ICS anterior axillary line. • Chest tube thoracostomy in the 4th/5th ICS mid-axillary line after decompression. 44
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A female presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Best management for this patient?
questions.explanation: The patient has hyperprolactinemia due to a pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma). Hyperprolactinemia → suppresses GnRH → ↓ LH/FSH → menstrual irregularities and infertility. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine or Cabergoline) as they inhibit prolactin secretion and can shrink the tumor. Bromocriptine is safe in women desiring pregnancy. Surgery (trans-sphenoidal resection) is reserved for drug-resistant or compressive symptoms (e.g., visual loss). Prolactinoma: • Causes: • Pituitary adenoma (most common) • Drugs: antipsychotics, metoclopramide • Hypothyroidism (↑ TRH → ↑ prolactin) • Symptoms: • Women: amenorrhea, galactorrhea, infertility • Men: decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, gynecomastia • Mass effect: headaches, bitemporal hemianopia if the optic chiasm is compressed • Diagnosis: serum prolactin, MRI brain with pituitary protocol 46 • Treatment: dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine, Cabergoline) → surgery if not responsive
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A child with progressive pallor and bone has an elevated HbS based on the HPLC report. Which is the best treatment to manage hemolysis in this patient?
questions.explanation: • HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) showing elevated HbS indicates Sickle Cell Disease (SCD). SCD is due to a mutation in β-globin gene → HbS polymerizes under low oxygen → sickling → chronic hemolysis + vaso-occlusive crises. • Voxelotor is an HbS polymerization inhibitor that increases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, stabilizing the oxygenated form and reducing RBC sickling. This directly reduces hemolysis and improves anemia, making it the best treatment here for hemolysis control. 47 Sickle Cell Disease (SCD): • Pathophysiology: Point mutation (Glu → Val) in β-chain of Hb → polymerization in deoxygenated state → distorted RBCs → hemolysis + microvascular occlusion. • Clinical features: • Hemolytic anemia (pallor, jaundice, gallstones) • Pain crises (bone pain, chest pain, abdomen) • Dactylitis in children • Splenic infarction → functional asplenia → infection risk • Diagnosis: HPLC / electrophoresis (↑ HbS, ± HbF, ↓ HbA) • Management: • Hydroxyurea (↑ HbF, reduces crises) • Voxelotor (↓ hemolysis, ↑ Hb) • L-glutamine (↓ oxidative stress) • Crizanlizumab (P-selectin inhibitor, ↓ vaso-occlusion) • Supportive: vaccination, folate, transfusion if needed
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who exhibits miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light conditions?
questions.explanation: • The clinical presentation of miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light is suggestive of Horner syndrome. Ptosis is a result of the weakness of Müller muscle and miosis due to the unopposed action of the sphincter pupillae with resultant anisocoria. • Pancoast tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms seen in Horner syndrome: ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis (lack of sweating). Acquired Neurogenic Ptosis: Acquired ptosis with drooping of the upper eyelid caused by a disruption in the nerve supply to the muscles responsible for elevating the eyelid. Causes: • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement. • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhidrosis (loss of sweating). • Ophthalmoplegic migraine • Multiple Sclerosis Diagnosis: • Topical apraclonidine test is now considered the test of choice. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that also acts as a very weak alpha 1-adrenergic agonist; when topically applied in Horner’s syndrome, it causes dilation of the affected pupil and possibly lid elevation, without change to the normal pupil.

questions.question_text: A 60-year-old female presents with weakness, back pain and repeated infections. Work up shows M spike on serum electrophoresis. Prognosis is determined by which of the following factors?
questions.explanation: The International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma — a widely accepted prognostic model — uses two lab values: serum β₂-microglobulin and serum albumin. • β₂-Microglobulin is a marker of tumor burden and renal function; elevated levels indicate more advanced disease and poorer prognosis. • Albumin reflects the patient’s general health and disease activity; lower levels are associated with more aggressive disease and worse outcomes. 50 ISS Staging Stage Criteria Prognosis I β₂-microglobulin < 3.5 mg/L albumin ≥ 3.5 g/dL Best prognosis II Intermediate values (not fitting I or III) Intermediate prognosis III Intermediate values (not fitting I or III) Poor prognosis
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A young male patient has the following serological status: HbsAg positive, IgM anti Hbc negative, IgG Anti-Hbc positive and HBeAg positive. Select the best treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: • The serology indicates chronic active hepatitis B infection: • HBsAg positive → Ongoing HBV infection. • IgM anti-HBc negative, IgG anti-HBc positive → Chronic (not acute) phase. • HBeAg positive → High viral replication and infectivity. • Patients with chronic active HBV and high viral load (HBeAg positive) require antiviral therapy to suppress viral replication and reduce liver inflammation, fibrosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma risk. • Lamivudine, an oral nucleoside analog, inhibits HBV DNA polymerase and is one of the older but effective drugs in HBV management (though tenofovir and entecavir are now preferred first-line due to less resistance).
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient with RTA is passing red color urine due to myoglobinuria. Which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: • Myoglobinuria typically occurs after rhabdomyolysis, where muscle breakdown releases myoglobin and intracellular potassium into the bloodstream. • Myoglobin is nephrotoxic, causing acute tubular necrosis (ATN). • Tubular injury in ATN often impairs potassium excretion, resulting in Type 4 RTA physiology, which is characterized by hyperkalemia and mild metabolic acidosis. • The potassium rise is further exacerbated by direct release from damaged muscle cells.

questions.question_text: A patient after RTA had a renal shut down. Work-up shows: FeNa: < 1%, Urine osmolality: 300 mOsm/kg, Urinary sodium: 40 mEq/L. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • This presentation points to intrinsic renal injury, specifically ATN, where damaged renal tubules lose the ability to reabsorb sodium and concentrate urine. • Key features in this case: • Urinary sodium > 40 mEq/L → tubular sodium wasting • Urine osmolality ~300 mOsm/kg → isosthenuria (urine similar to plasma) • FeNa < 1% is more typical of pre-renal AKI, but in early ATN or mixed states it can also be low. • Here, the high urinary sodium and poor urine concentration outweigh FeNa alone, supporting ATN.
