Clinical Phases of ATN Phase Description 54 Prerenal Phase (Pre-ATN) • ↓ Renal perfusion (e.g., hypovolemia, CHF) • Tubular function intact • FeNa <1%, BUN:Cr >20 • Responds to fluids • Reversible if corrected early Initiation Phase • Time of original injury (ischemia/toxins) • Mild ↓ GFR, slight ↑ creatinine • Urine output may be normal • Damage beginning but potentially reversible Extension Phase • Ongoing injury + inflammation (days 1–3) • Tubular necrosis, obstruction • Key sign: ↑ Creatinine + new oliguria despite fluids • FeNa >2%, granular casts may appear Maintenance Phase • Established tubular damage • Low GFR, sustained ↑ creatinine/BUN • Oliguric or non-oliguric • Electrolyte imbalances: hyperkalemia, acidosis Recovery (Repair) Phase • Tubular regeneration • Polyuric phase: ↑ urine output • Gradual ↓ creatinine • Risk: volume depletion, electrolyte loss
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: A patient is in ICU and there is a failed attempt of subclavian catheterization. Shortly after, BP drops and the pulse rises. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Subclavian vein catheterization carries a significant risk of pleural injury, which can cause pneumothorax. • Air entry into the pleural space leads to reduced venous return, causing hypotension and reflex tachycardia. • In the ICU setting, this can rapidly progress to tension pneumothorax, which is life- threatening and requires urgent decompression. • Typical signs: sudden drop in BP, tachycardia, respiratory distress, unilateral decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on percussion.

questions.question_text: A patient had a road traffic accident (RTA). NCCT head was normal on admission. The patient later died after several days in the ICU due to coma. Brain biopsy revealed multiple punctate hemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Diffuse axonal injury is a primary brain injury caused by shearing forces during high- velocity trauma (e.g., RTA). • These forces disrupt axons in the white matter, corpus callosum, and brainstem. • On initial imaging, NCCT may be normal or show only tiny petechial hemorrhages; the condition is often diagnosed clinically or via MRI. • Histopathology (or biopsy) reveals multiple punctate hemorrhages in deep white matter tracts. • DAI often leads to immediate or prolonged coma without a lucid interval and carries a high mortality rate. 57
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: A patient presents with fever and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shows multiple ring stages. Best treatment is?
questions.explanation: • Fever with altered sensorium in malaria indicates cerebral malaria — a severe form most often due to Plasmodium falciparum. • Multiple ring forms on smear strongly suggest falciparum malaria. • Artesunate is preferred over quinine for severe malaria as per WHO guidelines, given its better safety profile, faster parasite clearance, and lower mortality. • It is administered intravenously in the acute setting. 59
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.explanation: Importance of Chest X-ray in Central Line Placement • Initial Assessment: • A chest X-ray should be performed immediately after internal jugular and subclavian line placement to confirm correct catheter placement and rule out iatrogenic pneumothorax. • Post-Procedure Verification: • It is crucial to verify catheter placement and ensure no complications, like pneumothorax, following the procedure. • Ipsilateral Side Approach: • If the internal jugular central venous line (CVL) insertion fails, move to the ipsilateral subclavian vein. • A chest X-ray or ultrasound should be performed before attempting the opposite side to prevent bilateral pneumothoraces. Options B, C, and Dare
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: What defect is seen in Bernard Soulier syndrome?
questions.explanation: • Bernard–Soulier syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive platelet disorder characterized by a defect in platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet membrane glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) complex, which is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF). • This defect prevents platelets from binding to exposed subendothelial vWF during vascular injury, leading to defective primary hemostasis. • Clinically, it presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, prolonged bleeding time, and thrombocytopenia with giant platelets on peripheral smear.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with SOB and fatigue. CXR was done. What is the diagnosis? 62?
questions.explanation: • Asbestosis is an interstitial lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, often in occupations such as shipbuilding, construction, or insulation work. • The hallmark radiologic finding is calcified pleural plaques, especially along the parietal pleura and diaphragm (“peripheral pleural calcification”), along with lower lobe interstitial fibrosis. • Patients present with progressive dyspnea and restrictive lung disease on PFTs.

questions.question_text: A patient presents with progressive shortness of breath for the last 6 months, accompanied by dry cough. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal end-inspiratory crepitations. There is no history of fever, joint pain, or occupational exposure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive fibrosing interstitial lung disease of unknown cause, typically seen in older adults. • The classic presentation includes gradually worsening exertional dyspnoea and nonproductive cough over months. • On auscultation, bilateral basal end-inspiratory “Velcro” crackles are characteristic. • Absence of fever, joint symptoms, or occupational dust/fume exposure supports an idiopathic diagnosis rather than secondary interstitial lung disease.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A patient has a long arm span, hypermobile joints and hypermobile lens. What is the defective protein?
questions.explanation: • The presentation describes Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to defective fibrillin-1, an essential component of microfibrils that provide structural integrity to connective tissue and regulate TGF-β signaling. • Clinical features include tall stature, disproportionately long limbs (increased arm span- to-height ratio), joint hypermobility, lens subluxation (typically upward), and cardiovascular involvement (aortic root dilatation, aneurysm). 66
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: A child presents with kawasaki disease with multiple small coronary artery aneurysms. Treatment is?
questions.explanation: • In Kawasaki disease patients with small coronary artery aneurysms, low-dose aspirin is continued for about 6 to 8 weeks to prevent thrombosis as the aneurysms may regress over time. • The 6-week duration covers the period of highest thrombotic risk during vascular remodeling. • Early IVIG administration is also critical during the acute phase to reduce aneurysm 68
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: The infant is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of seizures. ECG shows Hypsarrhythmia. Which drug is preferred for management?
questions.explanation: • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG is characteristic of infantile spasms (West syndrome), a severe epileptic encephalopathy in infants. • The first-line treatment is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which helps reduce spasms and improve developmental outcomes.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with contralateral face, arm, and leg weakness. NCCT shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). What is the most likely location of the CNS bleed?
questions.explanation: • Intracerebral hemorrhages causing contralateral hemiparesis (weakness of face, arm, and leg) most commonly occur in the basal ganglia, especially the putamen. • The basal ganglia hemorrhage compresses the internal capsule where corticospinal fibers run, causing dense contralateral motor deficits. 71
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: What is the management of undulant fever?
questions.explanation: • Undulant fever is a classic presentation of brucellosis, a zoonotic infection. • The standard treatment involves combination therapy with doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 6 weeks) plus rifampicin (600–900 mg daily for 6 weeks) to prevent relapse and ensure eradication. • Monotherapy with doxycycline alone is insufficient due to high relapse rates.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A patient has cheilosis with koilonychia and anemia. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation: • Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by the triad of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and glossitis/cheilosis. • Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) and cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth) are classic signs of iron deficiency. • This syndrome increases the risk of developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma if untreated.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Which classification is used for Barrett esophagus?
questions.explanation: • The Prague C & M classification is used for Barrett esophagus, where C denotes the circumferential extent of the Barrett mucosa and M denotes the maximal extent from the gastroesophageal junction, as measured endoscopically. • It helps in standardizing reporting and guiding surveillance. Prague Classification • Two key measurements: • C (Circumferential extent) • M (Maximum extent) • Circumferential extent • Distance (in cm) from the GE junction to the proximal limit of circumferential Barrett's mucosa • Maximum extent: • Distance from the GE junction to the furthest proximal extension of any Barrett's mucosa (including tongues or islands) 75 • Example: • If Barrett's mucosa is circumferentially present for 3 cm, and a tongue extends up to 6 cm: • Prague classification = C3M6

questions.question_text: A female patient complains of chest pain while waking up in the morning. Pain is more in winter months. Which of the following best describes this patient?
questions.option_c: Subendocardial ischemia due to increased demand of myocardium
questions.option_d: Increased sympathomimetic drive in morning hours
questions.explanation: • This presentation is classic for Prinzmetal’s (variant) angina, which is due to transient vasospasm of coronary arteries often occurring at rest, particularly in the early morning hours and more frequently in cold weather. • Acetylcholine and other vasoconstrictors can trigger the spasm. 76 • ECG during pain may show transient ST-segment elevation.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: CSF shows abundant PMNs with low sugar and elevated proteins. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation: • Acute bacterial meningitis (ABM) is characterized by neutrophilic predominance (PMNs) in CSF, low glucose (due to bacterial consumption and impaired transport), and elevated proteins (due to increased permeability of the blood–brain barrier). CSF Findings in various types of meningitis: 77 Type Openin g Pressur e Predominant Cell Type Protein Glucose Gross Appearanc e Bacterial Meningitis Elevated Polymorphonuclea r Neutrophils (PMNs) Elevate d Decrease d Turbid Fungal/Tubercula r Meningitis Elevated Lymphocytes Elevate d Decrease d Straw- colored (TB meningitis) Viral Meningitis Normal or Slightly Elevated Lymphocytes Normal or Slightly Elevate d Normal Normal or Turbid
questions.subject: Biochemistry

questions.question_text: A 5 year old boy presented with hematemesis and was found to have splenomegaly, on examination. There was a past history of exchange transfusion in this child for neonatal jaundice. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presentation of hematemesis and splenomegaly, along with the significant history of exchange transfusion in the neonatal period, strongly suggests portal vein thrombosis. This condition is a common cause of portal hypertension in children and can result from umbilical vein catheterization during exchange transfusion.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A skin graft was performed on an immunocompromised patient using tissue from another immunocompromised individual. Weeks later, the patient developed contractures and systemic symptoms. What is the most likely cause?
questions.option_c: Rejection due to recipient T8 cells
questions.explanation: • Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs when immunocompetent donor T lymphocytes recognize recipient tissues as foreign and mount an immune response. • This typically happens in immunocompromised recipients who are unable to reject the donor T cells. • In the context of a skin graft (especially from another immunocompromised individual where donor lymphocytes may survive), • GVHD can cause systemic symptoms (fever, rash, liver dysfunction, diarrhea) along with local changes like skin contractures.
questions.subject: Dermatology

questions.question_text: The finding seen in the image is? 81?
questions.explanation: • Herbert’s pits are small, shallow depressions seen at the limbal conjunctiva due to healed limbal follicles in trachoma. • They are considered pathognomonic of previous trachoma infection. • Pathophysiology: Chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection causes limbal follicles → ulceration → healing with depression. • WHO grading: Presence of Herbert’s pits indicates prior active trachoma and is seen in the scarring stage (TS). 82

questions.question_text: A patient with pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma now presents with loss of visual field. What visual field defect will be seen in the patient?
questions.explanation: • The optic chiasm contains crossing fibers from the nasal retina of both eyes. • Pituitary adenoma commonly compresses the central chiasm from below → affects crossing nasal fibers → loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes → Bitemporal hemianopia • Clinical scenario: Gradual, progressive peripheral vision loss, more noticeable while driving or walking. • Mechanism: Nasal retinal fibers detect temporal fields → damage leads to bitemporal hemianopia. 83 84 Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects Site of Lesion Fibers Affected Field Defect Optic Nerve Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers Optic Chiasma Bilateral Nasal Fibers 85 • Optic Tract • Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion) • Optic Radiation Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip (Post. Cerebral Artery) Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation Tip of Visual Cortex (Middle Cerebral Artery) Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers. Aspect Inferior Optic Radiations (Meyer’s Loop) Superior Optic Radiations (Baum’s Loop) Location of Lesion Temporal lobe Parietal lobe Affected Visual Field Superior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes Inferior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes. Visual Defect Superior homonymous quadrantanopia (Option D ruled out) Inferior homonymous quadrantanopia Associated Symptoms • Memory loss • Hearing loss • Auditory hallucinations • Contralateral hemiplegia • HemiAnaesthesia • Optokinetic nystagmus 86 Homonymous anopia (Option B): Complete blindness in corresponding halves of the visual fields of both eyes (e.g., entire right field loss) - occurs with complete optic tract lesion, not chiasmal compression.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with complaints of eye strain. The given image shows the focus of light rays in different meridians in the eye. Which refractive error is present in this patient? 87?
questions.explanation: • The image of Sturm’s conoid demonstrates that parallel light rays do not converge to a single focal point, but rather form two focal lines at different distances due to unequal refractive power in different meridians of the cornea or lens. • This optical phenomenon is characteristic of astigmatism, where light rays along one meridian focus in front of the retina while rays along the perpendicular meridian focus either behind or at a different point. • Astigmatism causes blurred or distorted vision and eye strain (asthenopia), especially with prolonged near tasks. Sturm’s conoid in Astigmatism: 1. Light rays from an object pass through two principal meridians with different curvatures. 2. Each meridian has its own focal length → creates two focal lines (not a single point). 3. The area between these two focal lines is called the Sturm’s conoid. 4. The best vision is achieved at the circle of least confusion, located between the two focal lines. 88
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A myopic patient presents with complaints of flashes and floaters. On examination, a deep anterior chamber is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • A myopic patient with flashes (photopsia), floaters, and a deep anterior chamber suggests posterior vitreous detachment with retinal tear. This allows liquefied vitreous to pass into the subretinal space, leading to rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. • Key mechanism: Myopia → long axial length → retinal thinning + lattice degeneration → predisposes to retinal breaks. These breaks allow fluid entry under retina → separation from retinal pigment epithelium. • Deep anterior chamber in this context is due to elongation of the globe and posterior shift of the lens–iris diaphragm in high myopia. Type of Retinal Detachment Clinical Features 90 Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment 1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration. 2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements. 3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads. 4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region. 5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment. 6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis. 7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment. 8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts. 91 Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option C ruled out) 1. Gradual, progressive visual loss 2. Typically painless 3. No associated flashes or floaters 4. Vitreoretinal bands present 5. No retinal breaks 6. Detached area - concave and localized 7. No shifting fluid 92 Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option A ruled out) 1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss 2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations. 3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances 4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit. 5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature. Central serous retinopathy (Option D): Localized serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula, seen in young stressed males; presents with central vision blurring and metamorphopsia, not flashes/floaters.
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: An elderly female presents with sudden onset of pain, redness, and decreased vision. On examination, hazy cornea, fixed mid-dilated pupil, and shallow anterior chamber are noted. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • The presence of ocular pain, redness, decreased vision, and corneal haze can be seen in both acute uveitis and acute angle-closure glaucoma, but here the combination of inflammation signs (ciliary congestion, corneal edema) and pupil changes points toward acute uveitis as the answer given. • In uveitis, cells and flare in anterior chamber cause corneal haze, and pupil is irregular or sluggishly reactive due to posterior synechiae; early on it may appear mid- dilated. • The shallow anterior chamber here may be due to ciliary body swelling pushing the iris forward in acute inflammation. Key features of Acute Uveitis: 1. Pain, photophobia, redness (ciliary flush). 2. Decreased vision due to corneal edema and aqueous flare. 3. Irregular or sluggish pupil (posterior synechiae). 4. May cause shallow anterior chamber due to ciliary body congestion. Anterior Uveitis Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye. Clinical Features: • Pain • Redness • Photophobia (sensitivity to light) • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking) • Serous discharge • Blurring and diminished vision Examination Findings: 94 • Keratic Precipitates (KPs): • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle • Aqueous Cells: • Indicator of active inflammation • Aqueous Flare: • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues • Muddy Iris: • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage • Miosis: • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue • Nodules on the Iris: • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non- granulomatous uveitis • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis 95 Complications: (Findings) • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens • Cyclitic Membrane • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris 96
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer in the eye. On examination, a long, branching ulcer with desquamated epithelium is seen on the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • A painless corneal ulcer indicates reduced or absent corneal sensation. • The finding of a long, branching ulcer with desquamated epithelium but without the typical raised edges and terminal bulbs of herpes simplex keratitis suggests a neurotrophic ulcer. 97 • Neurotrophic keratopathy results from damage to trigeminal nerve sensory supply, leading to impaired healing and epithelial breakdown, producing branching epithelial defects. Neurotrophic Ulcer: 1. Painless despite corneal epithelial defect. 2. Decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation. 3. Often branching/irregular ulcer margins. 4. Causes: herpes simplex/zoster, trigeminal nerve damage (tumor, surgery), diabetes, chronic topical medication toxicity. 5. May follow procedures like Gasserian ganglion removal or blockage, often used in treating trigeminal neuralgia. 6. Poor healing tendency due to loss of corneal reflex and trophic support.
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A 45-year-old patient with eye examination findings of a deep anterior chamber and jet-black pupil is prescribed +12D glasses. Likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Clinical reasoning: • Deep anterior chamber → suggests absence of crystalline lens. • Jet-black pupil → no lens reflections seen. • +12D prescription → large convex lens to replace lost refractive power of natural lens. • Aphakia = complete absence of the natural lens (usually post-cataract surgery without IOL implantation). • Without the lens, refractive power decreases drastically (~+15D needed), so strong convex lenses are prescribed. • Causes: Post-cataract extraction without IOL, trauma, congenital. • Features: Deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, jet-black pupil, high hypermetropia (+10 to +15D). Aphakia: Definition • Absence of crystalline lens from the eye. Aetiology • Congenital absence (rare) • Surgical removal (common) • Traumatic extrusion of lens (rare) • Posterior lens dislocation (optical aphakia) Optical Effects • High hypermetropia • Reduced eye power to +44 D (from +60 D) Symptoms • Defective vision (far and near) • Erythropsia and cyanopsia (abnormal red and blue color defect) 99 Signs • Limbal/corneal scar (in surgical cases) • Deep anterior chamber • Iridodonesis & Jet-black pupil • Only 2 Purkinje images (normal: 4) • Hypermetropic small optic disc Treatment Correct refractive error with: • Spectacles: the problem of spherical aberration and roving ring scotoma (jack-in-the-box phenomenon) • Contact lenses • Intraocular lenses (IOL) - best method • Refractive LASIK surgery
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A man presents to the hospital with a bizarre behavior. He is unable to recall his personal identity and has no memory of how he traveled 100 km to reach the hospital. A collateral history reveals he experienced a traumatic earthquake a few months ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient's presentation is a classic example of a dissociative disorder, specifically dissociative amnesia with a dissociative fugue. The key features that point to this diagnosis are: • Inability to Recall Personal Information: The patient is unable to remember his personal identity and significant past events. This memory loss is not due to a medical condition. • Following a Traumatic Event: The amnesia is directly linked to a recent, severe traumatic stressor (the earthquake). This is a hallmark of dissociative disorders. • Dissociative Fugue: The patient's purposeful travel over a long distance (100 km) without any memory of the journey is characteristic of a dissociative fugue, a subtype of dissociative amnesia.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A girl with schizophrenia presents to a Primary Health Centre (PHC) in India. Which of the following online applications, provided by the Government of India (GOI), is used for mental health service support? 101?
questions.explanation: Tele MANAS, which stands for Tele Mental Health Assistance and Networking Across States, is the correct answer. It is a landmark initiative by the Government of India (GOI) to provide mental health services to the public. • Service Offerings: Tele-MANAS is a 24/7, toll-free tele-mental health service designed to provide immediate mental health support to individuals in distress. • Accessibility: It is available through a toll-free number (14416) and is part of the National Mental Health Programme. It aims to bridge the gap in mental health care by providing accessible services, particularly in remote and underserved areas.
questions.subject: Psychiatry

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old software engineer presents with sleep disturbances, low mood, and stress for the past 3 months. He attributes his symptoms to ongoing problems at work. He has no prior psychiatric history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 102?
questions.explanation: The patient's symptoms are a classic presentation of adjustment disorder. The diagnostic criteria for this condition are: • Emotional or Behavioral Symptoms: The patient exhibits emotional or behavioral symptoms (sleep disturbances, low mood, stress) in response to an identifiable stressor. • Timeline: The symptoms must begin within three months of the onset of the stressor (in this case, excessive work pressure). • Marked Distress and Impairment: The symptoms cause marked distress that is disproportionate to the severity of the stressor and lead to significant impairment in social or occupational functioning (difficulty maintaining work-life balance). • Exclusion of Other Disorders: The symptoms do not meet the criteria for another specific mental disorder, such as major depressive disorder or a psychotic disorder.
questions.subject: Psychiatry

questions.question_text: A patient presents with painful lid swelling. On examination, a pus point is observed at the base of an eyelash. Which of the following glands is involved?
questions.explanation: • Painful lid swelling with a visible opus point (localized yellowish spot of pus) at the base of an eyelash is characteristic of external hordeolum (stye). • An external hordeolum is an acute bacterial infection (usually Staphylococcus aureus) of the sebaceous glands of Zeis located at the eyelash follicle. • The pain is due to acute inflammation, and the pus may discharge spontaneously, relieving symptoms. Condition Definition & Features Treatment 104 External Hordeolum (Stye) • Acute suppurative inflammation of a lash follicle and associated glands of Zeis or Moll. • Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus. • Symptoms: Acute pain with swelling on the anterior lid margin, watering and photophobia. • Hot compresses 2-3 times daily. • Evacuate pus by epilating involved cilia when pus point forms. • Rarely, surgical incision for large abscess. • Antibiotic eye drops and ointment. • Systemic anti- inflammatory and analgesics. • Systemic antibiotics for early infection control. • Identify and treat predisposing conditions in recurrent cases.
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A female presents with symptoms of being excessively talkative, hyperactive, sleeping very little, and spending large amounts of money on shopping sprees. When confronted, she becomes irritable. What is the most likely diagnosis? 105?
questions.explanation: The patient's symptoms are a classic and clear presentation of a manic episode, which is the defining characteristic of Bipolar I Disorder. The key symptoms described are: • Elevated or Irritable Mood: She is hyperactive and, when confronted, becomes irritable. • Decreased Need for Sleep: She is sleeping very little. • Pressured Speech: She is excessively talkative. • Risky or Impulsive Behavior: She is spending large amounts of money on shopping sprees, a form of impulsive and often reckless behavior seen in mania. A diagnosis of a manic episode requires these symptoms to be present for at least one week and to cause significant functional impairment, such as the social and financial distress caused by the spending sprees.
questions.subject: Psychiatry

questions.question_text: A 45-year-old patient presents with difficulty reacting to bright light. On examination, the pupillary light reflex is absent but the near reflex is preserved. Where is the lesion likely located?
questions.explanation: • Absence of the light reflex with preservation of the near reflex is known as light-near dissociation. • This occurs when the lesion interrupts the pathway from the optic tract to the Edinger– Westphal nucleus before the convergence–accommodation pathway branches — classically in the pretectal area of the midbrain. • Common causes: Argyll Robertson pupil (neurosyphilis), Parinaud’s syndrome (pineal tumors). Mechanism: 1. Light reflex pathway: Retina → optic nerve → optic chiasma → optic tract → pretectal area → bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei → oculomotor nerve → sphincter pupillae. 2. Near reflex pathway bypasses the pretectal area lesion and reaches Edinger–Westphal nuclei via cortical connections, so it remains intact.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A person has a false belief that he owns a lot of property and that someone he knows is trying to take it away from him. Which of the following best describes the type of delusions he is experiencing?
questions.explanation: This patient is experiencing two distinct types of delusions simultaneously: • Delusion of Grandeur: This is a false and exaggerated belief in one's own importance, power, or identity. The belief that he owns a lot of property is an example of a grandiose delusion, as it exaggerates his financial or social status. • Delusion of Persecution: This is the most common type of delusion, characterized by the false belief that one is being harassed, harmed, or conspired against. The belief that someone is trying to take his property away from him is a classic example of a persecutory delusion.

questions.question_text: A girl, after returning from a picnic, complains of pain in her eyes. She had not maintained proper hygiene of her contact lenses. What would be the cause?
questions.explanation: • Improper contact lens hygiene, especially with exposure to contaminated water (picnic scenario, possible swimming), is a major risk factor for Acanthamoeba keratitis. • Acanthamoeba is a free-living protozoan found in water, soil, and air; it can adhere to contact lenses and invade the corneal epithelium, causing severe pain (often disproportionate to clinical signs), redness, tearing, and photophobia. • Classic sign: ring-shaped stromal infiltrate in advanced cases. Acanthamoeba keratitis: 1. Severe pain out of proportion to clinical findings. 2. History of contact lens wear, especially poor hygiene or water exposure. 3. Resistant to routine antibacterial therapy; requires specific anti-amoebic agents (e.g., polyhexamethylene biguanide, chlorhexidine). 109 4. Delayed diagnosis can lead to corneal perforation and vision loss. Examination Findings in Acanthamoeba Keratitis: Symptoms: • Blurred Vision: Common in corneal conditions due to the disruption of the cornea's transparent surface. • Discomfort: Significant discomfort in the affected eye. • Severe Pain: Pain is often out of proportion to clinical signs, a key clinical clue. Signs: Early Disease: • Irregular and Greyish Epithelium: Early sign indicating amoebic invasion. • Pseudodendrites: Lesions resembling herpetic keratitis • Limbitis and Stromal Infiltrates: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction with diffuse or focal infiltrates in the anterior stroma. • Perineural Infiltrates (Radial Keratoneuritis): Hallmark sign, radial streaks extending towards the cornea's centre, pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis. Advanced Disease: • Ring Abscess: Characteristic of advanced infection, where infiltrates form a ring-shaped abscess. • Stromal Opacification and Vascularisation: Corneal opacity and new blood vessel growth, leading to significant vision impairment. • Corneal Melting: Serious complication where corneal tissue breaks down, often at the infiltrate edges. • Scleritis: Reactive inflammation of the sclera, not a direct infection extension. Investigations and Treatment of Acanthamoeba Keratitis: Investigations: • Corneal Scraping: • The primary method for obtaining tissue for examination. • Scrape the margins and base of the lesion after applying a non-preserved topical anaesthetic. • Staining: • PAS (Periodic acid–Schiff) and Calcofluor white: Highly effective for visualizing Acanthamoeba cysts. • Gram and Giemsa stains: Less sensitive but can also demonstrate cysts. • Culture: Definitive diagnosis by culturing on non-nutrient agar with dead E. coli. • Additional Investigations: • Immunohistochemistry: Uses antibodies to detect specific Acanthamoeba antigens. 110 • PCR: Useful for detecting Acanthamoeba DNA. • In Vivo Confocal Microscopy: Provides detailed images of Acanthamoeba cysts within the cornea. • Corneal Biopsy: • Considered if other diagnostic methods are inconclusive. Treatment Modalities: • Debridement: Removal of infected epithelium to enhance topical medication penetration. • Topical Amoebicides: • PHMB (polyhexamethylene biguanide) 0.02% and Chlorhexidine 0.02%: Effective against both trophozoites and cysts. • Hexamidine: More effective than Propamidine (Brolene). • Topical Steroids: • Considered for persistent inflammation after two weeks of anti-amoebic treatment. • Caution against use if corneal thinning is present. • Pain Management: Oral NSAIDs are recommended for pain relief. • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Required for cases resistant to medical therapy or when corneal perforation occurs.
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A patient with schizophrenia, developed muscular dystonia and was treated for it. The patient now presents with complaints of dry mouth, dizziness, and hypotension. What is the most likely drug causing these side effects? 111?
questions.explanation: The patient with schizophrenia likely developed acute dystonia as a side effect of antipsychotic therapy, which is commonly treated with an anticholinergic drug like benztropine. • Treatment: Muscular dystonia is typically treated with anticholinergic medications. These drugs work by blocking acetylcholine activity to restore the balance of neurotransmitters in the brain. • New Symptoms: The patient now presents with dry mouth, dizziness, and hypotension. These are classic side effects of anticholinergic drugs. • Dry mouth: Caused by the anticholinergic effect of blocking muscarinic receptors in the salivary glands. • Dizziness and hypotension: Can be caused by the drug's effect on blood pressure regulation and the central nervous system.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: The following light reflex is seen in a patient. How much is the deviation?
questions.explanation: • The image shows the Hirschberg test result — the corneal light reflex is displaced toward the limbus in one eye. • In the Hirschberg test: • Each 1 mm displacement of the corneal light reflex from the center corresponds to ~15 prism diopters (PD) of deviation. • Reflex at the limbus ≈ 45 PD deviation. 113 • Here, the reflex is at the corneal periphery/limbus, indicating about 45 PD of exotropia (outward deviation). Hirschberg test correlation: Reflex position Deviation (PD) Centered 0 1 mm from center 15 PD Midway between center & limbus 30 PD At limbus 45 PD
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: What could be the diagnosis for a child who exhibits below-average mathematical skills despite having a normal IQ and age-appropriate learning abilities and remains unaffected by a year-long private mathematics tutoring?
questions.explanation: The child described is likely experiencing a Specific
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient presents with a down and out right eye with ptosis since birth. What is the nerve palsy? 115?
questions.explanation: • The down and out position of the eye indicates unopposed action of the lateral rectus (CN VI) and superior oblique (CN IV) muscles, suggesting paralysis of the other extraocular muscles supplied by oculomotor nerve (CN III). • Ptosis occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris (also supplied by CN III). • Since it is present since birth, this is likely a congenital oculomotor nerve palsy. Key features of 3rd nerve palsy: 1. Eye position: abducted and depressed ("down and out"). 2. Ptosis due to levator palpebrae weakness. 3. May also have pupil dilation if parasympathetic fibers are involved. 4. Causes: congenital, trauma, aneurysm (PComm), diabetes.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A posterior staphyloma was observed on indirect ophthalmoscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • A posterior staphyloma is an outpouching of the weakened posterior sclera, visible as an ectatic area on fundus examination. • It occurs most commonly in pathological (high) myopia due to progressive elongation of the eyeball, leading to stretching and thinning of the sclera, choroid, and retina at the posterior pole. • This structural change can cause progressive visual decline and predispose to retinal degenerations/detachments. • Axial length usually >26 mm. • Fundus signs: temporal crescent, chorioretinal atrophy, lattice degeneration, and posterior staphyloma. • Etiology: mechanical stretching from axial elongation. • Clinical impact: distorted vision, higher retinal detachment risk. Staphyloma: • It is ectasia of the outer coats of the eye (cornea, sclera, or both) with an incarceration of the uveal tissue. Based on the site affected, staphyloma can be classified as 117 Types of staphyloma Causes Anterior Pseudocornea Intercalary Perforating injuries of the peripheral cornea, marginal corneal ulcer, anterior scleritis, and scleromalacia perforans Ciliary Glaucoma, scleritis, and trauma to the ciliary region Equatorial (approx 14 mm behind the limbus) Scleritis, degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma Posterior Degenerative high axial myopia Treatment: • Treat underlying condition • Local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft • Large staphyloma: Staphylectomy and keratoplasty, or enucleated and replaced with an implant 118
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with a history of dilation & curettage (D&C). Subsequent diagnostic tests reveal all hormone levels, including progesterone and estrogen, to be within the normal range. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • A history of D&C followed by amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea with normal estrogen, progesterone, FSH, and LH levels points toward a uterine (outflow tract) cause. • Asherman syndrome results from intrauterine adhesions or fibrosis following procedures like D&C, leading to secondary amenorrhea despite normal ovarian function. • Since hormone production is normal, the problem lies in the endometrial cavity’s inability to respond due to scarring. Asherman Syndrome: 1. Cause: Trauma to the basal layer of the endometrium (often post-D&C, postpartum curettage, or infection). 119 2. Symptoms: Secondary amenorrhea, infertility, recurrent pregnancy loss. 3. Hormones: Normal ovarian and pituitary function. 4. Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy (gold standard), hysterosalpingography, or saline sonohysterography.
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A female presents with multiple small, pink, umbilicated papules on the face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The description of the skin lesions—multiple small, pink, umbilicated papules—is the classic clinical presentation of Molluscum contagiosum. 120 • Etiology: This is a common, self-limiting viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus. • Lesion Characteristics: The lesions are typically flesh-colored or pink, dome-shaped papules with a characteristic central umbilication (a small indentation or dimple in the center). • Affected Population: It is most common in children, particularly on the face, trunk, and extremities, but can also be seen in sexually active adults in the genital area.

questions.question_text: Identify the given condition and its treatment. 124?
questions.option_a: Staphylococcal scalded syndrome with Inj cephalexin
questions.explanation: 125 The image shows a child with widespread erythema and superficial desquamation (peeling of the skin). This is the hallmark of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS). • Pathophysiology: SSSS is caused by an exfoliative toxin produced by Staphylococcus aureus. This toxin causes the top layer of the epidermis to detach, leading to the characteristic blistering and peeling of the skin, making it look "scalded." • Treatment: As it is a serious systemic infection, the treatment involves intravenous (IV) antistaphylococcal antibiotics to target the underlying bacterial cause. The skin itself is treated with supportive care, similar to that for a burn patient. The provided answer, while mentioning cephalexin (an oral antibiotic), likely refers to the class of antistaphylococcal antibiotics required.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the characteristic lesion of Kaposi sarcoma?
questions.option_b: A white, striated lesion that cannot be scraped off
questions.explanation: The characteristic lesion of Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a raised, purple-red lesion. • Etiology: Kaposi sarcoma is a type of cancer caused by the Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). • Lesion Morphology: The lesions typically begin as flat, reddish-purple macules and progress into raised, palpable plaques and nodules. The color is a result of extravasated red blood cells and hemosiderin deposition. The violaceous (purple-red) appearance is a hallmark of this condition. • Affected Population: It is most commonly seen in patients with compromised immune systems, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.
questions.subject: Dermatology

questions.question_text: A child accidentally took a bottle full of iron tablets. Which of the drugs is used as an antidote for iron poisoning?
questions.explanation: • Acute iron poisoning can occur when a person ingests a toxic amount of iron tablets or other iron-containing substances. • Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that is used as the antidote for Acute iron poisoning. • Mechanism: Binds iron in the body and forms a stable complex that can be excreted through urine and faeces. • Deferoxamine helps to remove excess iron from the body and prevent its toxic effects.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A patient with borderline tuberculoid leprosy presents with the following findings. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction and nerve is enlarged? 132?
questions.explanation: 133 The image shows a patient with a visibly thickened and enlarged nerve in the neck region, which is the greater auricular nerve. The question also mentions that the patient has borderline tuberculoid leprosy and is experiencing a reaction. • Leprosy Reactions: Leprosy reactions are episodes of acute inflammation that occur during the course of the disease. Type 1 (reversal) reactions are a form of delayed-type hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. They are caused by a sudden increase in the cell- mediated immune response to the Mycobacterium leprae bacteria. • Clinical Presentation: These reactions often involve inflammation of existing skin lesions and, most importantly, acute neuritis, which is the painful inflammation and enlargement of peripheral nerves. The greater auricular nerve is a common site for this nerve enlargement. Therefore, the correct pairing is a Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction and the greater auricular nerve.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A child was brought with c/o multiple lesions. O/E multiple vesicular lesions are seen on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing the disease? 134?
questions.explanation: The most likely etiological agent causing multiple vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa in a child is Coxsackie virus. • The classic presentation described—vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa—is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD). • HFMD is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and occasionally other coxsackievirus strains (like A6, A10) and Enterovirus 71. However, Coxsackievirus remains the prototypical agent linked to these clinical findings in children. 135
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: Oral contraceptive pill prevents all except?
questions.explanation: • OCPs have documented protective effects against epithelial ovarian cancer and endometrial cancer by suppressing ovulation and providing a progestin-dominant environment. • Some studies also suggest a modest protective effect against colorectal cancer. • However, long-term OCP use is associated with a slightly increased risk of cervical cancer due to hormonal influence on HPV persistence. OCP cancer protection profile: 1. Protective against: Epithelial ovarian, endometrial, and possibly colorectal cancer. 2. No protection / Slightly increased risk: Cervical and breast cancer (with prolonged use). 3. Mechanism: Reduced ovulation, decreased endometrial proliferation, hormonal modulation of certain tissues.

questions.question_text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic reporting recurrent skin lesions as seen on the image. He describes that these lesions emerge within hours each time he takes NSAIDs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Fixed drug eruption features: • Recurrent lesions that appear within hours of taking NSAIDs • well-demarcated, erythematous patch • They recur at the same site upon re-exposure to the offending drug • Common triggers: NSAIDs, sulfa drugs, antibiotics • They heal with hyperpigmentation
questions.subject: Dermatology

questions.question_text: What is the importance of the following manoeuvre?
questions.option_a: To protect from tearing of the perineum
questions.option_b: To pull the baby out faster
questions.option_c: To facilitate controlled extension of the fetal head
questions.option_d: To rotate the shoulders during delivery
questions.explanation: This image depicts the classic Ritgen/perineal support manoeuvre — one hand supports the fetal head while the other applies controlled counter-pressure through the perineum to the fetal chin/posterior neck. Its primary purpose is to regulate the speed and angle of head extension during crowning, thereby reducing sudden expulsion and minimizing perineal and neonatal trauma. The main aim is to protect the perineum from sudden overstretching and tearing. • Performed at crowning to control the final extension of the fetal head rather than hasten delivery. • One hand supports the head externally; the other applies upward/posterior counter- pressure through the perineum on the fetal chin/posterior neck to moderate extension. • Benefits: slows uncontrolled delivery of the head, decreases downward force on the perineum, reduces risk/severity of perineal tears and neonatal scalp trauma. • Not intended to speed delivery; it is a protective, controlled manoeuvre. • Requires careful, gentle technique — excessive force can harm mother or baby.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient presents with severe headache. A CT scan of the brain reveals hypodense areas in the right basal region, marked as ‘X’. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 148?
questions.explanation: • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) typically presents with a sudden, severe “thunderclap” headache, often described as the worst headache of life. • On non-contrast CT, acute blood in the subarachnoid space appears hyperdense (bright), especially in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure. • When the blood fills the basal cisterns, the appearance is classically described as the “Star of Death” sign. • Hypodense areas may develop later due to ischemia or edema. • The most common cause is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm at the circle of Willis. 150
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: The following radiological image was taken to assess the urinary tract. Identify the investigation shown below. 153?
questions.explanation: • An Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) is a contrast-based radiological investigation used to visualize the anatomy and function of the urinary tract, including kidneys, ureters, and bladder. • Iodinated contrast is injected intravenously, filtered by the kidneys, and excreted into the collecting system, allowing sequential imaging to assess drainage and detect structural abnormalities such as calculi, strictures, or masses. • The image typically shows contrast-filled calyces, pelvis, ureters, and bladder in a single study. 155
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Identify the tarsal bone marked by the arrow in the given X-ray of the right foot. 157?
questions.explanation: • The navicular bone is a wedge-shaped tarsal bone located medially in the midfoot. 158 • It articulates proximally with the talus, distally with the three cuneiform bones, and laterally with the cuboid. • On a dorsoplantar (DP) or oblique foot X-ray, it is seen on the medial side between the talus and cuneiforms. • The arrow in this case points to its distinctive position and shape.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Identify the investigation shown in the image:
questions.explanation: • The image shows the two standard mammographic views used in breast cancer screening and diagnosis: • Mediolateral Oblique (MLO) view – includes the upper outer quadrant and pectoralis muscle. • Craniocaudal (CC) view – top-down view of the breast. • Mammography is performed using low-dose X-rays with breast compression to improve resolution and detect abnormalities such as masses, architectural distortions, and microcalcifications.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Identify the condition shown in the chest X-ray of a sand mine worker. What is the most likely diagnosis? 161?
questions.explanation: • Silicosis is a pneumoconiosis caused by chronic inhalation of crystalline silica dust, common in occupations such as sand mining, stone cutting, and quarrying. • Inhaled silica particles are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, leading to their death and the release of inflammatory mediators, which stimulate fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition, resulting in progressive pulmonary fibrosis. • On chest X-ray, the hallmark finding is "eggshell calcification" — a thin rim of calcification along the periphery of enlarged hilar lymph nodes. • Parenchymal findings often include small rounded opacities (upper lobe–predominant nodules) that may coalesce over time, forming progressive massive fibrosis.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: What does a linear accelerator (LINAC) produce in radiation therapy?
questions.explanation: • A linear accelerator (LINAC) is the most commonly used device in external beam radiation therapy. • It accelerates electrons to high energies using microwave technology. • These high-energy electrons can be used directly to treat superficial tumors, or they can be directed onto a metal target to produce high-energy X-rays (photons) for treating deep- seated tumors. • This allows precise targeting of malignant tissue while sparing surrounding normal structures. LINAC Machine: 164 • The overhead X-ray tube emits X-ray beams to the patient. • It also has a movable arm that can be mobilized around the patient. • The treatment head contains significant shielding material to minimize leakage radiation.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Fetal anaemia is primarily determined by Doppler assessment of which artery?
questions.explanation: Fetal anemia is best assessed by Doppler measurement of the peak systolic velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA). • In fetal anemia, the blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity is reduced, so the fetus compensates with increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity. • This leads to faster blood flow in the MCA, which can be picked up on Doppler. • An MCA-PSV > 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age strongly suggests moderate-to-severe anemia. • Other vessels like the umbilical artery or ductus venosus are more useful for assessing placental insufficiency or cardiac compromise, not specifically anemia. • Uterine artery Doppler is about maternal blood flow to the placenta, not fetal hemoglobin status.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painful vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On USG, a well-formed gestation ring with central echoes from the embryo indicates a healthy fetus, and there is observation of fetal cardiac motion. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • The presence of vaginal bleeding in the first trimester along with a healthy fetus observed on USG, indicated by a well-formed gestation ring, central echoes from the embryo, and fetal cardiac motion, is characteristic of a threatened abortion. The cervix is typically closed in such cases, and the pregnancy may still continue successfully with appropriate care. Clinical Classification of Spontaneous Abortion Characteristic Threatened Inevitable (Option A) Incomplete (Option C) Complete (Option D) Missed Presentation Vaginal bleeding in < 20 weeks Vaginal bleeding or membrane rupture in < 20 weeks Expulsion of some products of conception Cervix closed after conception product expulsion No symptoms Cervical OS Closed Open Open Closed Closed USG Findings Normal intrauterine pregnancy with fetal heartbeat Dilated cervix with sac low in the uterine cavity or cervical canal Empty gestational sac or retained products of conception Empty uterus with no retained products of conception Absence of fetal heartbeat and/or absent growth of gestational sac Management Rest, monitor fetal viability Prepare for inevitable expulsion Evacuation of retained products of conception Observation Surgical evacuation or expectant management
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient develops profuse uterine bleeding after a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). Oxytocin has already been administered but bleeding continues. What is the 1st step of management?
questions.explanation: • After oxytocin failure in atonic postpartum hemorrhage, the next first-line mechanical measure is to tamponade the bleeding surface with a balloon catheter (e.g., Bakri balloon). • This is a quick, fertility-preserving step that allows time for stabilization and is less invasive than surgical interventions. • Stepwise approach to atonic PPH: uterotonics → mechanical tamponade → surgical vessel ligation → hysterectomy. Intrauterine balloon tamponade is often considered the first-line for managing persistent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony when initial treatments with uterotonics are ineffective. It involves placing a balloon within the uterus and inflating it to apply pressure and reduce bleeding. This method is less invasive compared to other surgical options and can effectively control bleeding in many cases. Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices 171 Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices are typically used for uterine atony unresponsive to medications and massage, often as a step before more invasive surgery. Contraindications: • Allergy to any device component or packing material. • Retained Products: Should not replace evacuation of retained pregnancy tissue. Intrauterine Balloon Tamponade (Option A) Types: Multiple balloon catheters used for intrauterine tamponade. Sengstaken tube. Examples: • Bakri, BT-cath, ebb complete; • Foley's catheter (can hold up to 100 ml of fluids) • Condoms Mechanism: Hydrostatic pressure applied inward to outward against uterine wall to reduce blood flow and facilitate clotting. Vacuum-Induced Tamponade Mechanism: Applies low-level intrauterine vacuum (70-90 mmHg) to evacuate blood and clot, facilitating uterine contractions. Intrauterine Packing Plain Gauze/Laparotomy Sponges: Traditional packing method; Replaced by balloon tamponade due to its effectiveness. Hemostatic Gauze: Gauze with additional hemostatic mechanisms Compressed Mini-Sponges: Novel device. Uterine or hypogastric artery embolization (Option B ruled out) Candidates Suitable for patients with persistent, slow, excessive bleeding. Hemodynamically stable and unresponsive to less invasive treatments. Procedure Performed by an interventional vascular specialist using diagnostic angiography. Gelfoam is the preferred embolizing agent (temporary occlusion: 2-6 weeks). 172 Uterine Devascularization • Progressive ligation of more proximal arteries to control uterine bleeding. • May require a hysterectomy if unsuccessful. Bilateral Uterine Artery Ligation • Ligation of the ascending branch of each uterine artery at the lateral border of the uterus. Ovarian and Uterine Artery Anastomosis Ligation • Ligation of the anastomosis between ovarian and uterine arteries on each side. Bilateral Internal Iliac Artery Ligation • Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery on one or both sides to reduce blood flow to the uterus. Uterine Compression Sutures Techniques involving sutures to compress the uterus and control bleeding. 173 B-Lynch Suture • Envelops and compresses the uterus; most common technique. • Effective for uterine atony, simple to learn, safe • May increase risk of Asherman syndrome. Hayman Technique • Uses two to four vertical compression sutures without hysterotomy. • Suitable after vaginal birth. Pereira Technique • Involves transverse and longitudinal sutures around the uterus without entering the uterine cavity. • Requires care to avoid damaging blood vessels, ureters, and fallopian tubes; manual compression before tying sutures. Cho Technique • Utilizes multiple squares or rectangles for uterine compression. Uterine Artery Embolization Minimally invasive procedure using interventional radiology to block blood flow by injecting embolic material. Hysterectomy (Option D ruled out) It is a last resort for PPH, it may be necessary in cases where other measures have failed or when there are compelling reasons to remove the uterus. Internal iliac artery ligation (Option C): Surgical vessel ligation is more invasive, technically demanding, and reserved for refractory cases when tamponade and less invasive measures fail. 174 Hysterectomy (Option D): Definitive life-saving step for uncontrolled bleeding when fertility preservation is not possible, but it is a last resort after failure of medical and conservative surgical measures.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: In a study, an investigator compared the mean blood pressure and standard deviation between two independent groups. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical test to assess the significance of the difference between the two means?
questions.explanation: • The question describes two independent groups where the investigator is comparing mean blood pressure values. The correct statistical test for comparing the means of two independent samples is the unpaired (independent samples) t-test. Unpaired t-test: A parametric test used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine if the difference is statistically significant. Assumptions: • The two groups are independent. • The data is continuous and approximately normally distributed. • The variances of the two groups are equal (homogeneity of variance). Advantages: Simple to apply when assumptions are met. Limitations: Not suitable for non-normal or categorical data; use non-parametric alternatives like Mann–Whitney U test if assumptions fail. 175 No. of Groups Relatedness of Samples Test Used 2 Independent Unpaired t-test 2 Paired/Matched Paired t-test >2 Independent ANOVA Paired t-test (Option A): Used for matched pairs or before–after measurements in the same group; not for independent groups. Chi-square test (Option C): Used for association between categorical variables; not for comparing means of continuous data. ANOVA (Option D): Used for comparing means among more than two independent groups.

questions.question_text: Patient has variable deceleration. What does that indicate?
questions.explanation: • Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate with variable timing and shape, often “V” or “W” shaped on CTG. • They are most commonly caused by transient umbilical cord compression, leading to sudden changes in fetal circulation. Variable decelerations: 176 • Pathophysiology: Cord compression → brief fetal hypoxia → reflex vagal stimulation → transient FHR drop. • Variable decelerations differ from early decelerations (head compression) and late decelerations (placental insufficiency). • Management: Maternal position change, amnioinfusion if persistent, treat underlying cause. • Severity depends on depth, duration, and frequency of decelerations. Non-Stress Test (NST): • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements. • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy. • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements. Indications for NST: • Post-term pregnancy. • Decreased fetal movements. • High-risk pregnancies (e.g., hypertension, diabetes). • History of previous pregnancy complications. • Suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Primary parameters evaluated during an NST: 1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR) 2. Beat-to-beat Variability: • Normal: 110-160 bpm • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm. • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm. • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next. • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal). 3. Accelerations • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline. • Reactive NST: • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period. • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks). • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period. 4. Decelerations 177 Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline. • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions. • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression. • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. 5. Fetal Movements • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress. Interpretation: • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function. • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

questions.question_text: In a case of face presentation during labor, which diameter is seen?
questions.explanation: • In face presentation, the fetal head is fully extended, and the presenting part is the face with the chin (mentum) as the leading point. • The submentobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is engaged when mentum is anterior, allowing vaginal delivery. • Face presentation occurs due to factors like multiparity, cephalopelvic disproportion, or neck masses. • Prognosis depends on chin position: mentum anterior may deliver vaginally; mentum posterior usually requires cesarean. Face presentation of the fetus • Attitude: flexed limbs with extended neck • Lie: Longitudinal • Presenting part: Face • Risk factors • Maternal factors • Multiparity • Lateral obliquity of the uterus 179 • Contracted pelvis • Pelvic tumors • Fetal factors • Ananecepathy • Congenital goiter • Congenital bronchocele • Increased tone of extensor neck muscles • The engaging diameter depends on the extension of the neck • Fully extended head - Submentobregmatic diameter 9.5 cm • Partially extended head - Submentovertical 11.5 cm • Delivery of the head is achieved by flexion rather than extension like normal vaginal delivery • Brow presentation can also convert to face presentation as it is unstable. 180

questions.question_text: Secondary prevention is most useful in the early detection and treatment of which of the following cancers?
questions.explanation: • Secondary prevention involves early detection and prompt treatment to halt disease progression. It is most effective for cancers with a long preclinical phase and a reliable screening test. Cervical cancer fits these criteria - it has a well-defined precancerous stage (CIN), and screening via Pap smear or HPV testing can detect lesions early, allowing for effective intervention. • Pancreatic, ovarian, and glioblastoma cancers typically lack effective population-based screening methods and have short asymptomatic phases, making secondary prevention less useful. Screening methods: • Pap smear – Cytological detection of abnormal cervical cells. • HPV DNA testing – Detects high-risk HPV strains. • Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) – Low-cost alternative in low-resource settings. • WHO recommendation: Screen women aged 30–49 years at least once, preferably every 3–5 years. • Early treatment of CIN significantly reduces invasive cervical cancer incidence. Levels of Prevention in Cancer: 182 Level Goal Example in Cervical Cancer Primary Prevent onset HPV vaccination Secondary Early detection & prompt treatment Pap smear screening Tertiary Reduce complications & recurrence Radiotherapy, chemotherapy for invasive CA Pancreatic cancer (Option A): Usually diagnosed late due to lack of early symptoms and reliable screening tests; secondary prevention is limited. Ovarian cancer (Option B): No cost-effective, sensitive population-level screening; early detection remains challenging. Glioblastoma (Option C): Highly aggressive, short preclinical phase, and no screening method for asymptomatic individuals.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: What is the best diagnostic test for evaluating endometrial pathology?
questions.explanation: • Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity and targeted sampling of suspicious areas, making it the gold standard for diagnosing focal and diffuse endometrial lesions. 183 • It improves diagnostic accuracy, especially for polyps, submucosal fibroids, and localized carcinoma. • Direct visualization prevents sampling errors common in blind methods like D&C or Pipelle. • Allows simultaneous diagnosis and treatment (e.g., polyp removal). • Particularly useful in abnormal uterine bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding, and inconclusive imaging results.
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: In which of the following conditions is the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) absolutely contraindicated?
questions.explanation: 184 • Among the listed options, the absolute contraindication for IUCD use is active, untreated HIV infection with immunosuppression and high risk of pelvic infections. In such cases, IUCD insertion can increase the chance of ascending infection and sepsis. • Controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus are not absolute contraindications- though they may be considered for caution depending on the patient’s overall health and choice of contraceptive method. • Conditions where IUCD use poses unacceptable health risks, as per WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) Category 4. Absolute Contraindications: • Current PID or purulent cervicitis. • Unexplained vaginal bleeding. • Known or suspected pregnancy. • Cervical or endometrial cancer. • Distorted uterine cavity (e.g., large fibroids). • Active, untreated HIV infection with high risk of opportunistic infections. Safer Alternatives in HIV: • Condoms (dual protection). • Hormonal methods (with drug–drug interaction checks). Condition Category Remarks Active HIV with AIDS symptoms 4 Absolute contraindication HIV on ART, clinically stable 2 Benefits outweigh risks Unexplained vaginal bleeding 4 Insert only after evaluation Current PID 4 Treat infection before IUCD insertion Hypertension (Option A) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs can be used safely. Hyperlipidemia (Option B) – No restriction for IUCD use. Diabetes mellitus (Option C) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs are generally safe unless there is severe infection risk or uncontrolled complications.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Which of the following occupational exposures is most strongly associated with the development of mesothelioma?
questions.explanation: • Mesothelioma, particularly malignant pleural mesothelioma, is strongly linked to occupational exposure to asbestos fibers. Asbestos can be inhaled during mining, manufacturing, or use in construction materials, and the fibers lodge in the pleura, 187 causing chronic inflammation and carcinogenesis. The latency period is typically very long (20–40 years). Asbestos: Group of naturally occurring silicate minerals with heat resistance and insulating properties. • Types: Chrysotile (serpentine), amosite, crocidolite (amphiboles — more carcinogenic). • Health effects: • Asbestosis (interstitial lung fibrosis). • Lung carcinoma (Most common) • Malignant mesothelioma (pleura, peritoneum, pericardium): Most specific. • Benign pleural plaques and effusions. • Pathogenesis: Inhaled fibers → persistent pleural irritation → chronic inflammation & DNA damage → malignant transformation. Silicosis Sandstone industry, granite industry. Pottery industry, ceramic industry, gold, mica and steel industry, glass factory, building and construction work, rock mining Asbestosis Cement factory, fireproof industry, construction, airplanes Anthracosis Coalmines Baritosis Photography, printing, barium diagnostic works Byssinosis Textile industry Bagassosis Cane sugar factories, paper and cardboard factories-Fibrous residue from bagasse used in paper factories Farmer's lung Agricultural industry Siderosis Iron mines, Iron, and steel industry • Occupations at risk: Shipyard workers, construction, insulation manufacturing, asbestos mining. Silica dust (Option B): Causes silicosis and increases risk of TB and lung cancer, but not strongly linked to mesothelioma. Cotton dust (Option C): Associated with byssinosis (“Monday fever”); no direct link to mesothelioma. Coal dust (Option D): Causes coal workers’ pneumoconiosis (“black lung disease”); no direct link to mesothelioma. 188

questions.question_text: A 12-year-old female presents with Tanner stage II breast development and white, odorless vaginal discharge. This discharge is most likely due to the action of which hormone?
questions.explanation: • In early puberty, rising estrogen levels stimulate the vaginal epithelium to proliferate and produce glycogen. • This glycogen supports lactobacilli growth, leading to acidic pH and physiological leukorrhea — a normal, odorless, white discharge before menarche. • Tanner stage II = breast budding; estrogen effects become evident on genital mucosa. • Discharge is not associated with infection, pain, or foul smell — reassurance is key.
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A 36-year-old P2L2 patient diagnosed with severe endometriosis shows pelvic adhesions on laparoscopy. She has undergone tubal ligation and adhesiolysis previously. What is the most appropriate management during laparoscopy?
questions.explanation: • The patient has recurrent severe endometriosis with pelvic adhesions despite prior surgery. She has completed her family (P2L2, tubal ligation), so fertility preservation is not required. • Definitive surgical option: In women with no fertility desire, total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the gold standard for recurrent/severe endometriosis to remove both the uterus and the main source of estrogen (ovaries). • Why this works: • Removes disease and adhesions. • Prevents recurrence by eliminating estrogen production. • Addresses pain and progression risk. Management of Endometriosis: 190 COC-Combined oral contraceptives CC-Clomiphene citrate IUI-Intrauterine insemination • Medical management of endometriosis includes: Mild pain Moderate to severe pain • NSAIDs & OCPs (First line) • Progesterone (Second line) • Continuous GnRH agonist (Third line) • Continuous GnRH agonist / GnRH antagonist (First line) • Laparoscopy, if medical management fails. • Laparoscopy: Investigation of choice in endometriosis, used for diagnosing, staging, and therapeutic management of pain • Other Drugs useful in endometriosis are: • Aromatase inhibitors (Letrozole) 191 • Progesterone receptor modulators (Mifepristone, Ulipristal) • GnRH Antagonists (Injection: Ganirelix and cetrirelix) • Tab Danazol (400 mg/day)
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A woman presents with a breast lump, associated with skin dimpling and nipple retraction. What is the most likely anatomical structure responsible for the skin dimpling? 192?
questions.explanation: Skin dimpling and nipple retraction in breast carcinoma occur due to fibrosis and contraction of the suspensory (Cooper’s) ligaments. • These fibrous bands extend from the dermis of the skin to the pectoral fascia through the breast tissue. • When a malignant lesion infiltrates these ligaments, it shortens them, pulling the skin inward → dimpling or puckering. • Similarly, infiltration of lactiferous ducts can cause nipple retraction.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A long-term study found that individuals who had high blood pressure (BP) during childhood continued to have high BP in adulthood, and those with low BP in childhood tended to maintain lower levels later in life. Which of the following epidemiological concepts does this pattern best represent? 193?
questions.explanation: • Tracking of blood pressure refers to the tendency of an individual’s relative position within a distribution (e.g., BP levels) to remain consistent over time. In other words, those with high BP in childhood often remain at the higher end of BP in adulthood, and those with low BP tend to stay lower - even though absolute values may change with age. • This concept is important in predicting adult disease risk from childhood measurements and emphasizes early preventive measures. Rule of halves (Option A): Refers to the observation in hypertension that only half of all hypertensives are diagnosed, half of them are treated, and half of those treated achieve control. It does not describe lifelong consistency in BP levels. Regression to the mean (Option B): This is a statistical phenomenon where extreme values tend to move closer to the average on subsequent measurements. It does not imply consistent rank ordering over time. Cohort effect (Option D): Refers to differences in health outcomes between groups born in different time periods due to shared exposures or experiences. It is unrelated to the persistence of BP levels within the same individuals.
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: In the image shown, identify the function of the marked structure on the endotracheal tube. 194 195?
questions.option_c: Prevention of air leakage and aspiration
questions.option_d: Suctioning of lower respiratory tract secretions
questions.explanation: • The marked structure is the inflatable cuff of the endotracheal tube. When inflated, it creates a seal between the tube and the tracheal wall. • This seal prevents air leakage during positive pressure ventilation, ensuring efficient delivery of tidal volume. • It also reduces the risk of aspiration by blocking secretions from the upper airway from entering the lungs. • Overinflation can cause tracheal mucosal injury; thus, cuff pressure should be maintained between 20–30 cm H₂O. 196
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: What is the embryological cause of this anomaly? 197?
questions.option_c: Failure of fusion of metanephric duct
questions.explanation: A unicornuate uterus with a rudimentary horn occurs due to failure of one paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct to develop completely and failure of fusion with the contralateral duct. Unicornuate uterus caused by the failure of one Mullerian duct to develop, results in a single uterine cavity and fallopian tube, leading to poor pregnancy outcomes. It appears smaller and curved to one side (banana shaped), unlike a bicornuate uterus (heart-shaped). Representation HSG of Unicornuate uterus 199
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: After an initial serum β-hCG test in a patient with suspected pregnancy, when should the repeat β-hCG level ideally be checked to assess viability or progression? 201?
questions.explanation: Β-hCG levels are checked ideally after 48 hours.
