In a viable intrauterine pregnancy, the serum β-hCG level should rise by at least ~66% over 48 hours in early gestation. • This doubling time is a key marker of normal trophoblastic function. • Slower rises can indicate ectopic pregnancy or failing pregnancy, while falling levels suggest miscarriage. • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman with a short cervix undergoes a cervical cerclage procedure. What is the most likely procedure performed? 202?
questions.explanation: The modified Shirodkar cerclage is a variation of the original Shirodkar procedure, performed for cervical insufficiency in pregnant women with a short or incompetent cervix. • In the Shirodkar technique, a suture (usually Mersilene tape) is placed at the level of the internal os after dissecting the bladder and rectum off the cervix, allowing a higher placement than the McDonald’s method. • The modified version often uses less extensive bladder dissection or different suture materials, making it technically simpler but still allowing high placement for better cervical support. • This technique is especially indicated when a high and strong cerclage is desired, such as in women with significant cervical shortening early in pregnancy. Cerclage placement in cervical insufficiency: Transvaginal route: • More commonly preferred than the transabdominal route due to the ease of the procedure • It is an outpatient procedure and local anaesthesia is preferred. • McDonald’s cerclage: • More commonly used than Shirodkar’s procedure • A purse-string suture with a non-absorbable suture is applied at the cervicovaginal junction. • Shirodkar’s cerclage: • The cervicovaginal junction is cut and continuous, non-absorbable sutures (using Mersilene tape) are applied at the internal os. 204 • Wurm’s stitch (or rescue stitch) is used when a woman presents with cervical dilatation and bulging fetal membranes. Transabdominal route: • It is done only when vaginal cerclage fails or severe cervical anatomical defects are present. • Performed less commonly than vaginal cerclage. • The suture is placed abdominally at the uterine isthmus • The cerclage is left until childbearing is completed and therefore cesarean delivery is required In both transvaginal and transabdominal procedures, after the placement of cerclage, the patient should be started on progesterone up to 36 weeks+6 days of gestation. 205

questions.question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes for emergency contraception within 8 hours after engaging in sexual intercourse. She expresses a preference for a single pill rather than multiple pills. What would be your recommendation in this situation? 206?
questions.explanation: • Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the most appropriate option for emergency contraception in this case. It is a progestin-only pill and is highly effective when taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. Since the patient prefers a single-pill regimen, this option is ideal. It does not contain estrogen, avoiding estrogen-related side effects such as nausea or vomiting. Emergency Contraceptive Methods Method Drug(s) Dosage Schedule Time Period for Use Oral Contraceptive Pills Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg (single dose) 1 dose Within 72 hours after unprotected sex Combination Pills (Yuzpe Regimen) Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl estradiol Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg + Ethinyl estradiol 0.1 mg per tablet 2 doses, 12 hours apart Within 72 hours after unprotected sex Levonorgestrel Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg per tablet (take 2 tablets) 1 dose Within 72 hours after unprotected sex Ulipristal Acetate Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (single dose) 1 dose Within 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex 207 Copper IUD (Best) Copper IUD N/A (inserted by healthcare provider) Insertion by a healthcare provider Within 5 days after unprotected sex Mifepristone (Less Common) Mifepristone (in combination with misoprostol) 200 mg (single dose) 1 dose Within 72 hours after unprotected sex
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A patient presents with obstructed labor, and on abdominal examination, a groove or band is palpable across the uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A Bandl’s ring is an abnormal pathological retraction ring that forms between the upper contractile segment and the lower thin, stretched segment of the uterus during obstructed labor. • On abdominal examination, it presents as a palpable transverse or oblique groove running across the uterus. It is associated with prolonged obstructed labor and is a sign of impending uterine rupture if not managed promptly. Bandl's Ring Schroeder's Ring (Option B) Definition An abnormal ring of constriction that forms in the uterus, typically between the lower and upper uterine segments. It causes an extreme form of uterine atony A pathological ring of constriction that can occur in any stage of labor, resulting from oxytocin overuse, and may lead to uterine rupture Cause Prolonged second stage of labor Oxytocin overuse, or misuse of uterine stimulants Stage of Labor Second stage of labor Any stage of labor Management Cesarean section Discontinuation of oxytocin, relaxation of the uterus (using tocolytics), and possible cesarean section depending on severity Constriction ring(Option A): Localized spasm of a small portion of the myometrium, usually around the fetus; not felt as a transverse groove across the abdomen. Contraction ring(Option C): Normal physiological junction between upper and lower uterine segments; not pathologically elevated or palpable in normal labor.
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: The waveform shown in the image represents which of the following physiological parameters? 209?
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 2-month-old male infant presents with a scrotal swelling that has been present since birth. Now, the swelling has become suddenly painful, red, and irreducible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The infant has a congenital scrotal swelling (likely due to a hernia present since birth) that has become painful, red, and irreducible, suggesting that bowel has entered the hernial sac and is now compromised with vascular obstruction - this is the definition of a strangulated inguinal hernia. • This is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent bowel necrosis. Strangulated Hernia: • A strangulated hernia occurs when a portion of tissue or intestine protrudes through a weakened area in the abdominal wall and becomes trapped. • The trapped segment loses its blood supply, leading to tissue ischemia (lack of blood flow) and potential tissue death if not promptly treated. 212 Clinical Features: • Irreducibility: The hernia cannot be pushed back. • Signs of Intestinal Obstruction: Colicky pain, bilious vomiting, absence of faeces and flatus. • History: Sudden onset of pain at the hernia site, followed by generalised abdominal pain. • Physical Examination Findings: Tense, extremely tender hernia with reddish or bluish skin discolouration and no cough impulse. • Diagnosis isprimarily based on clinical examination and physical findings. Treatment: • Initial Resuscitation: • Administer intravenous (IV) fluids. • Provide IV antibiotics. • Perform nasogastric aspiration. • Insert Foley's catheter. • Surgical intervention is done only after Initial Resuscitation. Surgical management Algorithm: 213 Mesh Usage: • Synthetic mesh is contraindicated due to the increased risk of infection. • If a mesh is necessary, bioprosthetic or absorbable mesh is preferred. Acute epididymo-orchitis (Option A): Presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and erythema but is rare in this age group and usually associated with urinary tract infection; swelling is not from birth. Testicular torsion (Option B): Sudden severe scrotal pain and swelling, but not present since birth; does not involve an irreducible groin/scrotal mass. Incarcerated inguinal hernia (Option D): Irreducible hernia without compromised blood supply; no redness or severe tenderness — if blood supply is compromised, it becomes strangulated.
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: A patient underwent split-thickness skin grafting for a burn injury on the arm. On post-operative day 6, he develops stiffness of the arm during physiotherapy. What is the most appropriate next step in management? 214?
questions.option_b: Passive extension of the joint under direct visualization of the graft
questions.option_d: Remove the graft and regraft the area
questions.explanation: By post-operative day 6, the split-thickness skin graft is in the fibrovascular ingrowth and early maturation phase. If stiffness develops during physiotherapy, the safest approach is to perform passive extension under direct visualization to ensure that the graft is not disrupted. • This allows assessment of graft integrity and prevention of shearing forces that could cause partial or total graft loss. Surgical excision of contracture (Option A): Contracture release is indicated in long-standing, mature scars, not within the first week after grafting. Continue physiotherapy without intervention (Option C): Risk of damaging the graft if stiffness is due to early adhesion or improper graft placement; should first ensure graft safety. Remove the graft and regraft the area (Option D): Not necessary unless the graft has failed; stiffness alone at day 6 is not an indication for regrafting.
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman is being assessed for induction of labor. On vaginal examination: Cervical dilation: 2 cm, Effacement: 20%, Cervical consistency: Soft, Position: Midline, Station: –2. What is the modified Bishop Score? 215?
questions.explanation: A score ≤5 means the cervix is unfavorable for induction, and cervical ripening is needed before oxytocin induction. • Cervical dilation (2 cm) = 1 point • Effacement (20%) = 1 point • Cervical consistency (Soft) = 2 points • Position (Midline) = 1 point • Station (–2) = 0 points MODIFIED BISHOP score is calculated as: Criteria 0 Points 1 Point 2 Points 3 Points Dilation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 ≥5 Cervical length >4 cm 3-4 cm 1-2 cm <1cm Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2 Consistency Firm Medium Soft Position Posterior Mid position Anterior Effacement 0-30 40-50 60-70 80 216
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a recommended treatment for esophageal varices?
questions.explanation: • Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is the first-line treatment for acute bleeding esophageal varices and for secondary prophylaxis. It works by mechanically strangulating varices, leading to thrombosis and obliteration, with fewer complications than sclerotherapy. Management of Esophageal varices: • The immediate priority in managing variceal bleeding is stabilizing the patient's condition. This involves the airway, breathing, and circulation. • Establishing intravenous access with large-bore cannulae allows for rapid fluid resuscitation, ideally with blood transfusions, to restore circulatory volume and address hypotension. 217 Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (Option B): Used as a salvage therapy when bleeding persists or recurs despite optimal endoscopic and pharmacologic management. Intravenous labetalol (Option C): Not used; nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol or nadolol are used for prophylaxis, not labetalol. Oral amoxicillin (Option D): Antibiotics (usually ceftriaxone) are given prophylactically in variceal bleeding, but amoxicillin is not the standard choice and does not control bleeding.

questions.question_text: During the management of shoulder dystocia in childbirth, which of the following is the earliest and first maneuver typically attempted?
questions.explanation: The McRoberts maneuver is the first and earliest step in managing shoulder dystocia. It involves hyperflexing the mother’s thighs onto her abdomen, which straightens the lumbosacral angle, rotates the pelvis, and frees the impacted anterior shoulder behind the pubic symphysis. • Sequence of events in Shoulder dystocia: • Help – call for extra assistance → Evaluate for episiotomy → McRoberts maneuver (first maneuver) → Suprapubic pressure → Rubin maneuver → Woods corkscrew maneuver → Delivery of posterior arm → Roll patient to all fours (Gaskin maneuver) → If unsuccessful, consider cleidotomy, Zavanelli maneuver, or symphysiotomy as last resorts.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: OCPs can be given in which of the following conditions? 219?
questions.explanation: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are generally contraindicated in certain high-risk conditions due to their estrogen component, which can increase the risk of thromboembolic and cardiovascular events. • In HIV, OCPs can still be used safely, though drug interactions with some antiretroviral drugs may occur, but HIV itself is not a contraindication. Complications associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) Complication Details Minor Complications Nausea, Vomiting, Headache Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolves over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent. Mastalgia Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles. Weight Gain Minimal long-term weight gain Menstrual Abnormalities Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use. Libido Changes in sexual desire can occur Leukorrhea Increase in vaginal discharge 220 Major Complications Depression Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations Hypertension Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment. Vascular Complications • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking. (Option A) • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction Cholestatic Jaundice Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs. Neoplasia Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

questions.question_text: Identify the types of sutures? 221?
questions.explanation: The image depicts Simple interrupted suture. Suturing Techniques: 222 Technique Image Description Suture Placement Interrupted Sutures Needle inserted at 90-degree angle, passed through both sides of wound Distance = tissue thickness, each suture twice as far from edge as previous Continuous Sutures Continuous placement after initial start, with suture appearing diagonal Maintain proper tension, secure end with Aberdeen knot or final suture loop Mattress Sutures (Option A & B) Vertical or horizontal, used to align wound edges Passed through both sides, either vertically or horizontally Subcuticular Sutures (Option C) Aesthetic closure with small bites of tissue, edges easily approximated Absorbable or non-absorbable, secured with collar and bead or buried knot

questions.question_text: A woman sustains a perineal tear during delivery. Examination reveals that less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is involved. Based on the classification system, what is the most appropriate description of this injury? 223?
questions.explanation: Degrees of perineal tear Description First Degree Injury to perineal skin only. Second Degree (Option A) Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter. Third Degree Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal): • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn (Option C) • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn (Option B) • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn Fourth degree (Option D) Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium. 224 Risk factors of perineal tear: • Big baby(weight ≥ 3 kg). • Nulliparity. • Outlet contraction with narrow pubic arch. • Shoulder dystocia. • Forceps delivery. • Scar in the perineum (perineorrhaphy, episiotomy). • Face to pubis delivery. • Midline episiotomy. • Precipitate labour. 225
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: Identify the type of ulcer?
questions.explanation: • An ulcer in the gaiter area (medial aspect of the lower leg, above the ankle) is most commonly due to chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are typically shallow, have irregular margins, and are associated with skin changes like hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and edema. The type of ulcer edges seen in various clinical conditions is listed in the table below: Type of edges Clinical conditions Details Sloping edge • Healing ulcer • Varicose ulcer Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue) Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation) Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue) Undermined edge • Tubercular ulcers Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue) whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards Punched out edge • Arterial / Ischemic ulcers • Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer • Trophic ulcer Due to endarteritis Raised and beaded edge Rolled out / Pearly white edge • Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma • Beads are due to proliferating active cells • Pearly white in appearance Everted edge / Rolled out edge • Squamous cell carcinoma Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin 227 Arterial ulcer (Option A): Usually found on toes, dorsum of foot, or pressure points; have “punched-out” edges, very painful, and are associated with diminished pulses. Diabetic ulcer (Option C): Typically over pressure points of the foot (metatarsal heads, heel) due to neuropathy; often painless. Neuropathic ulcer (Option D): Similar to diabetic ulcers but specifically due to peripheral neuropathy from any cause; usually over pressure-bearing areas.

questions.question_text: A 46 year male had a tumor in his left lobe of liver, so left sided hemi hepatectomy was planned, which of the following lobes of liver will be resected in this procedure? 228?
questions.explanation: Liver lobes are defined surgically based on Couinaud's segmental anatomy (functional anatomy), which follows the portal vein and hepatic vein divisions rather than the classical anatomical right/left lobes. In a left hemihepatectomy, the left functional lobe is removed. • This includes segments II, III, and IV: • Segment II & III: Left lateral section • Segment IV: Left medial section Segments of the liver Segment VIII: • The superior part of the right anterior sector. • Drainage: Drains into the right and middle hepatic veins. Segment I (Caudate Lobe): • Posterior to segment IV, straddles the inferior vena cava. • Drainage: Multiple small veins drain directly into the inferior vena cava. • Bile Ducts: Related to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. Segment II: • Posterolateral to the left portal fissure. • Drainage: Drains into the left hepatic vein; rarely directly into the inferior vena cava. 229 Segment VII: • The superior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right hepatic vein. • Drainage: Primarily into the right hepatic vein; occasionally directly into the inferior vena cava. Segment III: • Between the umbilical and left portal fissures. • Drainage: Primarily into the left hepatic vein; alternative drainage via falciform ligament veins. Segment VI: • Inferior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right portal fissure. • Drainage: Usually into the right hepatic vein; may drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Segment V: • Inferior segment of the right anterior sector. • Drainage: Typically into the right and middle hepatic veins; can drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Segment IV: • Between the umbilical fissure and main portal fissure, anterior to segment I. • Drainage: Usually into the middle hepatic vein; can also drain into the left hepatic vein. 1, 2 & 3 (Option B): Segment I is the caudate lobe, which is functionally separate and not routinely removed in a left hemihepatectomy. 5, 6, 7 & 8 (Option C): These are part of the right functional lobe. 2, 3, 4 & 5 (Option D): Segment 5 belongs to the right lobe. 230
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: Given below what is the correct sequence of Damage control surgery? 1. Patient selection 2. Primary exploration 3. ICU care 4. Secondary exploration?
questions.explanation: Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is performed in critically ill or severely injured patients to quickly control bleeding and contamination, then allow physiological stabilization before definitive repair. Sequence: • Patient selection – Identify patients who are unstable (acidosis, hypothermia, coagulopathy) and unlikely to survive prolonged surgery. • Primary exploration – Abbreviated laparotomy to control hemorrhage (packing, vessel ligation) and contamination (bowel stapling, temporary closure). • ICU care – Aggressive resuscitation and correction of acidosis, coagulopathy, and hypothermia. • Secondary exploration – Definitive surgical repair after stabilization, usually within 24– 48 hours. 231
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: A 12-year-old girl has developed breast and pubic hair. The mother wants to know which sign of puberty will typically occur next?
questions.explanation: Pubertal development in girls generally follows Tanner’s sequence: 1. Thelarche – breast development (usually the first sign, ~8–11 years) 2. Pubarche – pubic hair development 3. Peak height velocity – occurs about 1 year after thelarche and before menarche 4. Menarche – typically 2–2.5 years after thelarche, after peak growth has occurred 5. Axillary hair – develops later in the sequence 6. Vaginal discharge – may occur just before menarche Since this girl already has breast and pubic hair, the next expected milestone is peak height velocity.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 12-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has been raised as a girl, has not developed breast tissue, and ultrasound reveals absence of the uterus. Karyotyping shows a 46 XY chromosomal pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to a mutation in the CYP17A1 gene. • This enzyme has two functions: 1. 17α-hydroxylase activity – needed for cortisol synthesis. 2. 17,20-lyase activity – needed for sex steroid synthesis. When it’s defective, the body cannot produce cortisol or sex steroids (androgens or estrogens) efficiently. Consequences: • Cortisol deficiency → ACTH increases → adrenal hyperplasia. • Sex steroid deficiency → lack of androgens in XY → female-like external genitalia; in XX → absent secondary sexual characteristics. 233 • Excess mineralocorticoids (due to shunting into deoxycorticosterone production) → hypertension + hypokalemia. Key laboratory findings: • ↑ ACTH (due to low cortisol) • ↑ Mineralocorticoids (DOC, corticosterone) • ↓ Renin • ↓ Sex steroids (testosterone, estradiol) ↑ BP, ↓ K⁺
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: What is the most appropriate treatment for an 8cm chylolymphatic mesenteric cyst?
questions.option_c: Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel 234
questions.explanation: • Chylolymphatic mesenteric cysts are typically benign, well-encapsulated lesions arising from lymphatic malformations in the mesentery. The majority are attached to the mesentery but do not infiltrate the bowel wall, meaning the cyst can be separated from the mesenteric vessels without compromising bowel blood supply. • Preferred treatment: Complete enucleation of the cyst while preserving the bowel, to prevent recurrence and avoid unnecessary resection. Tillaux Triad: 1. Peri-umbilical swelling 2. Tillaux sign → swelling moves at right angle to mesentery 3. Transverse band of resonance 235 Investigation of choice: Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) Types of Mesenteric Cysts Chylolymphatic cyst (most common) Enterogenous cyst Origin Sequestered lymphatic tissue Sequestered bowel tissue Wall Thin Thick Fluid Clear Turbid Blood supply Independent Shares with bowel Treatment Enucleation Resection + anastomosis 236 Site distribution: • Small intestine → 60% • Colon → 40% Complications: • Torsion • Rupture • Infection • Hemorrhage Aspiration (Option A) – Not definitive; high recurrence/infection risk. Resection of the cyst along with the adjacent bowel (Option C) – Needed only when the cyst shares vascular supply with the bowel or infiltrates the wall. Conservative (Option D) – Not appropriate due to risk of enlargement, infection, torsion, or rupture.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: During assited vaginal delivery, where is the vacuum device typically applied?
questions.option_a: At 3 cm behind the anterior fonatnelle
questions.option_c: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
questions.option_d: Between the anterior and posterior fontanelle
questions.explanation: 237 • In assisted vaginal delivery (vacuum extraction), the optimal placement of the vacuum cup is over the flexion point, this is about 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle along the sagittal suture toward the anterior fontanelle. • The flexion point is the ideal spot for achieving maximum flexion of the fetal head, ensuring the smallest presenting diameter (suboccipitobregmatic diameter) passes through the birth canal. • Placing the cup here causes the chin to tuck toward the chest, improving descent and minimizing trauma.
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: A patient is scheduled for laparoscopic surgery under general Anaesthesia in a day care setting. Which of the following factors makes him unsuitable for day care surgery?
questions.option_a: Home is 45 minutes away from the hospital
questions.option_b: The surgical procedure is expected to last slightly over 1 hour
questions.option_c: No attendant is available at home to care for the patient postoperatively
questions.option_d: The patient has had general Anaesthesia in the past without complications
questions.explanation: A fundamental requirement for day care surgery with general Anaesthesia is the presence of a responsible adult. This person must transport the patient home and provide care for at least the first 24 hours post- surgery. After general Anaesthesia, patients have impaired judgment, coordination, and reaction time. The absence of a caregiver poses a significant safety risk due to the potential for: • Falls and other injuries. • Delayed reactions to medications. • Inability to recognize or appropriately respond to post-operative complications. Without this support, the patient is unsuitable for discharge to their home.
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: What is the co-test in cervical cancer screening?
questions.explanation: Co-testing in cervical cancer screening refers to performing both: 1. HPV testing – detects high-risk human papillomavirus DNA (especially HPV 16 and 18, which cause ~70% of cervical cancers). 2. Pap smear (cytology) – examines cervical cells for precancerous or cancerous changes. HPV testing → very sensitive for detecting the cause (virus) of cervical cancer. Pap smear → detects cellular changes before they become invasive. Together, they improve detection rates and reduce the risk of missing early disease. In many countries, co-testing (HPV + Pap) is recommended every 5 years for women aged 30– 65 years if results are negative.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a contraindication to subcutaneous contraceptive implant?
questions.explanation: • Undiagnosed genital bleeding can be a sign of serious underlying conditions like endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, or structural lesions. • Inserting a subcutaneous contraceptive implant without first diagnosing the cause could delay detection and treatment of a potentially dangerous condition. • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria lists it as Category 4 (unacceptable health risk) until the cause is clarified.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old female presented with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen after 4 days of cholecystectomy. On USG, it showed a significant collection in RUQ. What will you do further?
questions.explanation: • The patient presents 4 days post-cholecystectomy with a localized collection in the right upper quadrant on ultrasound. The immediate priority here is diagnosis and therapeutic drainage — aspiration will relieve symptoms, confirm the nature of the fluid (bile, pus, blood), and guide further management. If the aspirated content is bile → further evaluation with MRCP or ERCP can be planned to localize and treat the leak. Aspiration is minimally invasive and avoids unnecessary re-exploration in a stable patient. Post-Cholecystectomy Collections: • Causes: Bile leak (cystic duct stump leak, accessory duct injury), intra-abdominal abscess, hematoma, seroma. • Symptoms: Fever, abdominal pain, localized tenderness, distension, jaundice (if major duct injury). • Diagnosis: • USG: Detects and localizes fluid collection. • Aspiration: Confirms content type. • MRCP: Maps biliary anatomy if a bile leak is suspected. • ERCP: Diagnostic + therapeutic (stenting, sphincterotomy). • Surgical anatomy: • Calot’s triangle boundaries → Cystic duct (medial), common hepatic duct (lateral), inferior surface of liver (superior). • Contents: Cystic artery, cystic lymph node of Lund, connective tissue. 242 • Management pathway: • USG-guided aspiration. • If bile leak → MRCP/ERCP. • Persistent leak or large duct injury → surgical repair. Re-explore laparoscopically (Option A) – Too invasive without knowing the nature of the collection. Higher antibiotics (Option B) – Won’t resolve a large collection; drainage is required. MRCP (Option C) – Useful after confirming bile in the aspirate, but here aspiration is the first step. 243
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: During general Anaesthesia, which nerve is commonly monitored using a nerve stimulator to assess neuromuscular blockade?
questions.explanation: The ulnar nerve is the standard site for neuromuscular monitoring because: 1. Muscle Innervation: It innervates the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand. This muscle is highly sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents, and its response accurately reflects the blockade's depth. 2. Clear Twitch Response: Monitoring the adductor pollicis muscle provides a clear and easily measurable twitch response. This allows anesthesiologists to precisely gauge the degree of muscle paralysis. 3. Superficial Location: The ulnar nerve is easily accessible at the wrist, making electrode placement simple and reliable. 4. Assessment of Blockade: It provides a dependable assessment of non-depolarizing blockade, which is crucial for determining the appropriate time for drug administration or reversal.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A patient with a previous history of cesarean section is in labor and has contractions of 3/10, no fetal distress and membranes are intact. What is the next step in management?
questions.option_b: Perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and monitor
questions.explanation: Artificial rupture of membranes can: • Increase endogenous prostaglandin release • Strengthen contractions naturally • Help labor progress It allows continued monitoring of fetal heart rate and labor progress without immediately escalating to high-risk interventions. Since the patient is already in labor with contractions 3 in 10 minutes (mild to moderate frequency), no fetal distress, and membranes intact, we do a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC).
questions.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology

questions.question_text: A patient under Anaesthesia is found to be in a “cannot intubate, cannot ventilate” (CICV) scenario. What is the next best step in management? 246?
questions.explanation: A "cannot intubate, cannot ventilate" (CICV) scenario is a life-threatening emergency in which both endotracheal intubation and non-invasive ventilation (e.g., with a bag-valve-mask or supraglottic airway) have failed. This situation demands an immediate and decisive response to establish an airway. • Immediate Surgical Airway: In a CICV situation, an immediate surgical airway is required to oxygenate the patient and prevent hypoxic brain injury or cardiac arrest. This must be performed as quickly as possible, ideally within 3-5 minutes of declaring the CICV state. • Cricothyroidotomy: A cricothyroidotomy is the fastest and most accessible emergency surgical airway technique. It involves making a small incision through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to insert a tube directly into the trachea. Because it is performed at a superficial level and does not require complex dissection, it is the method of choice in this time-critical situation. 247
questions.subject: Anaesthesia

questions.question_text: A follow-up patient of GERD on endoscopy was having a nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum, which hormone are you suspecting to be raised?
questions.explanation: • A nodule in the 2nd part of the duodenum in a patient with GERD symptoms raises suspicion of a gastrinoma (Zollinger–Ellison syndrome). Gastrinoma: • Gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor → marked acid hypersecretion → severe peptic ulcer disease. • Common sites: • Duodenum (~70%) • Pancreas (~25%) • Other sites (~5%) — stomach, lymph nodes. • Gastrinoma Triangle: • Cystic duct–CBD junction • Junction of 2nd & 3rd part of duodenum • Neck & body of the pancreas. 249 • Associations: MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1) → Gastrinoma + Pituitary adenoma + Parathyroid hyperplasia. • Clinical features: • Refractory peptic ulcers (often multiple, distal to duodenal bulb) • GERD • Chronic diarrhea (acid inactivates pancreatic enzymes → malabsorption) • Diagnosis: • Fasting serum gastrin >1000 pg/mL (very high suspicion) • Secretin stimulation test → paradoxical rise in gastrin. • Imaging: Endoscopic ultrasound, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy. • Treatment: 250 • High-dose proton pump inhibitors (acid suppression). • Surgical excision if localized. Inulin (Option B) – Not a hormone; used as a marker for GFR measurement. VIP (Option C) – Elevated in VIPoma; causes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome), and no duodenal nodules with GERD. Glucagon (Option D) – Elevated in glucagonoma; presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, and anemia, typically in the pancreas, not the duodenum.
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A patient undergoing surgery develops sudden deranged vitals following a failed attempt at subclavian vein catheterization. On examination, the trachea is shifted to one side and breath sounds are absent on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient's clinical presentation is a classic triad of signs and symptoms that strongly indicate a tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition that occurs when air enters the pleural space, but cannot escape, causing a one-way valve effect. The key findings are: • Tracheal deviation: The trachea is shifted away from the affected side as the increasing pressure in the pleural space pushes the mediastinum to the opposite side. 251 • Absent breath sounds: Breath sounds are absent on the affected side due to the complete collapse of the lung. • Hypotension and hypoxia: The high intrathoracic pressure compresses the major blood vessels, leading to a significant decrease in venous return, causing hypotension. This also impairs gas exchange, leading to hypoxia.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A neonate has intestines protruding from the abdomen without any external covering. What will be your next line of management?
questions.option_c: Cover the content with a Silo bag and wait
questions.explanation: • A neonate with intestines protruding without any external covering is most likely gastroschisis. In gastroschisis, the bowel is directly exposed to air and amniotic fluid 252 postnatally, making it edematous, thick, and friable. If the abdominal cavity is too small to accommodate the swollen bowel without causing respiratory compromise, primary surgical closure is avoided initially. Instead, the bowel is placed in a sterile silo bag to protect it, prevent fluid loss, and allow gradual reduction of contents into the abdomen over several days, after which definitive closure is performed. This staged approach minimizes the risk of abdominal compartment syndrome and preserves bowel viability. • Another gastric defect is an Omphalocele. Gastroschisis vs Omphalocele: Feature Gastroschisis Omphalocele Defect location Right of umbilicus Through umbilicus Covering None (bare bowel) Peritoneum + amnion sac Associated anomalies Rare (~10%) Common (~60%, esp. cardiac, chromosomal) Cause Vascular disruption of the right omphalomesenteric artery Failure of midgut return & closure Bowel appearance Thick, edematous, and inflamed Normal, within sac Initial management Silo bag, staged reduction Protect sac, repair when stable Image Surgical correction (Option A) – Primary closure may cause abdominal compartment syndrome; not preferred if bowel is edematous or the abdominal cavity is small. Conservative management with higher antibiotics (Option B) – Inadequate; needs urgent protective intervention for bowel. 253 Cover with NS soaked gauze (Option D) – Temporary measure if silo unavailable, but definitive staged reduction in silo is standard.
questions.subject: Surgery

questions.question_text: A 7-year-old male child was brought to the EMR 6 hours after a burn and was having 22% BSA burns. On examination, cool extremities, BP - 92/50mmHg, PR - 56 BPM. Urine output since burn episode: 30ml. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: • The child has burn shock — evidenced by hypotension, bradycardia (late sign in children), cool extremities, and low urine output. In pediatric burns, >15% BSA requires urgent IV fluid resuscitation to prevent progression to multi-organ failure. • This patient is 6 hours post-burn, meaning there is already an ongoing deficit that must be corrected promptly. Therefore, an initial bolus: 10 ml/kg of Ringer’s lactate is recommended to restore circulation before calculated maintenance fluids. • Colloids are not given early because, during the first 24 hours, capillary permeability is markedly increased → colloids leak into the interstitium → worsen edema. Colloids (e.g., albumin) are generally started after 24 hours. Burn Fluid Resuscitation: Formula Calculation Notes 254 Parkland formula 4 ml × body weight (kg) × %BSA burned Use Ringer’s lactate; give ½ in first 8 hrs (from time of burn), remainder in next 16 hrs Children Same as adults, but add maintenance fluids (Holliday– Segar method) Monitor urine output (goal: 1 ml/kg/hr) Evans formula Crystalloids + colloids after 24 hrs Rarely used now Brooke formula 2 ml × kg × %BSA + maintenance Modified approach to reduce over- resuscitation Nutrition in Burns: • Hypermetabolic state → ↑ protein and calorie requirement. • Early enteral feeding within 24 hrs reduces infections & maintains gut integrity. • Protein: 1.5–2 g/kg/day (children may need up to 3 g/kg/day). • Calories: 1.5–2 times basal requirement (can use Curreri formula: 25 kcal × kg + 40 kcal × %BSA burned). • Supplement vitamins A, C, and zinc to promote healing. Colloids in Burns: • Avoid in the first 24 hrs due to increased vascular permeability. • After 24 hrs, it may be used to maintain plasma oncotic pressure and reduce total crystalloid requirement. • Common colloids: albumin, plasma protein fraction. Give colloid bolus (Option B) – Not indicated in the first 24 hrs; will leak into tissues and worsen edema. Surgical intervention (Option C) – Definitive management is delayed until the patient is hemodynamically stable. Give bolus at 30 ml/kg/hr (Option D) – Unsafe; may cause fluid overload, pulmonary edema, and abdominal compartment syndrome.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: After an RTA patient has severe Maxillofacial trauma with SpO2 80% at room air, and the patient cannot be intubated or ventilated, what should be your immediate step for this? 255?
questions.option_d: Do suction and again try intubation
questions.explanation: • In this patient, in whom intubation and ventilation are not possible is known as a “cannot intubate, cannot ventilate” (CICV) scenario → this is a surgical airway emergency. • Severe maxillofacial trauma often distorts airway anatomy, making both oral and nasal intubation impossible. In CICV, the fastest and most accessible surgical airway is emergency cricothyrotomy. Although tracheostomy provides a definitive airway, it takes longer and requires a more stable patient; not suitable for immediate life- threatening hypoxia. Cricothyrotomy allows rapid oxygenation within 30–60 seconds. 256 Cricothyrotomy: • Indications: 1. CICV situations 2. Severe facial trauma 3. Upper airway obstruction 4. Massive facial burns/swelling • Landmarks: 1. Thyroid cartilage 2. Cricothyroid membrane (between thyroid & cricoid cartilage) • Procedure: 1. Palpate the cricothyroid membrane. 257 2. Make a vertical skin incision, a horizontal membrane incision. 3. Insert a tracheostomy or endotracheal tube. • Advantages: Quick, minimal equipment, bypasses upper airway obstruction. • Limitations: Should be converted to tracheostomy within 24–72 hrs to prevent subglottic stenosis. Other surgical airway options in emergencies: • Needle cricothyrotomy with jet ventilation: In children <12 years or where surgical cricothyrotomy is risky. • Tracheostomy: elective or semi-urgent, not first-line in hypoxic arrest situations. Tracheostomy (Option B) – Too time-consuming in a rapidly desaturating patient. ICD insertion (Option C) – For chest trauma/pneumothorax, not airway obstruction. Do suction and again try intubation (Option D) – Wastes critical seconds; patient already in CICV state.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 13-year-old male was brought to OPD with pain right side testes after being hit by a cricket ball 2 hours back. On examination, severe testicular pain and an absent cremasteric reflex. What is the next step?
questions.explanation: 258 The above clinical case of an adolescent male with testicular pain and absent cremasteric reflex is suggestive of testicular torsion. Guidelines recommend color Doppler ultrasound as the first investigation to check testicular blood flow. USG Arterial Doppler will show: • Absent or reduced arterial flow → confirms torsion → immediate surgical exploration. • Normal or increased flow → rules out torsion, suggests inflammation. However, if clinical suspicion is extremely high (classic torsion features), exploration is preferred without delay. Testicular Torsion: • Twisting of the spermatic cord → cuts off arterial supply to the testis → surgical emergency. • Peak age: Neonates and adolescents (12–18 years). • Causes: Bell-clapper deformity, trauma, sudden movements, or spontaneous. • Key clinical signs: • Sudden severe unilateral testicular pain • High-riding, horizontally oriented testis • Absent cremasteric reflex • Negative Prehn’s sign (no relief on elevation) • Golden period: Salvage rate is best if detorsion is done within 6 hours; irreversible damage after ~12 hours. • Treatment: Surgical exploration, detorsion, and bilateral orchidopexy (fixation of both testes). USG Arterial Doppler in Acute Scrotal Pain: Feature Doppler finding Testicular torsion Absent/reduced intratesticular arterial flow Epididymo-orchitis Increased/normal flow Torsion appendage Normal testicular flow, appendage visible as a hyperechoic mass NSAIDs (Option B) – Only symptomatic; would delay definitive diagnosis. USG Venous Doppler (Option C) – Venous flow is less reliable than arterial assessment for torsion diagnosis. Surgical exploration (Option D) – Best for classic torsion presentation; but here, trauma history may lower pretest probability, so Doppler is chosen first. 259
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A 16-year-old boy presents with multiple episodes of abdominal pain and a history of passing blood in his stools. On examination, he has darkly pigmented spots on his lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: • Based on the above signs and symptoms, this classic triad is diagnostic of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (PJS), a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by STK11/LKB1 gene mutation. There is an increased risk for multiple cancers: GI (colon, stomach, pancreas), breast, ovary, cervix, and testes. 260 Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome (PJS): • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant. • Gene: STK11/LKB1 tumor suppressor gene mutation (chromosome 19p13.3). • Pathology: Multiple hamartomatous polyps (non-neoplastic, but with malignant potential due to genetic instability). • Features: • Mucocutaneous pigmentation → dark spots on lips, buccal mucosa, fingertips. • Pigmentation is due to melanin deposition in the basal cell layer (resembles freckles, but in the mucosa too). 261 • Hamartomatous polyps predominantly in the small intestine (especially jejunum). • Symptoms: abdominal pain, GI bleeding, intussusception (due to large polyps). • Complications: • Intussusception (the most common acute presentation in children) • GI bleeding → anemia • Malignancy risk: GI tract (esp. pancreas), breast, gonadal tumors • Management: • Symptomatic relief for obstruction/bleeding • Endoscopic polypectomy for large polyps • Cancer surveillance: colonoscopy, upper GI endoscopy, pancreatic screening Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (Option A) – Hundreds to thousands of adenomatous (not hamartomatous) polyps in the colon, due to APC gene mutation; no mucocutaneous pigmentation. Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (Option C) – Multiple juvenile polyps (hamartomas) in colon/rectum, usually <5 years; no mucocutaneous pigmentation. Cronkhite–Canada Syndrome (Option D) – Non-hereditary, middle-aged adults; GI polyps + alopecia, skin hyperpigmentation, nail atrophy (but not perioral mucosal pigmentation pattern).
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old male presented to EMT with H/o Penetrating chest trauma. On examination, severe tracheal deviation was present. What is the immediate step of management? 262?
questions.explanation: • History of penetrating trauma, severe tracheal deviation after chest trauma strongly suggests tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency caused by one-way air entry into the pleural space, leading to: • Increased intrathoracic pressure → collapse of the ipsilateral lung → pushes mediastinum away from affected side. • Mediastinal shift → compression of the opposite lung and major vessels • Obstructive shock → ↓ venous return, ↓ cardiac output 263 Do NOT wait for imaging like CXR or E-FAST; immediate decompression is required. Needle decompression → large-bore cannula into the 5th intercostal space (mid-axillary line), followed by ICD (chest tube) placement. Tension Pneumothorax: • Causes: Trauma (blunt/penetrating), barotrauma, mechanical ventilation, rib fractures. • Symptoms: Sudden respiratory distress, tachycardia, hypotension, unilateral absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, tracheal deviation away from the affected side, and distended neck veins. • Management: 1. Immediate needle decompression 2. Intercostal chest drain insertion for definitive management 264 Chest X-ray (Option B) – Imaging delays life-saving intervention; done after stabilizing the patient. E-FAST (Option C) – Bedside ultrasound is useful in trauma, but here the diagnosis is clinical, and urgent treatment is the priority. O₂ support at 100% (Option D) – Oxygen is supportive but will not relieve the life-threatening pressure in the pleural space.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A young adult patient presents with a fracture of the neck of the femur. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: The most appropriate management for a femoral neck fracture in a young adult is internal fixation. This method involves surgically inserting screws or a plate to stabilize the fracture while preserving the patient's natural hip joint. • Preserving the Femoral Head: Unlike older patients, young adults have a higher potential for the femoral head to heal and maintain its blood supply. Internal fixation is chosen to preserve the native femoral head and joint, which is crucial for a young, active patient. • Preventing Complications: The goal is to achieve an accurate reduction and stable fixation to promote healing and reduce the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis (AVN) and nonunion, which are more likely if the fracture is not treated correctly.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with a ring-shaped (lytic) lesion in the bone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic form of osteomyelitis, a bacterial infection of the bone. It's most commonly found in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly in the tibia. • Imaging Features: On an X-ray, it presents as a lytic, ring-shaped lesion surrounded by a thick, reactive sclerotic rim. The central lytic area represents the pus-filled abscess, while the sclerotic rim is new bone formation laid down by the body in response to the chronic infection. • Clinical Presentation: Patients, often young adults, may experience localized pain that is worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Identify the pathology in the child.
questions.explanation: • The image shows a soft swelling at the umbilicus in a child, which is characteristic of an Umbilical Hernia. Definition: Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring due to incomplete closure of the abdominal wall after birth. Typical presentation in children: • Soft bulge at the navel. • More prominent when the child cries, coughs, or strains. • Usually painless. Etiology: Common in infants, especially premature babies, due to delayed closure of the umbilical ring. Prognosis: Most close spontaneously by 2–3 years of age. Spigelian Hernia (Option B): Occurs along the semilunar line (lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle), not at the umbilicus. Inguinal Hernia (Option C): Presents as swelling in the groin or scrotum, not at the umbilicus. It is commonly due to a patent processus vaginalis. Femoral Hernia (Option D): Appears as swelling below the inguinal ligament, more common in adult females.
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: A patient was in a road traffic accident and presented with the following fracture. What type of fracture is this? 273?
questions.explanation: The image shows a fracture that occurs in the proximal femur, specifically in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. This is the definition of an intertrochanteric fracture. • Location: This type of fracture is located in the extracapsular region of the hip joint, meaning it is outside the joint capsule. This is an important distinction because the blood supply to the femoral head is typically well-preserved in these fractures, leading to a lower risk of avascular necrosis compared to femoral neck fractures. • Characteristics: These fractures are often comminuted (broken into multiple fragments) and can have a spiral or oblique pattern. They are common in elderly patients, often resulting from a simple fall.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A child comes after a train accident with stable vitals but a big laceration on the leg. Which triage category does the patient come under?
questions.explanation: • In disaster triage, the Yellow category means the patient is “Delayed” — they have serious injuries but are not in immediate danger of death and can tolerate some delay before definitive treatment. • Stable vitals → no immediate threat to airway, breathing, or circulation. • Big laceration on the leg → significant injury requiring medical attention, but not life- threatening right now. • The child can be managed after Red category (Immediate) patients are stabilized. Triage Color Codes: 1. Red - Immediate (Option A) • Life-threatening but treatable injuries needing urgent attention. • Examples: airway obstruction, severe bleeding, shock. 276 2. Yellow - Delayed(Option B) • Serious injuries but stable; treatment can be delayed. • Examples: large lacerations, stable fractures, moderate burns. 3. Green - Minor • Walking wounded; minor injuries. • Examples: small cuts, abrasions, sprains. 4. Black - Expectant / Deceased (Option D) • No signs of life or injuries incompatible with survival even with care.
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the hospital. Parents report a history of a single fall, but X-ray reveals multiple fractures at different stages of healing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario presents a classic case of non-accidental injury, also known as battered baby syndrome or child abuse. The key red flags are: • Inconsistent History: The parents' report of a single, minor fall is inconsistent with the severity and number of fractures. A single fall from a short height is highly unlikely to cause multiple fractures in an infant. 277 • Multiple Fractures at Different Stages of Healing: The presence of both new fractures and older, healing fractures on the X-ray is a strong indicator of repeated trauma over time, not a single event. • Fracture Patterns: Certain fracture patterns are highly suggestive of abuse, such as metaphyseal corner fractures (also known as "bucket handle" fractures) and posterior rib fractures in an infant.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following veins are involved in the formation of esophageal varices?
questions.explanation: • Esophageal varices occur due to portal hypertension (commonly from liver cirrhosis). • In portal hypertension, blood flow is obstructed in the portal vein, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. One important site is lower esophagus, where: • Portal circulation: Left gastric vein (drains into portal vein) • Systemic circulation: Esophageal veins (drain into azygos vein → superior vena cava) Increased pressure in the left gastric vein causes dilated submucosal esophageal veins → varices. Right gastric vein (Option B): Drains the lesser curvature of the stomach. It connects to the portal vein, but not a major contributor to lower esophageal varices. Left gastroepiploic vein (Option C): Drains the greater curvature of the stomach into the splenic vein (portal system). It is not involved in esophageal portosystemic anastomosis. Right gastroepiploic vein (Option D): Drains into the superior mesenteric vein (portal system). It has no role in esophageal varices. 279
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Injury to which part causes difficulty in dorsiflexion of the foot?
questions.explanation: The x-ray shows nerves labelled around the knee. B is pointing to the common peroneal nerve. • Function of the Common Peroneal Nerve: The common peroneal nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the lower leg. Specifically, it branches into the deep and superficial peroneal nerves. The deep peroneal nerve innervates the tibialis anterior muscle, which is the primary muscle responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot (lifting the foot upward). • Clinical Significance: Injury to the common peroneal nerve, which is common due to its superficial location around the fibular head, results in the inability to dorsiflex the foot. This condition is known as foot drop, where the foot hangs down and the patient has to lift their leg high to avoid dragging their toes while walking. 281
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: An elderly woman involved in a road traffic accident presents with difficulty in breathing and altered mental status. D-Dimer is elevated. X-ray findings are suggestive. What is the most likely diagnosis? 283?
questions.explanation: The patient's presentation following a road traffic accident is highly suggestive of a fat embolism syndrome. This condition occurs when fat globules from the bone marrow are released into the bloodstream after a long bone fracture, traveling to the lungs and brain. The classic triad of symptoms includes: • Respiratory Distress: This is the most common symptom, typically occurring 24-72 hours after the trauma. The fat emboli obstruct the pulmonary capillaries, leading to hypoxia and respiratory failure. The chest X-ray often shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, mimicking acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), as seen in the image provided. • Neurologic Changes: These can range from altered mental status to confusion, agitation, and even coma, as the fat emboli affect the cerebral circulation. • Petechial Rash: A characteristic, but not always present, rash of tiny red spots on the chest, neck, and axilla is a classic finding. An elevated D-dimer is a non-specific finding that can be seen in both fat embolism and pulmonary embolism, as it indicates a breakdown of a clot. However, the combination of respiratory distress and neurological changes following a long bone fracture (common in road traffic accidents) makes a fat embolism the most likely diagnosis.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with the fracture shown in X-ray. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this type of fracture? 285 286?
questions.explanation: The X-ray shows a spiral fracture of the midshaft humerus. This type of fracture is notoriously associated with injury to the radial nerve, which runs in close anatomical proximity to the bone at this specific location. • Anatomical Proximity: The radial nerve courses through the spiral groove (or radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it highly vulnerable to trauma during a fracture of the midshaft. • Clinical Presentation: An injury to the radial nerve typically presents with wrist drop, which is the inability to extend the wrist and fingers. This is a result of the nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the forearm. The incidence of radial nerve palsy in these fractures is approximately 10-20%. 287 288
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which ligament is tested in the following test? 289?
questions.explanation: The image depicts the anterior drawer test, a clinical maneuver used to assess the integrity of the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL). The test is performed by: • Flexing the patient's knee to 90 degrees. • Stabilizing the patient's femur with one hand. • Pulling the tibia forward with the other hand.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 9-month-old infant is brought for a routine check-up. Which of the following developmental milestones is most likely to be present at this age? 291?
questions.option_b: Creeps well on hands and knees
questions.explanation: • By 9 months, most infants develop good gross motor skills such as creeping (moving on hands and knees) and pulling to stand. They also typically have a crude pincer grasp, respond to their name, and show stranger anxiety. Key Developmental Milestones Age Gross Motor Milestones Fine Motor Milestones Social Milestones Language Milestones 1 month Alerts to sounds 2 months Social smile 3 months Neck holding Recognises mother, anticipates feed Cooing 4 months Laugh Aloud 5 months Rolls over Bidextrous reach 292 6 months Sits in tripod position Unidextrous reach stranger anxiety(7 months) Monosyllables 8 months Sits without support 9 months Stands with support Immature pincer grasp Waves bye bye Bisyllables 12 months Creeps well, stands without support Mature pincer grasp Comes when called, plays simple ball game 1 to 2 words with meaning 15 months Walks alone, creeps upstairs Imitates scribbling, tower of 2 blocks Jargon speech 18 months Runs, explores drawers Scribbles, tower of 3 blocks Copies parents in task 8 to 10 words vocabulary 2 years Walks up and downstairs (2 feet per step), jumps Tower of 6 blocks, copies straight line Asks for food, drink, toilet, pulls people to show toys 2 to 3 word sentences
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A doctor receives two summons, one to appear in court in a murder case and another to provide expert medical opinion. Which of the following should the doctor prioritise?
questions.option_b: Appearance for providing medical expert opinion
questions.explanation: A criminal court summons in a murder case generally carries a legal imperative and higher priority; attendance is mandatory unless legally excused.  Providing expert opinion is important, but when faced with a direct court order in a criminal case, the legal obligation to appear in court for the criminal matter is prioritized.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old man came with choking episodes after ingestion of fish bone while eating. The fishbone got impacted at the level of T4 in the esophagus. Which is the most likely site of obstruction?
questions.explanation: The fishbone is impacted at the T4 level, where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus and creates a normal anatomical narrowing, making it the most likely site of obstruction. Oesophageal Constrictions:  Constrictions occur at four main points: Point of constriction Distance from Incisors Description Vertebral level Cricopharyngeus Muscle (Option C ruled out) 6 inches This first constriction is at the upper esophageal sphincter where the esophagus begins. It is caused by the cricopharyngeus muscle, which plays a role in swallowing. C6 2 Aortic Arch (Option B) 9 inches The second narrowing occurs where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus. The pressure from the aorta causes this indentation. T4 Left Main Bronchus (Option A ruled out) 11 inches Third constriction is where the left bronchus crosses over the esophagus, leading to a narrowing. T6 Diaphragmatic Hiatus (Option D ruled out) 15 inches The final narrowing happens where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus. T10 3
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A man fell on his shoulder with his head pushed in the opposite direction. He presented with the following deformity. Which nerve root values are most likely affected? 4?
questions.explanation: 5  A fall on the shoulder with the head pushed to the opposite side suggests a traction injury to the upper brachial plexus, resulting in the characteristic posture seen in Erb’s Palsy, most commonly affecting the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Erb’s Palsy Definition Erb-Duchenne palsy results from damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6 nerve roots). (Option A) Mechanism of Injury Traction or stretching of the neck during childbirth (shoulder dystocia) or traumatic separation of the head and shoulder. Anatomical Structures Involved Brachial Plexus: Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves Upper Trunk: Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami Erb’s Point: Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions. Clinical Presentation  Muscle Weakness/ Paralysis ○ Shoulder Abduction: Affected (supraspinatus, deltoid) ○ External Rotation: Affected (infraspinatus, teres minor) ○ Elbow Flexion: Affected (biceps brachii, brachialis) ○ Forearm Supination: Affected (biceps brachii)  Arm Position: Limp arm by the side, forearm pronated, hand inward ("waiter’s tip" position).  Sensory Deficits: Numbness or tingling along the lateral arm, forearm, and hand, corresponding to C5 and C6 dermatomes. 6 Associated findings  Horner's Syndrome: Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury.  Skeletal abnormalities: Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance. 7 8
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Which structure is formed by the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.explanation: The arrow points to the Notochord, an embryonic midline structure that acts as the primitive axial skeleton, induces neural tube formation, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc in adults.  Nucleus pulposus: The core of the intervertebral disc, derived from the embryonic notochord, and functions to absorb spinal compression and provide flexibility.  Notochord Formation: ○ Formation of the primitive streak 11 ○ Migration of mesodermal cells through the primitive node ○ Formation of the notochordal process ○ Formation of the notochordal plate ○ Detachment of the notochordal plate ○ Rolling into the definitive notochord
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A diabetic worker sustains a stab injury to the central region of his palm. After 3 days, he develops swelling, severe pain, and inability to extend his middle and ring fingers. Pus accumulation is suspected in one of the palmar spaces. Which of the following spaces is most likely involved?
questions.explanation: A stab injury to the central palm in a diabetic patient, followed by swelling, pain, and inability to extend the middle and ring fingers, suggests pus accumulation in the midpalmar space (B) - a deep space bounded by the palmar aponeurosis and metacarpals, commonly involved in deep hand infections affecting the 3rd and 4th digits. 14
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: Which is the narrowest part of the adult laryngeal airway?
questions.explanation: In adults, the glottis- specifically the rima glottidis, the space between the true vocal cords - is the narrowest part of the laryngeal airway and plays a key role in controlling airflow and voice production. Infant Larynx Adult Larynx Position Superiorly placed (C1-C4) 3rd -6th cervical vertebrae (C3-C6) Epiglottis Omega-shaped, floppy Leaf like Narrowest area Subglottis Glottis (Option B) Submucosal tissue More abundant Less abundant 16

questions.question_text: A man sustained trauma on the lateral side of his right knee. Two days later, he complains of difficulty in walking, as his toes keep dragging on the ground. He also notices numbness over the upper lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: A man with lateral right knee trauma now has foot drop and numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of the foot, indicating injury to the Common Peroneal Nerve.  Supply: Common peroneal nerve branches from the sciatic nerve. It wraps around the neck of the fibula and then divides into two major branches: ○ Superficial peroneal nerve → Peroneus longus and Peroneus brevis (motor supply) → Eversion of the foot. ○ Deep peroneal nerve → Dorsiflexion of the foot and toes and extension of the toes (motor supply) ■ Tibialis anterior ■ Extensor hallucis longus ■ Extensor digitorum longus ■ Peroneus tertius ■ Extensor digitorum brevis  Mechanism of Trauma: Trauma to the lateral side of the knee, especially around the fibular neck, is a common site of injury to the common peroneal nerve, where it is superficial and vulnerable.  Symptoms: ○ Foot drop (toes drag while walking) → due to loss of dorsiflexion (caused by paralysis of muscles innervated by the deep peroneal nerve). ○ Numbness over the upper lateral leg and dorsum of foot → sensory supply of the common peroneal nerve and its superficial branch.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A young patient experiences shortness of breath specifically during exercise in winter, which subsides after using salbutamol. What is the most likely explanation for this condition?
questions.option_a: Vagal stimulation due to cold air exposure
questions.option_c: Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction triggered by cold air
questions.option_d: Airway hyperreactivity due to cold-induced asthma exacerbation
questions.explanation: Shortness of breath during winter exercise relieved by salbutamol suggests Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction, triggered by cold air in individuals with airway hyperresponsiveness. Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction 19 Definition Transient narrowing of airways during or after exercise Triggers  Cold, dry air (common in winter) (Option C)  Intense physical activity Mechanism Loss of heat and moisture from airways → airway hyperreactivity → bronchoconstriction (Option C) Symptoms  Commonly seen in: ○ Young individuals ○ Underlying asthma or allergies  Shortness of breath  Wheezing  Coughing during/after exercise Diagnosis Exercise challenge test or spirometry Management  Salbutamol (β2-agonist) inhaled before exercise  Avoid cold air exposure (e.g., use a mask or warm-up before exercise).
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: During an explosion, a patient sustains a crushed lower limb injury by collapse of a building. What type of blast injury does this represent?
questions.explanation: Quaternary blast injuries include building collapse causing crush injuries. Primary blast injury (Option A)  Air-wave/ blast wave/ shock wave - Air compression  Barotrauma damages hollow organs  Ear  Tympanic membrane- M/c, Ossicles, Bleeding, perforation  Lungs  Most fatal injury  Alveoli, capillaries injured (blast lung)  GIT  Vomiting, Perforation, Hematemesis, Melena Secondary blast injury (Option B)  Flying missiles/ projectiles/ objects - Hitting body  Bruises  Abrasions 21  Punctate laceration Tertiary blast injury (Option C)  Lifted and thrown around  Hits ground  Skeletal fractures/ displacements Quaternary blast injury  Miscellaneous  Building collapse: Traumatic Asphyxia  Burn, Flame injuries Quinary Blast Injuries  Environmental contaminants  Chemicals (Chloride, Savin)  Radiations (nuclear bomb)  Virus and bacteria. 22
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: The upper part of the uncinate process commonly attaches to?
questions.explanation: The uncinate process is a thin, curved bony structure of the ethmoid bone that extends superiorly and typically attaches to the middle nasal concha (middle turbinate), helping to form part of the lateral nasal wall and the drainage pathway of the frontal sinus. Components of the Middle Meatus of the Nose:  Uncinate Process: ○ Hook-like structure running from anterosuperior to posteroinferior. ○ Forms a gap with the bulla ethmoidalis called the hiatus semilunaris inferior. 23 ○ Divides the lower middle meatus into anterior and posterior fontanelles (membranous areas).  Infundibulum: ○ Bounded medially by the uncinate process and laterally by the lamina papyracea. ○ Contains the natural ostium of the maxillary sinus in its lower part.  Bulla Ethmoidalis: ○ Ethmoidal cell located behind the uncinate process, forming the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris. ○ May be pneumatized or a solid prominence.  Hiatus Semilunaris: ○ Inferior: The gap between the uncinate process and bulla. ○ Superior: The cleft between the bulla and skull base.  Ostiomeatal Unit (Complex): ○ Key area where the ostia of the frontal, ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain into the middle meatus. ○ Common drainage pathway for the anterior group of sinuses.

questions.question_text: What best describes step 3 in the given diagram? 24?
questions.option_d: Resting membrane potential is maintained by the Na-K pump
questions.explanation: Step 3 – Repolarisation occurs as voltage-gated K⁺ channels open, causing K⁺ efflux, which restores the membrane potential toward its resting level. Process Membrane Potential Change Ion Movement/Channe l Activity Threshold Impact 26 Resting Potential ~ -65 mV Higher K⁺ inside than outside Neutral Depolarization More positive Na⁺ influx (channels open) Possible Action Potential EPSP More positive Positive ions enter Triggers Action Potential if threshold reached Repolarization Returns to -65 mV from peak of depolarization Na⁺ channels close, K⁺ channels open wider Returns to resting state Hyperpolarization More negative than -65 mV Cl⁻ enters or K⁺ exits (channels remain open) Less likely to fire immediately IPSP More negative Negative ions enter or K⁺ exits Inhibits action potential

questions.question_text: A child is brought to the hospital with pinpoint pupils and difficulty breathing after playing at home. What is the most likely substance the child accidentally ingested?
questions.explanation: Opioid ingestion classically causes miosis (pin-point pupils) and respiratory depression — the hallmark of opioid toxicity. Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning Cause Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose. 28 Symptoms  Unconsiousness/coma  Miosis: Pin point pupil  Respiratory depression  Dry secretion in the eye/mouth  Urinary retention  Constipation  Flaccid muscles  Convulsions (in children) Management Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote) ↓ Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):  Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol  Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine ↓ Abstinence (Prevent relapse):  DOC: Oral Naltrexone
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: In the given image which vein is mainly affected? 29 30?
questions.explanation: The image depicts varicose veins following the path of the great saphenous vein, the primary vein affected is the great saphenous vein. Great Saphenous Vein (GSV) Origin  Arises on the dorsum of the foot, as a continuation of the medial marginal vein Course  Ascends in front of the medial malleolus  Runs along the medial leg  Courses behind the knee  Inclines forward in the thigh  Passes through the saphenous opening into the femoral vein 31 Tributaries  Dorsal venous arch of the foot  Medial marginal vein  Posterior arch vein  Calf vein  Accessory saphenous vein  Anterior cutaneous vein of the thigh  Superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, and external pudendal veins Valves  Contains 10-20 valves, more concentrated in the leg Clinical Significance  Commonly used in surgical grafting, especially for coronary artery bypass  Varicose veins: Dilated, tortuous veins due to valve incompetence, commonly in GSV and tributaries
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: An alcoholic patient is admitted to the hospital 48 hours after his last drink. He presents with altered consciousness, disorientation, and severe agitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Based on the timing (48 hours), severe agitation, and altered mental status in this patient strongly point to Delirium tremens rather than simple alcohol withdrawal or other causes.  Delirium tremens is the most severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal, typically occurring 48–72 hours after the last drink. It presents with altered consciousness, disorientation, severe agitation, autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever), and sometimes hallucinations.  DT is a medical emergency with high mortality if untreated (5–15%). It is caused by CNS hyperexcitability due to the sudden removal of chronic ethanol’s depressant effect. Management: ICU care, high-dose benzodiazepines, thiamine supplementation, and supportive measures. Risk factors:  Prior severe withdrawal  Concurrent illness  Heavy, prolonged alcohol use. Time since last drink Common features Severe complications 6–12 hrs Tremors, anxiety, insomnia, GI upset — 33 12–24 hrs Visual/tactile hallucinations — 24–48 hrs Seizures (generalized tonic-clonic) — 48–72 hrs Confusion, agitation, autonomic instability → Delirium tremens Death if untreated

questions.question_text: Which among the following hormones, in a lactating mother, is responsible for the growth of breast tissue?
questions.explanation: In a lactating mother, prolactin is primarily responsible for stimulating the growth and development of the milk-producing breast tissue (lobuloalveolar structures). Prolactin Source Secreted by lactotrophs of the anterior pituitary (number increase during pregnancy, lactation, estrogen therapy) Synthesis  Synthesized as preprolactin → proprolactin → prolactin  Stored in granules of lactotrophs → secreted upon stimulation Factors Controlling Secretion Increased by:  Prolactin Releasing Factor (PRF)  Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH) (B)  Pregnancy, estrogen therapy, breastfeeding  Sleep, stress (D)  Oxytocin, serotonin, Angiotensin-II (A)  Dopamine antagonists, opioids 35 Decreased by:  Dopamine and its agonists  Somatostatin, GABA  Prolactin (feedback mechanism) Functions  Milk Synthesis and Secretion: Stimulates milk synthesis and secretion  Breast Development: ○ Hyperplasia of breast tissue (puberty, pregnancy and lactation) ○ Stimulates development of mammary glands ○ Works with estrogen, progesterone, cortisol, GH, insulin  Reproductive Functions: ○ Inhibits GnRH (prevents ovulation,cause lactational amenorrhea) ○ Inhibition of libido, stimulation of maternal behaviour ○ Decreases spermatogenesis in males  Immunity: Synthesized by immunocytes (balance immune response during pregnancy).  Liver: Increases synthesis of synlactin (intermediary growth factor). Clinical Correlation  Amenorrhea-galactorrhea syndrome due to hyperprolactinemia  Diagnosis: High plasma prolactin levels, pituitary MRI  Treatment: Dopaminergic drugs to inhibit prolactin secretion, restoring fertility and libido 36
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A patient presented to OPD with ophthalmoplegia and ptosis. Diagnosis of superior orbital fissure syndrome was confirmed after examination. Which nerves are compressed in this case?
questions.explanation: Superior orbital fissure syndrome compresses cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI, causing ophthalmoplegia and ptosis due to impaired eye movement and sensory loss around the eye.  Superior orbital fissure: Triangular gap through which the middle cranial fossa connects with the orbit Part Structures Passing Through Lateral Part  Lacrimal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)  Frontal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)  Trochlear nerve (CN IV)  Superior ophthalmic vein  Meningeal branch of lacrimal artery  Anastomotic branch of middle meningeal artery (anastomoses with recurrent branch of lacrimal artery) Middle Part  Upper division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)  Lower division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)  Nasociliary nerve  Abducens nerve (CN VI) Medial Part  Inferior ophthalmic vein  Sympathetic nerve from plexus around internal carotid artery 38 V2 (maxillary nerve) and II (optic nerve) (Option B, C, D) do not pass through the superior orbital fissure:  V2 passes through the foramen rotundum.  II passes through the optic canal.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old man wakes up after sleeping with his arm draped over a chair and complains of pain. Which of the following accurately describes the order of susceptibility of nerve fibers in the given condition?
questions.explanation: The order of nerve fiber susceptibility to compression is: A > B > C Susceptibility to Local Anaesthesia Pressure Hypoxia Aγ and Aδ >> Aα and Aβ >> B >> C Aα > B > C B > A > C
questions.subject: Anatomy
