Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen Rhizopus 175 176 Pathogenesis Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction. Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness) Common Sites  Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.  Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.  Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis 177 Clinical Features  Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis: ○ Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis. ○ Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.  Pulmonary Zygomycosis: ○ Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis 178 Diagnosis Histological Examination: Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae. Culture:  After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.  Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.) a. 179 b. a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores) Treatment:  Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.  Medical control of diabetes is required.
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A tympanometry graph is shown below. An arrow indicates a shallow peak at pressure = 0 daPa. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the tympanometry result shown?
questions.explanation: The tympanogram shows a normal middle ear pressure (peak at 0 daPa) but reduced compliance (shallow peak). This pattern is diagnostic of Type As tympanogram, which indicates stiffening of the middle ear system. Common causes:  Otosclerosis (stapes fixation)  Tympanosclerosis (post-infection scarring)  Thickened tympanic membrane Impedance audiometry: Impedance audiometry comprises of acoustic reflex and tympanometry. A. Tympanometry:  Measures the compliance (stiffness) of the tympano-ossicular system by detecting the reflected sound energy.  Can also test Eustachian tube function by pressure changes and swallowing.  Different tympanogram types indicate middle ear pathologies: Tympanogram Type Characteristics Indication Type A Normal peak Normal middle ear function Type As Shallow peak Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis) Type Ad Deep peak Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane Type B Flat, no peak Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane Type C Peak at negative pressure Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure 182 B. Acoustic Reflex (Stapedial Reflex):  Measures the stapedial muscle contraction in response to loud sounds (70-100 dB above threshold).  Useful for: ○ Assessing hearing in infants and young children. ○ Detecting malingering. ○ Diagnosing cochlear and CN VIII pathologies. ○ Assessing facial nerve function and brainstem lesions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not seen in Meniere's Disease?
questions.explanation: Meniere’s disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops. However, ear pain is not a typical feature of Meniere’s disease unless secondary infections or complications occur. Meniere’s Disease Feature Description Cause Excess endolymph accumulation (endolymphatic hydrops) Triad of Symptoms 1. Vertigo (episodic, lasts minutes to hours) 2. Tinnitus (low-frequency, roaring type) 3. Hearing loss (sensorineural, fluctuating, progressive) Other Symptoms Aural fullness (blocked ear sensation) 184 Not Typically Seen Ear pain, except in secondary infections Diagnosis Clinical + Audiometry (low-frequency SNHL) Treatment Dietary modifications (low sodium), diuretics, vestibular suppressants, intratympanic steroids, and surgery in refractory cases
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A farmer presents with fever, malaise, and diarrhea. There is a history of exposure to livestock. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the illness?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of a farmer with acute febrile illness after exposure to livestock suggests the diagnosis of Q fever, a zoonotic infection caused by Coxiella burnetii.  Source → Infected livestock (cattle, sheep, goats) — bacteria found in birth products, urine, faeces, and milk.  Transmission → Inhalation of aerosolized particles (often from contaminated hay, barn dust, or animal waste).  Symptoms → Fever, malaise, myalgia, headache; may include pneumonia or hepatitis.  Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhoea can occur, especially in acute infection.  No rash (unlike many other rickettsial infections). 186 Rickettsia rickettsii (Option A): Rocky Mountain spotted fever; requires tick bite; classic triad is fever, rash and history of tick exposure. Rickettsia typhi (Option B): Murine (endemic) typhus; transmitted by fleas from rodents, not livestock. Orientia tsutsugamushi (Option D): Scrub typhus; transmitted by chigger mites; seen in rural/forest scrub areas, not directly from livestock.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: A patient presents with fever after returning from a forest trip. On examination, a black eschar is noted on the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its drug of choice?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and a black eschar (site of the bite) after a forest trip is suggestive of mild to moderate Scrub Typhus in which Doxycycline is given. 187 Scrub typhus Causative agent Orientia tsutsugamushi (bacteria) Transmission Chiggers (larval mites) Vector Trombiculid mite (Leptotrombidium) Geographical distribution Endemic in the “tsutsugamushi triangle” (parts of Asia, Australia, Pacific Islands). Clinical manifestations Fever, headache, muscle pain, eschar (dark, scab-like lesion at the site of bite), and lymphadenopathy. Diagnosis Serological tests (ELISA, immunofluorescence) and molecular methods (PCR). Treatment Antibiotics (Doxycycline, Azithromycin) Prevention Avoid mite-infested areas, wearing protective clothing, and using insect repellants. Complications Organ failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), neurological complications. 188 Penicillin (Option A): Not effective against rickettsial organisms. Ceftriaxone (Option C): Used for bacterial meningitis, typhoid, gonorrhea, not scrub typhus. Artesunate (Option D): Antimalarial; used for severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: A diabetic patient presents with whitish plaques in the oral cavity. A KOH mount confirms the presence of budding yeast with pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for isolation of this organism?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis is Oral candidiasis/ Moniliasis, indicated by the presence of white patches in the oral cavity and the patient's risk factor such as diabetes. It is caused by Candida albicans, which is cultured on SDA agar. Investigations for Candida albicans:  KOH: This shows budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae  Fungal culture: It shows a creamy white colony.  Germ Tube Test is a screening test that is used to differentiate Candida Albicans from other yeast. When Candida is grown in human or sheep serum at 37°C for 3 hours, they form a germ tube, which can be detected with a wet KOH films as filamentous outgrowth extending from yeast cells. 190 Germ Tube Test Culture KOH Mount Oral candidiasis Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast. Presentation Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red, inflamed base 191 Risk factors  Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.  Neutropenia  Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increase susceptibility.  Use of inhaled corticosteroids  Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.  Poor Oral Hygiene: Leads to an increase in fungal colonisation.  Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis. Treatment  Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.  C. krusei- Resistant to azoles Chocolate agar(Option A): Enriched medium for fastidious bacteria (Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria), not fungi. Thayer-Martin medium(Option C): Selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae & N. meningitidis; contains antibiotics to suppress other microbes. Loeffler’s serum slope(Option D):Enrichment medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.question_text: What is the vector responsible for transmitting the Zika virus among the options listed? 192?
questions.explanation: Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is one of the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Zika virus. This mosquito species, along with Aedes aegypti, plays a major role in the spread of Zika, as well as other viral infections like dengue and chikungunya. Zika virus:  Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA. Transmission:  ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito.  Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation. 193 The life cycle of Zika virus Clinical Manifestations:  Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.  Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.  Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.  Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis. Laboratory Diagnosis:  Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.  IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.  Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins. Options A, C, and D are
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old man develops profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic. There is no fever. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: The very short incubation period (1–6 hours) after food ingestion, combined with the absence of fever and the involvement of dairy/salad-type foods, points strongly to preformed, heat-stable enterotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.  S. aureus produces enterotoxins (types A, B, C, D, E) that are resistant to heat and gastric enzymes, leading to sudden-onset nausea, vomiting, and sometimes diarrhea.  Because illness is due to ingestion of toxin (not bacterial multiplication in the body), symptoms appear rapidly and resolve within 24–48 hours. Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Causes a toxin-mediated diarrheal illness but incubation is longer (usually 8–16 h) and linked to reheated meat/gravies. Salmonella enterica (Option B): Typically causes invasive gastroenteritis with longer incubation (6–72 h) and fever. Bacillus cereus (Option D): Has two syndromes - emetic form (short incubation 1–5 h, often linked to chinese food) and diarrheal form (longer).
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A woman presents with sudden-onset high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse rash, and a history of using a tampon for an extended period. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical triad (fever, hypotension/shock, diffuse erythrodermic rash with history of tampon use) is most consistent with Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) caused by toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus (TSST-1) or sometimes group A Streptococcus.  TSST-1 is a superantigen that triggers massive, non-specific T-cell activation and cytokine release → shock and rash; desquamation of palms/soles later is typical. Major Criteria (All Required)  Acute fever; temperature >38.8° C (101.8° F)  Hypotension (orthostatic, shock; blood pressure below age-appropriate norms)  Rash (erythroderma with convalescent desquamation) Minor Criteria (Any 3 or more)  Mucous membrane inflammation (vaginal, oropharyngeal or conjunctival hyperemia, strawberry tongue)  Vomiting, diarrhea  Liver abnormalities (bilirubin or transaminase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)  Renal abnormalities (blood urea nitrogen or creatinine greater than twice the upper limit of normal, or greater than 5 white blood cells per high-power field) 196  Muscle abnormalities (myalgia or creatinine phosphokinase greater than twice the upper limit of normal)  CNS abnormalities (alteration in consciousness without focal neurologic signs)  Thrombocytopenia Treatment:  Supportive - IVFluids +/- Ionotropes  One course of Anti-staphylococcal antibiotics Septic shock (Option A): May cause hypotension and high fever, but TSS has a characteristic diffuse rash and association with tampon/exogenous foreign body and superantigen mechanism. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (Option C): Presents with pelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness; systemic hypotension and diffuse rash are not characteristic. Streptococcal pharyngitis (Option D): Localized sore throat ± fever; not the shock/rash pattern described.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Receptor used for the entry of HIV virus into the host cell is?
questions.explanation: CCR5 (C-C chemokine receptor type 5) is one of the primary receptors used by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) to enter host cells. Specifically, CCR5 is found on the 197 surface of CD4+ T cells and other immune cells, and HIV binds to it along with CD4 (another receptor) in order to gain entry into the host cell. Modes of Transmission of HIV  Sexual Transmission: ○ Most common (75% of cases). ○ Heterosexual Route: Male to female via vaginal intercourse is typical; risk per encounter is low (0.1–1%). Higher risk with anal intercourse.  Blood Transfusion: Least common (5% of cases) but has a high transmission risk (90–95%).  Percutaneous/Mucosal Transmission: Includes needle stick injuries and sharing razors; less effective compared to sexual transmission.  Perinatal Transmission: 20–40% risk of mother-to-fetus transmission without intervention; highest risk during delivery.  Casual Contact: No evidence of transmission through casual contact, kissing, or insect bites.  Viral Load: Highest in blood, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal fluid; minimal in saliva and other body fluids.  Saliva: Contains substances that may inhibit HIV transmission. Pathogenesis:  Receptor Attachment ○ Main Receptor: ■ HIV binds its gp120 to the CD4 receptor on host cells, primarily expressed on helper T cells and other cells like monocytes and macrophages. ○ Co-Receptors: Fusion requires a second receptor: ■ CXCR4: Found on T lymphocytes. ■ CCR5: Present on macrophage lineage cells. (Option B) ○ DC-SIGN: ■ A dendritic cell-specific receptor that binds HIV-1 but does not mediate entry; facilitates transport to lymphoid organs. ○ CCR5 Delta 32 Mutation: ■ Mutation can block HIV entry: 1. Homozygous individuals are resistant to HIV (1% of Northern Europeans). 2. Heterozygous individuals may have delayed progression to AIDS (10–15% of Europeans).  Replication 198 Options A, C, and D are
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: What is the most likely causative agent for a Tzanck smear showing multinucleated cells?
questions.explanation: A positive Tzanck smear demonstrates multinucleated giant epithelial cells and is classically associated with herpetic infections — most commonly Herpes simplex virus (HSV).  The presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck supports a herpesvirus family etiology (HSVor VZV), but HSV is the most frequent cause for localized herpetic lesions. Varicella-zoster virus (Option A): Also a herpesvirus and can produce multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck; however, when asked “most likely” in a general context, HSV is the usual single best answer for a positive Tzanck smear. Human papillomavirus (Option C): Causes koilocytosis — not multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck. Coxsackievirus A16 (Option D): Causes HFMD; does not give a positive Tzanck smear.
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism? 200?
questions.explanation: The given image is of E. histolytica trophozoites.  Entamoeba histolytica is the causative organism of amoebic dysentery, which can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and sometimes bloody stools. In the case of a child presenting with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea, Entamoeba histolytica should be strongly considered, especially when stool examination reveals characteristic trophozoites or cysts under the microscope. These trophozoites often have a distinctive central nucleus and can cause tissue destruction in the colon, leading to ulcerations and diarrhea. Entamoeba histolytica Trophozoite Cyst 202  Pointed pseudopodia  Single nucleus  Central karyosome  Cartwheel nucleus  Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBCs)  1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate  Thick Chromatoid body/ bar: ○ Composition: Ribonucleoprotein (RNP) ○ Stain: Iron hematoxylin Entamoeba histolytica Entamoeba coli Trophozoite  Pointed pseudopodia  1 nucleus  Central karyosome  Cartwheel nucleus  Erythrophagocytosis Trophozoite  Blunt pseudopodia  1 nucleus  Eccentric karyosome  No cartwheel nucleus  No erythrophagocytosis Cyst  1 to 4 nuclei- Quadrinucleate  Thick chromatoid body/bar Cyst  1 to 8 nuclei- Octanucleate  Thin filamentous chromatoid body/bar 203 Giardia lamblia (Option A): While Giardia can cause diarrhea (typically watery diarrhea), it doesn't typically cause bloody diarrhea or the same type of abdominal pain associated with Entamoeba histolytica. Giardia trophozoites would also look different under the microscope, with a characteristic "pear-shaped" appearance and two nuclei. Shigella dysenteriae (Option B): Shigella causes bacillary dysentery, which typically presents with bloody diarrhea and severe abdominal cramping. However, the stool exam would usually show bacilli or a lack of cysts or amoeboid cells, which would be different from what is seen with Entamoeba histolytica. Campylobacter jejuni (Option D): Campylobacter infection is another cause of diarrhea, and it is commonly associated with watery or bloody diarrhea and fever. However, it typically presents with curved rods on a stool culture, and the stool examination findings in this case would not show the characteristic cysts or trophozoites seen with Entamoeba histolytica.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis? 204?
questions.explanation: Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen is a rapid, highly sensitive, and specific for cryptococcal antigen detection. It can detect antigen even before symptoms develop in AIDS patients. It is the best for rapid bedside diagnosis in resource-limited settings. Clinical features of cryptococcosis Respiratory system  Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection  Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.  Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule  Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs 205 Central Nervous System Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection Skin Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients. Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D) Other Organs Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections Management of cryptococcosis Microscopy  India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells  Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans 206 Culture  Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.  Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.  The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci Antigen detection tests Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutinationtest Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test. 207 Treatment  Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine  Maintenance Therapywith Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.  Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.  Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk. India Ink Preparation of CSF (Option A):  Detects the capsulated yeast Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF.  Useful but low sensitivity, especially in cases with low fungal burden. Blood Culture (Option B):  Can grow Cryptococcus in disseminated cases but takes several days.  Not a rapid diagnostic method. CSF Culture (Option C):  Gold standard but time-consuming (takes 3-7 days).  Requires Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal growth.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: Which organism is most commonly responsible for gas gangrene?
questions.explanation: Clostridium perfringens (especially type A strains that produce alpha toxin) is the classic cause of gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis) Gas Gangrene  Features ○ Skin discolouration (blackish) 210 ○ Pain ○ Discharge ○ Gas bubbles (Crepitus) ○ Shock  Mechanism Requires  Anaerobic environment  Contamination of wound α-toxin/Lecithinase damages cell membranes ↓ Capillary permeability ↓ Tension in muscles ↓ Further anoxia  Causative factors ○ C. perfringens: 10-48 hours ○ C. septicum: 2-3 days ○ C. novyi: 5-6 days  Treatment ○ Surgical Debridement ○ IV Penicillin + Clindamycin for 10-14 days ○ Hyperbaric oxygen  Passive Immunization: Anti-gangrene serum Clostridium difficile (Option A): Causes antibiotic-associated colitis (pseudomembranous colitis), not gas gangrene. Clostridium tetani (Option B): Causes tetanus (neurotoxin-mediated spastic paralysis). Clostridium botulinum (Option D): Produces botulinum toxin, causing flaccid paralysis; not gas gangrene.

questions.question_text: A woman was bitten by a rabid dog. The dog developed symptoms and died within a week. What is the best method for antemortem diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The best method for antemortem diagnosis of rabies isthe DFAT (Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test).  In suspected rabies before death, the aim is to detect rabies virus antigen in accessible tissues/fluids. DFAT is the gold standard antemortem test:  Uses fluorescent-labelled antibodies specific for rabies virus.  Can be done on corneal smears, nuchal skin biopsy (hair follicles), or saliva.  Gives rapid, sensitive, and specific results. Detection of Negri bodies (Option A): Negri bodies (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons) are seen on histology of infected brain tissue. This is a postmortem finding, not antemortem. Seller’s staining (Option C): Seller’s stain highlights Negri bodies in brain tissue. This is a postmortem confirmation method. 212 Brain biopsy (Option D): Invasive, rarely done for antemortem rabies diagnosis.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 3-month-old child was admitted with pneumonia. The microscopy shows the following image. Choose the correct organism.
questions.explanation: The given structure is identified on the basis of the enveloped, 8 segmented RNA virus, which is found in Influenza virus. Classification:  Family: Orthomyxoviridae  Type: Enveloped virus  Genome: Segmented, single-stranded negative-sense RNA (–ssRNA)  Segments: 8 separate RNA segments (in influenza A and B; C has 7) A. Outer Envelope  Derived from host cell membrane during budding.  Contains two major glycoprotein spikes: ○ Hemagglutinin (HA) ■ Mediates viral attachment to host cells by binding sialic acid receptors. ■ Initiates membrane fusion during viral entry. ■ Target for neutralizing antibodies. ○ Neuraminidase (NA) ■ Cleaves sialic acid residues to release newly formed virions from infected cells. ■ Target for antiviral drugs (e.g., oseltamivir, zanamivir).  Envelope also contains M2 ion channel protein: ○ Important for uncoating of the virus by altering pH inside the virion. B. Matrix Layer  Just beneath the envelope.  Matrix protein M1: ○ Provides structural stability. ○ Links the envelope to the ribonucleoprotein core. C. Ribonucleoprotein Core  8 separate negative-sense RNA segments. 214  Each RNA segment is bound to nucleoprotein (NP) and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase complex: ○ PB1, PB2, PA (polymerase basic proteins).  Segmented genome allows genetic reassortment → basis for antigenic shift. Special Features:  Segmented genome (8 pieces) → enables exchange of segments between strains → major cause of pandemics.  Antigenic drift: Minor changes in HA and NA due to point mutations → seasonal epidemics.  Antigenic shift: Major change due to reassortment of genome segments → pandemics. Rotavirus (Option B): Non eveloped, 11 segmented dsRNA virus. Hepatitis virus (Option C): None of the hepatitis virus have segmented genome.HAV (+ssRNA, non-enveloped), HBV (partially dsDNA, enveloped), HCV (+ssRNA, enveloped), HDV (–ssRNA, enveloped). Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Option D): Enveloped, non-segmented ssRNA virus.
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A 20-year-old male was admitted with fever, headache and retro-orbital pain with rash. The tourniquet test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A young adult with the classic triad of fever, headache and retroorbital pain, along with rash and positive tourniquet test, suggests that the patient has acquired dengue hemorrhagic fever. Pathophysiology in DHF  Caused by secondary infection with a different dengue virus serotype (DENV-1 to DENV-4).  Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) leads to: ○ Increased vascular permeability. ○ Plasma leakage → hypotension/shock (Dengue shock syndrome). ○ Thrombocytopenia and bleeding tendencies. Malaria (Option A): Presents with cyclical fevers, chills, anemia, splenomegaly. Measles (Option B): Fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, rash starting at hairline → spreads downwards. No history of retro-orbital pain, no positive tourniquet test. Japanese encephalitis (Option D): Arboviral disease with fever, headache, altered sensorium, seizures.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old man presents with headaches, visual disturbances, and hypertension. MRI brain shows a cerebellar hemangioblastoma, and abdominal imaging reveals multiple cysts in the kidneys along with a solid renal mass suggestive of renal cell carcinoma. His father had similar findings and died from a brain tumor in his 40s.Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, a hereditary condition characterised by the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, pancreas, and other organs.  Genetics and pathogenesis: ○ Inheritance: Autosomal dominant ○ Gene: VHL tumour suppressor ○ Chromosomal location: 3p25–26 ○ Pathogenesis: ■ The VHL gene product is part of a complex that degrades hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) under normal oxygen levels. ■ Mutation or deletion → HIF is not degraded → ↑ VEGF, PDGF → abnormal angiogenesis and tumour formation.  Classic tumours/cysts: ○ CNS: Hemangioblastomas (esp. cerebellum, retina, spinal cord) ○ Kidneys: Simple cysts, clear cell RCC ○ Adrenal glands: Pheochromocytoma - headaches, palpitations, and sweating ○ Pancreas: Cysts, neuroendocrine tumours ○ Inner ear: Endolymphatic sac tumours 13q deletion (Option A): RB1 gene loss → retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma. 17p deletion (Option B): TP53 loss → Li-Fraumeni syndrome (sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, adrenal carcinoma). Trisomy 12 (Option D): common cytogenetic change in CLL. 217
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: Mutation in which of the following genes is most commonly associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Medullary thyroid carcinomas are associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation.  Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid a neuroendocrine tumour arising from parafollicular C cells.  They secrete calcitonin, which regulates calcium levels and is also a marker for diagnosis and postoperative follow-up. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker in whom calcitonin is negative.  They can be sporadic or associated with familial syndromes like MEN 2.  Both have associated RET mutations.  Sporadic tumors usually present with solitary nodules whereas familial are characterized by bilaterality and multicentricity, and can have features of other associated tumors.  A biopsy would show amyloid deposits (Acal) derived from calcitonin polypeptides. 218 Thyroid Malignancy Mutations/Genetic Alterations Follicular Thyroid Adenoma (Benign Condition)  RAS (Option A) Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC)  BRAF V600E (Option B)  RET/PTC rearrangements Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC)  RAS (Option A)  PAX8-PPARγ rearrangements  PIK3CA Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)  RET (Option C) Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma (ATC)  TP53 (Option D)
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by mutations in which type of genes?
questions.explanation: HNPCC / Lynch syndrome is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes.  The most commonly affected genes are: ○ MLH1 ○ MSH2 ○ MSH6 ○ PMS2  Loss of these MMR proteins → failure to correct base-pairing errors → microsatellite instability (MSI) → increased risk of colorectal cancer (esp. right-sided) and extra-colonic cancers (endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract).  Lynch syndrome is associated with germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, leading to microsatellite instability (MSI).  MSI is a hallmark of Lynch syndrome-associated tumours, including colorectal adenocarcinoma. APC(Option A): tumor suppressor gene mutated in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), not Lynch syndrome. MYC(Option C): proto-oncogene involved in Burkitt lymphoma (t(8;14)), not colorectal cancer syndromes. TERT1(Option D): encodes telomerase reverse transcriptase; mutations linked to certain familial cancers but not HNPCC. 220
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by his mother with irritability, poor school performance, and a history of recurrent ear infections. Otoscopic examination shows a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with fluid behind it. There is no blood clot present in the ear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The key findings in this case—persistent symptoms without acute signs of infection, a dull and retracted tympanic membrane, and the presence of fluid behind the tympanic membrane without clot or acute purulence—are classic for otitis media with effusion (OME), also known as serous otitis media or glue ear. This condition is often associated with eustachian tube dysfunction, which can result from various underlying issues.  The most common cause of eustachian tube dysfunction in children is adenoid hyperplasia. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the eustachian tubes, impairing the drainage of fluid from the middle ear and leading to fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane. Serous Otitis Media (Glue Ear)  Serous Otitis Media (SOM) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of non-purulent, often thick effusion in the middle ear, commonly affecting school-aged children. 221 Pathogenesis:  The Eustachian tube fails to aerate and drain fluid from the middle ear.  Increased Secretory Activity of Middle Ear Mucosa. Aetiology: Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube Allergy Unresolved otitis media Viral infections  Adenoid hyperplasia.  Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis.  Chronic tonsillitis: Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function.  Nasophary ngeal tumours: Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media.  Palatal defects: e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis.  Down's syndrome. Seasonal or perennial allergies obstruct the Eustachian tube and increase middle ear mucosal secretions. Inadequate antibiotic therapy can lead to persistent, low-grade infection, stimulating more mucous production and increasing goblet cells. Adenoviruses and rhinoviruses can invade the middle ear mucosa, leading to increased secretory activity.
questions.subject: Microbiology

questions.question_text: A chronic smoker who worked in a cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. This association is most likely due to?
questions.explanation: Mesothelioma is a malignant tumour of the pleura (and sometimes peritoneum or pericardium) that is strongly associated with asbestos exposure. Asbestos fibres are commonly encountered in:  Shipbuilding  Construction  Cement manufacturing  Insulation materials 223 Chronic inhalation of asbestos fibres → fibres lodge in pleura → chronic inflammation & fibrosis → mutations → mesothelioma (and also increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma, especially in smokers).  Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.  Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking. Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma.  Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.  Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.  Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma. 224
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: Stapedial reflex is dependent on the integrity of which cranial nerve for its motor response?
questions.explanation: 225  The stapedial reflex (acoustic reflex) is a protective middle ear reflex in which loud sounds cause contraction of the stapedius muscle to dampen ossicular movement and protect the inner ear from acoustic injury.  Pathway: ○ Afferent limb: Cochlea → Cochlear nerve (CN VIII) → Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex. ○ Efferent limb (motor): Facial nerve (CN VII) → Stapedius muscle.  Clinical correlation: Lesions of the facial nerve proximal to the stapedius branch cause absent stapedial reflex and may lead to hyperacusis (increased sensitivity to sound). Topodiagnostic tests of Facial nerve: Test Nerve Branch Assessment/Outcome Schirmer’s Test Greater (superficial) petrosal nerve  A unilateral decrease in tear production (>75%) or  Bilateral reduction (less than 10 mm in both eyes after 5 minutes). Stapedial Reflex Nerve to stapedius muscle  Reflex is either present or absent Electro- gustometry Chorda tympani  The taste threshold is compared between the two sides to detect abnormalities Salivary Flow Testing Chorda tympani  A 25% reduction in salivary flow is considered abnormal
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: Which of the following subunit is associated with inspiratory stridor?
questions.explanation: Stridor is a high-pitched, harsh sound due to turbulent airflow through a partially obstructed upper airway. Inspiratory stridor specifically occurs when obstruction is at or above the level of the vocal cords, because negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration tends to collapse the upper airway. Supraglottic structures include:  Epiglottis  Aryepiglottic folds  False vocal cords Obstruction here (e.g., epiglottitis, laryngomalacia, tumors) narrows the airway at a point where airflow is very sensitive to pressure changes during inspiration. During inspiration → pressure above the glottis becomes subatmospheric → floppy tissue collapses inward → stridor.

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal discomfort. The surgical image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries.  They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers. Mature teratoma  Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases.  They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformationto squamous cell carcinoma.  Grossly, they are unilocularcysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands. Immature teratoma: (Option B)  Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.  They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary.  They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy.  They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components). Monodermal teratoma:  Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy. 229 Serous cystadenoma (Option A):  It is the most common ovarian epithelial tumor, usually seen in older women. It is unilocular, bilateral in >50% and is mostly malignant. The characteristic histologic feature is the presence of psamomma bodies (seen in 40-45%) which is composed of concentric rings of lamellar calcifications. Endometrioma (Option D): “chocolate cyst” of endometriosis, filled with old blood, not sebaceous material or calcified teeth.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: Basophilic stippling of red blood cells is most characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Basophilic stippling is a characteristic haematological finding in lead toxicity. Acute lead poisoning  It’s rare, and there may be exacerbations of chronic lead poisoning.  Symptoms: Astringent or metallic taste, dry throat, thirst, burning abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, peripheral circulatory collapse, paraesthesia, depression, coma, and death. 231 Chronic lead poisoning (also known as Plumbism or Saturnism) Clinical manifestations Description Facial pallor It is caused by vasospasm and specifically occurs circumorally, which is the earliest and most specific feature. Anemia  Type: Microcytic-hypochromic.  Enzymes inhibited: ○ Ferrochelatase ○ ALA-dehydratase ○ Coproporphyrinogen oxidase  Blood picture: ○ Cabot rings in RBCs ○ Microcytic-hypochromic ○ Sideroblasts (nucleated red cells) ○ Anisocytosis ○ Poikilocytosis ○ Polycythemia 232 Basophilic stippling or Punctate basophilia  Multiple blue-coloured pinhead dots in RBCs due to the toxic action of lead on porphyrin metabolism (inhibition of enzyme 5- Pyrimidine nucleotidase) (PNN).  Accumulation of ribosomes in RBC Lead line or Burtonian lines The stippled blue line observed on the gums, resulting from a subepithelial deposit of granules that develops within one week, is seen in 50-70% of cases and is more common in individuals with carious teeth (bacteria form lead sulfide). Lead osteopathy/Lead line (Bone-line) In children, calcium deposition occurs at the growth plates of bones (specifically the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia), which appears as a radiopaque band and occurs over 4 weeks due to the inhibition of osteoclastic activity. Colic and constipation (Painter's Colic or Devonshire colic) Late presentation occurs in 85% of cases, typically at night, and is characterised by spasmodic pain relieved by pressure. 233 Lead palsy Predominantly motor features include:  Dry belly ache  Wrist drop (Radial nerve)  Foot drop (Common peroneal nerve) Encephalopathy This condition is seen in nearly all cases, is associated with tetraethyl lead exposure, primarily affects children, results in permanent brain damage in 85% of cases, and accounts for 25% of fatalities. Reproductive system  Amenorrhea  Dysmenorrhea  Abortion  Sterility derangements (both sexes) 234 Cardiovascular system and Kidneys  Hypertension (vascular constriction)  Permanent arteriolar degeneration  Nephritis Gout Saturnine gout (due to decreased excretion of uric acid) Others These include generalised weakness, anorexia, dyspepsia, emaciation, exhaustion, irritability, foul breath, headache, vertigo, alopecia, and dizziness. Conditions associated with Basophilic stippling:  Lead poisoning  Thalassemia (Beta-thalassemia)  Sideroblastic anemia  Arsenic poisoning  Alcoholism  Pyrimidine 5′-Nucleotidase deficiency  Megaloblastic anemia  Severe infections (e.g., malaria)  Myelodysplastic syndromes  Chronic inflammatory conditions Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): microcytic hypochromic cells, but no basophilic stippling. Megaloblastic anaemia (Option C): macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils, no stippling. Hereditary spherocytosis (Option D): spherocytes, increased MCHC, but no stippling.
questions.subject: Forensic Medicine

questions.question_text: In Pap smear cytology, which of the following is the most appropriate fixative used to preserve cellular details immediately after smearing?
questions.explanation: 95% ethanol is the fixative used in a conventional pap smear. Fixatives are chemicals that preserve biological tissues by stabilizing cellular structures and preventing decay or degradation. The goal is to maintain the tissue in a life-like state as much as possible for microscopic examination.  Fixation helps maintain the tissue's integrity by preventing autolysis (self-digestion) and putrefaction (bacterial decay).  Crosslinking Fixatives: These fixatives work by forming covalent bonds between the proteins and other cellular structures, effectively "locking" them in place. This preserves the tissue’s structural integrity. ○ Formaldehyde: Most commonly used in the form of 10% neutral-buffered formalin. (Option D) ○ Glutaraldehyde: Often used for electron microscopy due to its ability to preserve fine cellular structures. ○ Osmium tetroxide: Used primarily for electron microscopy, particularly for preserving lipids and membranes.  Precipitating Fixatives: These work by precipitating proteins and other cellular components, which makes them less soluble and helps preserve their structure. ○ Methanol ○ Ethanol 236  Additive Fixatives: They chemically bind to tissue components, such as proteins or nucleic acids, and stabilise them. They are typically more gentle and produce better preservation of ultrastructure. ○ Formaldehyde (Option A) ○ Glutaraldehyde  Non-Additive Fixatives: ○ Alcohol ○ Acetone Pap smear Site  The transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.  This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop. Instruments  Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix  Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone  Endocervical brush from the endocervix Procedure  Conventional Pap smear: Cells are collected with a spatula or brush, smeared onto a slide, and immediately fixed with a spray fixative or by immersing in 95% ethanol with/without ether  Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 12-year-old child presents with short stature. On evaluation, the bone age is found to be less than the chronological age. There are no dysmorphic features, and the child is otherwise healthy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.option_a: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
questions.explanation: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP) is the most common cause of short stature in otherwise healthy children. It is characterized by:  Normal birth length and weight  Slowing of growth velocity during early childhood  Bone age delayed compared to chronological age  No dysmorphic features  Normal growth potential — eventual catch-up and normal adult height  Often a family history of “late bloomers”
questions.subject: Anatomy

questions.question_text: A newborn, born to a diabetic mother, presents after 24 hours of life with a blood glucose level of <35 mg/dL. The baby is symptomatic. What is the next best step in management?
questions.option_a: Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution
questions.option_c: Administer IV glucose and recheck blood glucose after 20 minutes
questions.explanation: In a symptomatic newborn with blood glucose <35 mg/dL, immediate correction is necessary to prevent seizures and brain injury. The standard approach is:  Give an IV bolus of 10% dextrose (2 mL/kg)  Follow with a continuous glucose infusion (usually 6–8 mg/kg/min)  Recheck glucose after 20–30 minutes to ensure correction This is particularly important in infants of diabetic mothers, who are at high risk for hypoglycemia due to persistent fetal hyperinsulinism after birth. Management of Hypoglycemia in neonates: 239

questions.question_text: Which genetic syndrome is caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion)?
questions.explanation: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion). The name “cri-du-chat” (French for “cry of the cat”) refers to the characteristic high-pitched, cat-like cry of affected infants due to laryngeal hypoplasia and abnormal development of the nervous system.  Other features include microcephaly, hypertelorism, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, developmental delay, and severe intellectual disability.

questions.question_text: A young boy is brought to the clinic for developmental assessment. On examination, he has a prominent epicanthal fold, a single transverse palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability. Facial features appear flat with upslanting palpebral fissures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21 and is the most common chromosomal cause of intellectual disability. Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.  This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.  Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns. The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features. Clinical Features and Diagnosis: General Features:  Intellectual disability  Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).  Small nose with flat nasal bridge  Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue  Significant hypotonia  Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears  Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)  Simian crease on the palm  A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap) Comorbidities  Congenital Heart Disease:: 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF. Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.  Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.  Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.  Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.  Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients. 242  Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.  Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.  Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.  Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 10-year-old child weighs 40 kg and presents with mental retardation. On examination, the upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio is 1.1:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In a 10-year-old, the normal upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio is about 0.9:1 (lower segment longer than upper segment due to leg growth).  A higher US:LS ratio (e.g., 1.1:1) means the upper segment is disproportionately longer, suggesting shortening of the lower segment — commonly due to rickets or other conditions affecting long bone growth.  Rickets in childhood causes defective mineralization of bone, leading to limb deformities and disproportionate short stature.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: FBN1 gene mutation is seen in which of the following genetic disorders?
questions.explanation: Marfan syndrome is commonly associated with mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes the connective protein fibrillin on chromosome 15q21. Pathophysiology:  Abnormal fibrillin-1 → defective microfibrils → weakened elastic fibres.  This leads to increased TGF-β activity, which contributes to the characteristic features of the syndrome. Mode of inheritance:  Autosomal dominant.  Multisystem disorder with involvement of the connective tissues. Clinical features: Skeletal abnormalities:  Tall, thin build with long limbs (dolichostenomelia)  Arachnodactyly  Chest wall abnormalities like pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum  Thumb sign( On folding the thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive  Increased joint laxity  Scoliosis CVS abnormalities:  Aortic root dilation → aortic regurgitation  Risk of aortic aneurysm and dissection  Mitral valve prolapse  Arrhythmias Eye abnormalities:  Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye  Blindness, Myopia 245 Pulmonary involvement:  Increased risk of pneumothorax Diagnosis:  Marfan syndrome is clinically diagnosed using the Ghent criteria Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option A): Usually due to collagen synthesis defects (type III or type V collagen), not FBN1. Homocystinuria (Option C): Due to cystathionine β-synthase deficiency → high homocysteine levels; may have marfanoid habitus but with downward lens dislocation and thrombosis risk. Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (Option D): Due to VHL gene mutation on chromosome 3p, not FBN1; characterized by hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.

questions.question_text: A mutation in the SOD1 gene is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: 246  The SOD1 gene encodes superoxide dismutase 1, an enzyme responsible for breaking down harmful superoxide radicals into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. This protects cells from oxidative damage. SOD1 and ALS:  Condition: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.  Type: SOD1 mutations account for about 20% of familial ALS cases (familial ALS ~10% of all ALS cases).  Mechanism: ○ Mutant SOD1 misfolds → gains toxic properties → causes oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. ○ This leads to degeneration of both upper motor neurons (in motor cortex) and lower motor neurons (in brainstem and spinal cord). Clinical Features of ALS:  Mixed UMN and LMN signs: ○ UMN: Spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign. ○ LMN: Fasciculations, muscle atrophy, weakness.  Progressive, usually fatal within 3–5 years (respiratory failure common).  Sensation and cognition are usually preserved (helps differentiate from MS or other neuropathies). Huntington’s disease (Option A): CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene (chromosome 4). Multiple sclerosis (Option B): Autoimmune demyelination, not linked to SOD1. Parkinson's disease (Option C): Often linked to mutations in SNCA, LRRK2, PARK genes, not SOD1.

questions.question_text: Blood transfusion reactions are mediated by which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.explanation: Blood transfusion reactions (specifically acute hemolytic transfusion reactions) occur when the recipient’s immune system attacks donor red blood cells due to ABO incompatibility. Mechanism:  Type of hypersensitivity: Type II (antibody-mediated cytotoxic).  Pathophysiology: 1. Pre-existing IgM antibodies in the recipient bind to antigens (A or B) on donor RBCs. 2. This activates the complement cascade, leading to: ■ RBC lysis (intravascular hemolysis) ■ Release of haemoglobin ■ Inflammatory cytokine release 3. Clinical presentation: fever, chills, hypotension, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, possible DIC. 248 Type I (Option A): IgE-mediated (allergies, anaphylaxis). Type III (Option C): Immune complex–mediated (e.g., serum sickness, post-strep GN). Type IV (Option D): T-cell–mediated (delayed, e.g., TB skin test, contact dermatitis).
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A 58-year-old male with history of multiple sexual partners presented with anorexia and jaundice. The biopsy shows ground-glass opacity in the cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A diabetic male presented with seizures. Radiological examination shows a lesion. Histopathological examination shows liquefactive necrosis. What is the most important mechanism responsible for this?
questions.explanation: Diabetic patient with seizures → raises suspicion for a brain lesion (possibly abscess, infarct, or infection-related pathology).  Histopathology: liquefactive necrosis → classic type of necrosis seen in brain tissue.  Liquefactive necrosis in brain is mainly due to hydrolytic enzyme action breaking down tissue.  In the CNS, ischemia or infection activates microglia and infiltrating neutrophils.  These cells release lysosomal hydrolytic enzymes.  Brain tissue is rich in lipids and has little structural stroma, so enzymatic digestion quickly converts tissue into a liquid mass.  Mechanism: enzymatic degradation > structural breakdown → liquefactive necrosis. Mechanical (Option B): Trauma can cause hemorrhage or contusion, but necrosis type is not primarily from mechanical injury alone, here histology points to enzymatic breakdown. Ischemic (Option C): Ischemia in most organs causes coagulative necrosis, except in the brain, where it still leads to liquefactive necrosis, but the mechanism is enzymatic digestion, not ischemia per se. Pressure (Option D): Increased intracranial pressure can cause herniation or atrophy, not liquefactive necrosis by itself. 251
questions.subject: Pathology

questions.question_text: What is the eye manifestation seen in HLA B27-positive patients with ulcerative colitis?
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: An 8-year-old child presents with enuresis (bedwetting). The parents mention the child had a fall from bed once, but has no other significant medical history. There are no signs of urinary tract infection or neurological deficits. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation: In an 8-year-old with primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting since birth) and no evidence of urinary tract infection, neurological abnormality, or daytime symptoms, the first-line management is non-pharmacological behavioral measures. These include:  Limiting evening fluid intake  Scheduled voiding before bedtime  Positive reinforcement and reward systems  Enuresis alarms if behavioral methods alone are insufficient Pharmacological therapy like desmopressin or oxybutynin is reserved for cases where behavioral measures fail, or when there is a need for rapid short-term control (e.g., sleepovers, camps).
questions.subject: Pharmacology

questions.question_text: On January 1, 2024, an area with a population of 10,000 had 100 TB cases. During the year, 30 patients were cured and 10 died. Twenty new TB cases were reported, and 5 of them were cured before December 31, 2024. What is the incidence and prevalence of TB cases?
questions.explanation: Incidence (new cases during the year) and prevalence (total cases at a specific point in time, here end of year): Incidence:  Population at risk = Total population − existing cases on Jan 1 = 10,000 − 100 = 9,900  New TB cases during 2024 = 20  Incidence per 1,000 = (20 ÷ 9,900) × 1,000 = ≈ 2 per 1,000 254 Prevalence (Dec 31, 2024):  Remaining old cases = 100 − (30 cured + 10 died) = 60  Remaining new cases = 20 − 5 cured = 15  Total existing cases on Dec 31 = 60 + 15 = 75  Prevalence (%) = (75 ÷ 10,000) × 100 = 0.75% ≈ 1.2% Term Definition Formula Incidence New cases during a defined period among at-risk population (New cases ÷ Population at risk) × Multiplier Prevalence All existing cases (old + new) at a point in time (All cases ÷ Total population) × Multiplier  Incidence → measures risk of developing disease.  Prevalence → measures burden of disease. 1.2 and 10 (Option B) – Incidence is not 1.2 per 1,000 here; prevalence is not 10%. 1.2 and 12 (Option C) – Neither matches the calculated values. 2 and 10 (Option D) – Incidence matches, but prevalence is not 10%, it’s about 1.2%.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A 5-year-old child presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of cyanotic spells. On examination, there is clubbing and a harsh systolic murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 255?
questions.explanation: The child presents with cyanotic spells, exertional dyspnea, and clubbing, all classic signs of a cyanotic congenital heart disease.  A harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border is most consistent with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (pulmonary stenosis) in Tetralogy of Fallot. Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:  Pulmonary Stenosis: ○ Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.  Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): ○ A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.  Overriding Aorta: ○ The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.  Right Ventricular Hypertrophy: ○ Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: Which of the following is considered harmful to a newborn baby in the immediate postnatal period?
questions.option_a: Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab
questions.option_b: Giving a bath immediately after birth
questions.option_d: Placing the baby on the mother's chest
questions.explanation: Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is harmful because it:  Causes hypothermia due to rapid heat loss  Delays skin-to-skin contact and early initiation of breastfeeding  Increases the risk of respiratory distress in a cold-stressed baby  Removes the vernix caseosa, which has protective antimicrobial and moisturizing properties WHO recommends delaying the first bath for at least 24 hours after birth (or at least 6 hours if cultural reasons necessitate earlier bathing).
questions.subject: Ophthalmology

questions.question_text: In which of the following should a cotton swab with pus be discarded?
questions.explanation: Cotton swab with pus = soiled waste (items contaminated with blood, body fluids, pus, etc.).  Soiled waste → Yellow category (non-chlorinated plastic bags).  Chlorination is avoided for biodegradable waste like cotton, gauze, bandages, etc., as these are incinerated. Biomedical Waste Management Summary 259  Fetus, organ, tissue, soiled cotton, gauze, dressing, bandages, casts, plasters, IUD, expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic waste, body secretions e.g. sputum, pus, feces, X-ray developer fluids, disinfectants, linens, beddings, mattress, gowns, culture plates, blood bags, blood transfusion sets, live vaccine vial, blood products, masks, shoe cover, head cover: Yellow bag for incineration, plasma pyrolysis, and deep burial.  Recyclable plastics, tubes, vacutainers without blood, syringes without needles, urobags, catheters, Ryle's tubes, IV drip sets, face shields, goggles: Red bag.  Sharps and other metals: White bag.  Orthopaedic implants, glassware, artificial pacemaker: Blue bag. Yellow chlorination bag (Option A): Not used; yellow category waste is incinerated, so chlorination is unnecessary. Red chlorination bag (Option C): The red category is for contaminated recyclable waste (e.g., tubing, catheters), not soiled waste. Red non-chlorination bag (Option D): Still

questions.question_text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a respiratory rate of 66 breaths per minute, along with chest indrawing and nasal flaring. There are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In infants aged 2–12 months, WHO IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) classifies:  Pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing with fast breathing (≥50 breaths/min in 2–12 months) without danger signs.  Severe pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing plus any danger sign (e.g., chest indrawing with general danger signs such as inability to feed, lethargy, convulsions, hypoxia). Classification Signs Treatment Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease Any general danger sign OR  Oxygen saturation <90%  Stridor in calm child  Central cyanosis  Convulsions  AVPU = V, P, or U  Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.  Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.  Give diazepam if convulsing.  Prevent low blood sugar.  Treat wheeze if present.  Urgent referral or admission. Pneumonia Chest indrawing in calm child OR Fast breathing AND No signs of severe pneumonia  Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.  Give Vitamin A.  Treat wheeze if present.  Follow up in 5 days  Advise on immediate return signs. No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease  Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days  Advise on immediate return signs. 261 In this case:  Age = 4 months (threshold for tachypnea ≥50/min; child has 66/min).  Signs = Chest indrawing, nasal flaring, but no danger signs like inability to feed, cyanosis, altered consciousness. ○ Fits pneumonia classification, not severe pneumonia.
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: What is the most common cause of jaundice in this newborn presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, high alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in liver biopsy specimens, suggestive of Alpha 1 AT deficiency?
questions.explanation: Neonatal hepatitis: 263 Neonatal hepatitis is inflammation of the liver that occurs in newborn infants. It can be caused by various factors, including viral infections (such as hepatitis viruses), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and drug-induced liver injury. In the given scenario, the presentation indicative of neonatal hepatitis includes:  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia  Intrahepatic cholestasis  High alkaline phosphatase,  Presence of eosinophilic PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules on liver biopsy
questions.subject: Medicine

questions.question_text: An elderly man presents with leg deformities and skeletal abnormalities. On examination, he is using crutches and has visible bowing of the legs. It is also noted that several other villagers exhibit similar symptoms. Considering the cluster of cases in the same geographic area, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the investigation?
questions.option_d: Collect and analyze water samples for fluoride content
questions.explanation: A cluster of similar skeletal deformities in people from the same village suggests an environmental cause rather than an individual nutritional or endocrine disorder. Endemic skeletal fluorosis from high fluoride levels in drinking water causes bowing of legs, bone pain, and deformities. Therefore, the most logical next step is testing the local water supply for fluoride concentration. Endemic fluorosis:  Caused by long-term ingestion of water with fluoride >1.5 mg/L.  Early signs: joint stiffness, dental fluorosis.  Late signs: bony overgrowths, deformities, restricted movements.  Prevention: defluoridation of water, alternative safe water sources. 270 Check serum vitamin D levels (Option A): Could detect rickets/osteomalacia, but wouldn’t explain a cluster in the same area. Measure serum calcium levels (Option B): Useful for metabolic bone diseases, but not the primary step in an environmental cluster investigation. Perform parathyroid hormone (PTH) assay (Option C): For hyper/hypoparathyroidism; not first-line in a suspected environmental outbreak.
questions.subject: Physiology

questions.question_text: A teenage boy, who was previously raised as a girl, presents with primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. On examination, he has tall stature, small testes, and gynecomastia. Testosterone level was normal. Which of the following is the most likely genotype?
questions.explanation: The presentation fits Klinefelter syndrome, a condition with 47,XXY karyotype. Key features include:  Genotypic male but with small, firm testes and primary testicular failure  Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs  Gynecomastia and sparse facial/body hair  Often detected at puberty due to delayed secondary sexual characteristics or infertility  Testosterone may be in the low–normal range due to Leydig cell dysfunction, with elevated gonadotropins (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: A patient presents with increased consumption of Bajra (pearl millet) roti and now complains of drowsiness and giddiness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Bajra (pearl millet) can be contaminated with Claviceps purpurea (ergot fungus), which produces ergot alkaloids. These alkaloids cause vasoconstriction and may lead to symptoms like giddiness, drowsiness, tingling, and, in severe cases, gangrene or convulsions. Ergotism is classically linked to the consumption of contaminated grains like millet, rye, or sorghum. Food intoxicants: Condition Toxin Food Source Prevention Neurolathyrism Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal/grass pea) Vitamin C, steeping, parboiling Endemic Ascites Pyrrolizidine alkaloids Contaminated cereals with Crotalaria seeds Avoid contaminated grains Epidemic Dropsy Sanguinarine Mustard oil adulterated with Argemone oil Pre-testing (Nitric acid chromatography test), De-weeding Aflatoxicosis Aflatoxin B₁ Mouldy groundnuts, maize Proper drying & storage Ergotism Ergot alkaloids Rye, bajra, wheat with ergot fungus Floating plant in 20% salt solution Epidemic dropsy (Option A): Caused by Argemone mexicana contamination of mustard oil → edema, diarrhea, cardiac failure; not related to Bajra. Botulism (Option C): Caused by Clostridium botulinum toxin from improperly canned food → descending flaccid paralysis, not drowsiness from grain consumption. 273 Fusarium toxicity (Option D): From Fusarium fungi → alimentary toxic aleukia with pancytopenia; not typically linked to Bajra in this presentation.
questions.subject: ENT

questions.question_text: A mother brings her 9-month-old baby, concerned that no BCG scar has appeared, although the baby received the BCG vaccine at birth. What is the next best step?
questions.option_c: Do the Mantoux test & wait for the result
questions.option_d: Refer the baby for a chest X-ray & further evaluation
questions.explanation: After BCG vaccination, some children may not develop a visible scar, even though they have adequate immunity. No BCG scar is not an indication for revaccination if the child is otherwise healthy. WHO and national immunization guidelines recommend no further action in such cases- simply reassure the caregiver. BCG Vaccine  Type: Live attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis  Schedule: Single dose at birth (or as early as possible till 1 year of age)  Dose & route: 0.05 mL (infants <1 yr), 0.1 mL (≥1 yr) — intradermal, left upper arm  Purpose: Protection against severe forms of childhood TB (TB meningitis, miliary TB)  Contraindications: Symptomatic HIV infection, immunodeficiency, pregnancy, generalized skin disease  Storage: Lyophilized form at 2–8 °C; reconstituted vaccine stable for 3–4 hours only  Adverse events: Local ulcer at site, regional lymphadenitis, keloid (rare) 274  Coverage target: Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) Give the BCG vaccine immediately (Option B): Revaccination is not recommended; lack of scar doesn’t mean lack of immunity. Do Mantoux test & wait for the result (Option C): Not required in an asymptomatic, healthy, vaccinated child. Refer for chest X-ray & further evaluation (Option D): Only indicated if there are clinical features suggestive of TB.
questions.subject: Community Medicine

questions.question_text: Out of the MR & Pentavalent vaccine, which can be reused, and which one should be discarded when the vial is opened according to the open vial policy?
questions.explanation: Open Vial Policy (WHO guidelines) allows certain multi-dose vials to be reused for up to 28 days after opening if:  They have no preservative contamination.  They are kept under proper cold chain conditions (2–8 °C). Pentavalent vaccine → liquid formulation with preservative → can be reused until expiry within the 28-day rule. 275 MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccine → lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder without preservative, reconstituted with diluent before use → must be discarded within 4 hours of reconstitution, irrespective of remaining doses. Open Vial Policy:  Allows certain vaccines to be used in multiple immunization sessions after opening the vial, if stored and handled properly. If the vaccine is under the open vial policy then VVM will bw on the body (not on cap/neck). Purpose:  Reduce vaccine wastage  Ensure uninterrupted immunization services  Lower programme costs without compromising safety. The vaccine can be kept and used for up to 28 days after opening only if:  Vaccine is WHO-prequalified for MDVP use  Vaccine vial is kept at recommended storage temperature (+2°C to +8°C)  VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) has not crossed discard point  Expiry date has not passed  Aseptic technique used every time vial is opened  Reconstituted vaccines (like BCG, Measles, MR, JE) must be discarded within 6 hours or at the end of the session — no exception. Vaccines NOT under Open Vial Policy:  BCG  Measles / MR  COVID 19 (use within 8 hours) Discard Pentavalent, reuse MR (Option B): Wrong - MR cannot be used after 4 hous of reconstitution, so it must be discarded. Discard both MR and Pentavalent (Option C): Wrong - Pentavalent can be reused if stored properly. Reuse both MR and Pentavalent (Option D): Wrong - MR cannot be reused after 4 hours of reconstitution.
questions.subject: Community Medicine

questions.question_text: In a group, the mean blood glucose level is 105 mg/dL with a standard deviation of 10 mg/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the expected range of blood glucose values for approximately 95% of the population?
questions.explanation: In a normal distribution, approximately 95% of the population’s values lie within ±2 standard deviations (SD) from the mean.  Mean = 105 mg/dL  SD = 10 mg/dL  Range for 95% = Mean ± (2 × SD) = 105 ± 20 = 85 to 125 mg/dL. For normally distributed data, proportions within SD multiples are standard: ~68% within ±1 SD, ~95% within ±1.96 (≈±2) SD, ~99.7% within ±3 SD (empirical rule). 101 – 110 mg/dL (Option B): This is a much narrower range (±0.5 SD), covering far less than 95% of the population. 90 – 125 mg/dL (Option C): The lower limit is off; this is Mean − 1.5 SD to Mean + 2 SD, not a standard 95% range. 95 – 115 mg/dL (Option D): This is only Mean ± 1 SD, covering about 68% of the population. 281
questions.subject: Radiology

questions.question_text: In a family with three siblings, the eldest sibling moves out of the household, and a new (third) child is born. What is this change in the family structure called?
questions.explanation: Here, a new child is born into the family, and at the same time, there are already other children in different stages (eldest has moved out, middle child still at home). Complete extension means the family grows with members in different stages of life - younger children, older children, and parents present in the family cycle. Family life cycle: Sequence of changes a family undergoes over time. The main stages are: 282 1. Formation: Creation of a new family unit (usually marriage or cohabitation). 2. Extension: Addition of new members (e.g., birth of a child) without losing existing members. 3. Complete Extension: Addition of members from multiple generations (e.g., grandparents moving in + birth of grandchildren). 4. Contraction: Loss of members (e.g., children leaving home, death of elderly) without replacement. 5. Complete Contraction: Loss of members leaving only one or two people in the family unit. 6. Dissolution: The family unit breaks due to the death of one spouse (widow/widower remains). 7. Extinction: Death of the last surviving family member. Formation (Option A): Creation of a new family unit (e.g., marriage/cohabitation beginning a household); not applicable here because the family already exists. Contraction (Option B): Reduction in family membership (death or permanent loss) without replacement; this scenario adds a member, so it is not contraction. 283 Extension (Option D): Refers to addition of members (e.g., a birth) but without the multi-stage/generational overlap
questions.subject: Pediatrics

questions.question_text: A person has recently moved from Nigeria to the United States. Which of the following vaccines is required for international travel from Nigeria to the USA?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever is endemic in several African countries, including Nigeria. The WHO’s International Health Regulations require travelers from countries with risk of yellow fever transmission to present a valid yellow fever vaccination certificate when entering certain countries, including the USA. This prevents international spread of the disease. Yellow Fever(17D) vaccine is a live-attenuated viral vaccine.  Single subcutaneous dose provides immunity for life  Required for travel from yellow fever-endemic areas to prevent spread to countries where the disease is not endemic.  Nigeria is a yellow fever endemic zone; hence proof of vaccination is mandatory.  Must be given at least 10 days before travel to be valid.  Contraindications: Infants <9 months, severe egg allergy, immunocompromised persons, pregnancy (relative). 284 Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine (Option B): Recommended for travelers to rural Asia-Pacific regions, not Nigeria–USA travel. Measles vaccine (Option C): Important for general immunization but not an international travel requirement between Nigeria and USA. Rabies vaccine (Option D): Given for post-exposure prophylaxis or pre-exposure for high-risk groups, not a routine travel requirement for this route.
questions.subject: Community Medicine

questions.question_text: A study was conducted using office records over the past 20 years to compare the incidence of disease among factory workers exposed to aniline dye and unexposed clerical staff. What type of epidemiological study is this?
questions.explanation: In this study, past office records were used to compare disease incidence between two groups: exposed and unexposed- over a 20-year period. Since the data were collected from past records and both exposure and outcome had already occurred before the start of the study, it is a retrospective study.  Retrospective study looks back in time using existing records or data. Both exposure and outcome have already occurred at the time the study starts. Often uses medical records, employment logs, or registries. Can be retrospective cohort if subjects are grouped by exposure and followed through past records to see outcomes. Advantages: Less time-consuming, less expensive than prospective studies. 285 Limitations: Dependent on the accuracy and completeness of past records. Types of analytical studies: Cross-sectional Case-control Cohort Ecological Snapshot of population (survey) Retrospective (effect → cause) Prospective (cause / risk factor → effect) Correlational (compare populations) Prevalence Study of choice: Rare diseases Incidence Correlation of variables Odds ratio Odds ratio Relative risk, Attributable risk, Population attributable risk – Unit of study: Individual Unit of study: Individual Unit of study: Individual Unit of study: Population – Recall bias Attribution bias Ecological fallacy Prospective study (Option A): Follows subjects forward in time from exposure to outcome; here, data are already in the past. Case-control study (Option C): Starts with diseased and non-diseased individuals, then looks back for exposure; here, groups were defined by exposure, not disease. Ecological study (Option D): Compares populations or groups, not individuals; this study uses individual-level data.
questions.subject: ENT
